item.title: Kish Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ur III

Figure 1: This 9.7 x 9cm terracotta relief depicts a canoe with two boatsmen. One boatsmen is holding on the the prow and the other is standing taking aim at what can be assumed to be an animal, although this part is missing from the plaque. The ends of the canoe are slightly upturned. Dating from Ur III period (2112-2004 BCE). Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 1841). de Graeve 1981: 22 - 23. See also: S.H Langdon, Excavations at Kish, I. p. 61, pl. VI, 2; P.R.S Moorey, in Iraq 37, (1975)

Figure 2: A partial terracotta plaque depicts a boatman squatting and paddling. Dating from Ur III period (2112-2004 BCE). 6cm x 6cm. de Graeve 1981: 23. See also: P.R.S Moorey, in Iraq 37, (1975). p. 94

item.title: Nippur Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ur III period

The boat depicted in relief is "elegant and fairly low". The feet of the standing boatman are visible and he is punting the boat, "with a cleaved stick" (de Graeve 1981: 23). 3.5cm x 6cm. 2112-2004 BCE. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (not catalogued). See also: D.E. McCown, Nippur I. pl. 138, 4.

item.title: Tel ed-Der Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Alternative site name: Sippar-Mmnanum

Old Babylonian Period 1894 - 1595 BCE

Figure 1: Model is missing one end. Flat bottomed model, finger prints are visible; "the preserved prow or stern ends in an incurving volute" (de Graeve 1981:28). Found in the 19th Century. 8cm x 18.5cm x 6.5cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad. (D 1728).

Figure 2: "Elegant shape of prow with vertical tip divided into two parts. A thick lump of clay with a hole in the center, presumably for holding the mast, is pressed against the inner side of the raised part." (de Graeve 1981:28-29). A similar mast socket in the prow also occurs in a boat model from Susa, probably from the same period. 6cm x 9.2cm x 6.8cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad. (D 3641).

item.title: Ishchali Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Alternative site names: Nerebtum, Kiti, Sadlas

Site Occupied from the Akkadian to Old Babylonian Periods

Figure 1: "Prow or stern of a detailed model with incurving end with mooring hole; indication of the frames and the centeral plank" (de Graeve 1981: 29). Date unknown. Dimensions: 7.5cm x 11cm x 8.4cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 31058). See also: C. Qualls, Report of the fellow in Mesopotamina Civilizations, 1973-74, in Newsletter ASOR 9 (April 1976), p. 3, fig. 1

Figure 2:  "This fragment shows the frames and the centeral plank of the vessel" (de Graeve 1981: 29). Date Unknown. Dimensions: 3.2cm x 7.6cm x 4.8cm. Space between frames is 0.3cm. Stichting Allard Pierson, Amsterdam (No 6418; Ish. 34 R 318). See also: A. Göttlicher, Corpus, p. 29, pl. 7, No. 94

item.title: Failaka Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Approximately 2000BCE (according to de Graeve 1981)

Figure 1: Circular seal with engraved boat that is angular and what is thought to be a horned gazzel head as the prow. A furled sail hung on the mast; two men standing in the boat, lastly "a palm frond and a rectangle are seen in the field." (de Graeve 1981:30-31). de Graeve surmises that "although their date cannot be determined with complete certainty, it can be placed approximately around 2000 BC[E]". Diameter 4.5 - 5cm. Failaka Archeological Musuem (not catalogued). See also: T.H. Carter, The Johns Hopkins University Reconnaissance Expedition to the Arab-Iranian Gulf, in BASOR 207 (Oct. 1972), p. 25, fig. 15; K. Frifelt, Arkaelogiske Undersøgelser på Oman Halvøen. En foreløbig, rapport, in Kuml 1968, pp. 162, 172, fig. 3

Figure 2: Seal is engraved with a sailing boat with a mast that is fastened at the base with rope. On mast hangs a furled sail, the prow has a horizontal line "for a large bird which perches upon it", there is a second bird that is perched on the stern behind the man who sits on the throne. "The man is dressed in a flounced garment and holds two long differently shaped objects aloft; one of the objects maybe a palm frond." (de Graeve 1981:31) de Graeve surmises that "although their date cannot be determined with complete certainty, it can be placed approximately around 2000 BC[E]". Diameter 3cm. Thickness 6mm. Kuwait National Museum (690 F 6). See also: Ministry of Guidance and Information, Dept. of Antiquity and Musuems, Archeological Investigations in the Island of Failaka, 1958-1964, Kuwait Government Press, p. 133, fig. 70

item.title: Nimrud Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
9th Century BC

Figure 1:  The relief depicts three men in the water, they are trying to reach the fortress while archers are attacking them. Two of the men swimming are supported by an inflated skin which they hold in their left hand. "They probably keep the aperture in their mouth to breathe additional air into it". the third, man is dead, he does not hold an inflated skin, "this is suggested by the two arrows in his back". (de Graeve 1981: 39). Dimensions 860cm x 220cm. British Museum, London (BM 124538, Nimrud Gallery 6a.). See also: E.A.W Budge, Ashurnasirpal, p. 12, pl. XIII, 2. 

Figure 2: Depicts four naked soldiers swimming and lying flat on inflated skins, which they hold in their left hands. One of the soldiers holds the reins of two horses, and another man who is not holding an inflated skin holds on to the reins of two other horses. There are two quaffas depicted, the one on the left is smaller and rounder - it transports a chariot and a wheel is shown outside of the vessel. The other quffa carries utensils. the quffa's are propelled by two rowers seated in opposite directions - the oars are fastened to the gunwales by straps and "the oar blades are perpendicular planks fastened at the exterimity of the looms"(de Graeve 1981: 39). Dimensions 860cm x 220cm. British Museum, London (BM 124543, Nimrud Gallery No 8b). See also: E.A.W Budge, Ashurnasirpal, p. 15, pl. XXI, 2. 

Figure 3: Relief depicts soldiers that are about to cross the river, one is already swimming while the other is laying on a inflated animal skin - that he holds in his left hand. There are two other men still preparing their skins - one arranges the head of the animal skin and the other is blowing up his skin. There is also a cargo boat which is of long angular shape with upturned ends - it is slightly rounded at the top and is accommodating 2 boatsmen and 2 chariots; the man near the prow stands in the hull and "manioulates an oar with perpendicular plank fastened at its end"; the other stands at the stern while the other is placed in the boat by the man whose feet are on ground level and torso is hidden behind the wheel of the chariot. "The whole activity is attended by the king and his bodyguard." (de Graeve 1981: 40). Dimensions 860cm x 220cm. British Museum, London (BM 124541, Nimrud Gallery 7b.). See also: E.A.W Budge, Asgurnasirpal, p. 15, pl. XXI, 1. 

Figure 4: Relief depicts a naked man crossing the rive by lying on inflated skin; at the centeral part of the relief is a cargo boat transporting a king and 2 attendees as well as his chariot and a horsemen that holds the horses and is swimming behind, and on there are four members of the crew. The vessel is long and of an angular shape with upright ends; the vessels are hauled by 2 naked men by a rope which is attached at the prow and held by the men against the "upper part of their breasts". This boat is being paddled, rowed, and steered, there are 2 men leaning over the gunwale near the prow are paddling, while the one near the stern is rowing with an oar with a perpendicular oar blade. the helmsman "manipulates a long steering oar which has an ellipsoid blade and is attached to a post at the stern". This helmsman is on the centeral platform which the king and attendants stand. (de Graeve 1981: 40). Dimensions 860cm x 220cm. British Museum, London (BM 124545, Nimrud Gallery No 9b). See also: E.A.W Budge, Asgurnasirpal, p. 15, pl. XXI, 1. 

Figure 5:  "The scene may represent a castle or a city according to the double wall and the double gate. A women who stands upon the outer wall is wailing and a naked man is fishing from the river bank. An oar with ellipsoid blade is seen in the water. The boat, to which the oar belonged, is missing. Above, two men carry provisions or tribute, and march in the direction of the castle."(de Graeve 1981: 40-41). See also: BM 124545, Nimrud Gallery No 9b.

Neo Assyrian Period 912 to 612 BCE

Figure 6: Plaque is broken in three registers, the upper register is missing and the second register is partly destroyed; blow depicts a long and straight boat is deecorated prow and stern in the shape of a lion and bull adornment. Between the boat and the demon is a small tree. In the second register the first and last animal headed demon are preserved (de Graeve 1981:59). Dimensions 12.5cm x 9.6cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM55753). See also: M.E.L Mallowan, N&R, 1, p. 118, fig. 60; F.Basmachi, Treasures of the Iraq Museum, p. 404, No. 160

Tiglath-Pileser III Period 8th Century BCE

Figure 7: Preserved fragment shows the upper part os a prow and stern that is decorated with animal heads. The vessel has a mast in the middle of the ship, which is topped with a rectangle and a half circle; "Judging from Layard's drawing (fig. 81) a second boat navigates to the right" (de Graeve 1981: 64). Dimensions: 46cm x 45cm. British Museum, London (BM 102981). See also: R.D. Barnett, M. Falkner, Sculptures, p. 12, pls. LVI-LVII.

item.title: Tell Half Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
First half of the 9th century BCE

Figure 1:  "The flat-bottomed boat has high sides and vertical ends that are flattened at the top. The method of propulsion is unique. The helmsman stands on a kind of platform at the prow and holds an extremely long oat as steering divide. The loom curves over the whole length of the boat and is supported at the stern by a post. In the boat two seated or standing passengers are facing one another. Three great fish swim under the boat." (de Graeve 1981: 62-63). Dimensions: 63cm x 40cm. British Museum (BM 117112). See also: M.Von Oppenheim, TH, p. 149, pl. 29b.

item.title: Umma Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Larsa period.

Vase with four metopes including a boat with upturned and curved ends that carries "three tassled vertical poles" (de Graeve 1981: 25). Larsa period 1999 - 1799 BCE. Height 15cm x Diameter 11cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 4800). See also: E.C.L. during Caspers, The Bahrain Tummuli, in Persica 6 (1972-74), p. 139, pl. XX f.

item.title: Susa Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Larsa Period 2025BCE-1763BCE

Figure 1: Vase decorated with 4 metopes. A boat with an incurving end, is the main feature. It carries 10 standards. "High posts are surmounted by a crescent alternate with the low poles which are surmounted by a full circle" (De Graeve 1981:25). Height 14cm x Diameter 12.2cm. Louvre, Paris (Sb 9312). See also: E.C.L. During Caspers, in Persica 6 (1972-74), pl. XX b.

Figure 2: This vase has white incrustations. It is decorated with a prow or stern of a boat, that has an inward curving top, and boarder at the gunwale. "Three standards and traces of a fourth are preserved" The smaller of the standards are surmounted with a circle, while the others are by a crescent. "At the side of the boat a circle (?) hangs down from the boarder. The other preserved meteope is decorated with a geometric design" (De Graeve 1981:25-26). 9.5cm x 9.5cm. Louvre, Paris (Sb 9326). See also: J. De Morgan in MdP 1 (1900), p. 135, fig. 337; G. Cros, NFT, pl. IV, 3.

7th Century BCE

Figure 3: Rectangular shape with rounded corners. The three fragments almost completely restore the plaque. Lamashtu is engraved standing wearing a short kilt with a belt that retains 2 daggers. The boat has a flat bottom and a small incurving prow and heavy incurving stern. (de Graeve 1981: 69). Dimensions: 18.5cm high x 2.5cm thick. Brussels Museum (0549). See also: J. Nougayrol, Du bon usuage des faux, in Syria 43 (1966), pp. 332-333; Inscription: J. Nougaurol, Du bon usuage des faux, in Syria 42 (1965), pp. 227-234.

item.title: Telloh Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Alternative place name: Girsu

Larsa Period 1999 - 1799 BCE

Figure 1: "Decoration in four metopes: the boat with upturned and incurving end is completely preserved except for one top; the thirteen standard posts in the boat, alternating short and long, are each crowned by a crescent. A walking goose, a stilt standing on a big fish, and a bull are seen in the other meteopes." (de Graeve 1981: 26). Hieght 15cm x Diamtere 13cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 4116). See also: A. Parrot, Telloh, p.292, fig 61 d; G. Cros, NFT, p.244, pl. IV, 2.

Figure 2: "Decoration in four metopes: a small fragment of the hull of a boat, a walking goose, a stilt upon a big fish, and a vertical geometric motifs" (de Graeve 1981: 26). Height 10.cm x Diameter 12cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 4117). See also: G. Cros, NFT, p. 236, pl. IV, 2.

item.title: Tell Asmar Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Larsa Period 1999 - 1799 BCE

"Decoration: part of a boat with high vertical ends in which there are at least three standard posts; horned animal in the second preserved meteope" (de Graeve 1981: 26). 6cm x 6cm. Oriental Institute Museum, Chicago (A 8253). See also: P. Delougaz, Pottery, pp. 119-120, pl. 125, d.

item.title: Kultepe Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Old Assyrian period ca. 2000–1600 BCE

A boat with curving stems and a stern carrying a deity with a horned crown. Four figures approach the deity in robes and the third man wears a tall "headgear". "In the sky a disc in a crescent appears on either side of the deity in the boat and a crescent is seen before three other figures... The representation of a water deity with a flowing vase is a traditional theme of Mesopotamian art. On this Old Assyrian seal impression, however, the vase missing"; Seal impression 17 mm  (de Graeve 1981:31). Dimensions: 47cm x 36cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 1486). See also: L. Delaporte, Louvre II, P. 185, pl. 125, 5 a-b (A 847)

item.title: Acemhoyuk Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Karum Ib period

"An enthroned figure with staff (?) in its right hands faces a servant who holds a jar. Below is a crude rendering of a round bottomed boat, in the sky a disc in a crescent." (de Graeve 1981: 33) Dated 1793–1784 BCE in Manning, Sturt W., Griggs, Carol B., Lorentzen, B., Barjamovic, G., Ramsey, C. B., Kromer, B, Wild, E. M. (2016). "Integrated Tree-Ring-Radiocarbon High-Resolution Timeframe to Resolve Earlier Second Millennium BCE Mesopotamian Chronology". PLOS ONE. 11 (7) See also: N. Özgüç, Acemhöyük Saralarinda bulunmus olan Mühür Baskilari, in Belleten XLI, 162 (1977), p. 373, No 5, pl. XII, 29 Manning, Sturt W.; Griggs, Carol B.; Lorentzen, Brita; Barjamovic, Gojko; Ramsey, Christopher Bronk; Kromer, Bernd; Wild, Eva Maria (2016). "Integrated Tree-Ring-Radiocarbon High-Resolution Timeframe to Resolve Earlier Second Millennium BCE Mesopotamian Chronology". PLOS ONE. 11 (7)

item.title: Alishar Hoyuk Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
18th Century BCE

The flat bottomed boats float on waves. Two bearded heroes end the wave relief. Each hero touches the prow or stern of the boat. "with the other hand each hero touches the hull of the boat. The vessels seems to be punted by two nude bearded heroes with curls identical with those of the personified waters. In the middle a bull-eared god is enthroned, resting his feet on a recumbent human headed bull. The god is flanked by two bull men: the one in front of him carries a sacrificial goat, the one behind him holds a standard" (de Graeve 1981: 33). Dimensions: 1.5cm x 2.8cm. Oriental Institute Museum, Chicago (Field No d-2199). See also: H.H Von Der Osten, The Alishar Hüyük Seasons of 1930-32, Part II (OIP 29), 1937, p. 207, fig 246

item.title: Balawat Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
9th Century BCE

A number of bronze bands which would have been affixed to a giant gate were discovered... in a mound near the village of Tell Balawat (Imgur Enlil), hence the name Balawat Gates (de Graeve 1981:41) 

Figure 1: Band O, Lower register. "Band O depicts the campaign to Chaldea in 851 BC "Four men have left the city and cross the river. Two of them are naked and help themselves forward by moving their leg; they are supported by an inflated skin which they hold with both hands. The two other men paddle a small quffa which has a double bottom line. one of them is still looking towards his city." (de Graeve 1981: 43). Louvre, Paris (AO 22286). See also: M. De Clercq, Catalouge, II, p. 202, pl. XXXII, No 18

Figure 2: Band XI, Upper register. "Band XI illustrates the campaign to South Babylonia in 851 BC" "Two cargo boats with straight upcurved ends and without decoration go to the left. Although heavily loaded, they are ounted by a single person. Arriving at the riverbank, the boat on the left is towed by two men wading in the water" (de Graeve 1981: 43). British Museum, London (BM 124660). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 32, pl. LXIII

Figure 3: Band V, upper register. "Band V illustrates the campaing t to North Syria (858 BC)" "A boat ferries between a walled city and an Assyrian camp. It is a fairly long symmetrical boat with high ends rounded at the tops. At either end a straight sweep with an ellipsoid blade is attached to a bifurcated pole by means of a strap. Two figures seem to be seated amidships. (de Graeve 1981: 44). British Museum, London (BM 124651). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 25, pl XXX.

Figure 4:  Band XI, Upper register. "Band XI illustrates the campaign to South Babylonia in 851 BC" "Three Assyrian march from left to right upon a pontoon-bridge. The bridge is supported by four juxtaposed pontoons and has a double superstructure, the top of which is reinforced by a rope. The whole is fastened on poles at the river banks. Another Assyrian soldier and two horses stand upon the ramps of the bridge." (de Graeve 1981: 44). British Museum, London (BM 124660). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 31-32, pl. LX. 

Figure 5: Band XI, Lower register. "Band XI illustrates the campaign to South Babylonia in 851 BC" "One chariot rides over a pontoon-bridge which is supported by five pontoons. The simple superstructure is reinforced by a rope and is fixed on poles at the riverbank. Two other chariots stand upon the ramps of the bridge." (de Graeve 1981: 44). British Museum, London (BM 124660). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 31-32, pl. LXI - LXII. 

Figure 6:  Band O, Upper register. "Band O depicts the campaign to Chaldea in 851 BC: (p. 42) "On the fragment two pontoons of a bridge are hardly discernible upon the waves of the water. A chariot rides upon the bridge while a second climbs up the ramp. Both head for the city which was seen on the right. The soldiers next to the charioteers have their bow and arrow ready for the attack" (de Graeve 1981: 44). Louvre, Paris (AO 22279). See also: F. Lenormant, in Gazette Archeologique 4 (1878), pp. 119-129, pl. 22-23 top.

Figure 7: Band XI, Lower register. "Band XI illustrates the campaign to South Babylonia in 851 BC" "Three figures stand upon a bridge which is supported by four pontoons and is fixed on poles at the riverbank. The figure on the right seems to be supervisor; the others are servants. To the left four more servants march toward the bridge. The objects the servants carry can be interpreted as lumps of earth and branches brought for the construction of the upper level of the bridge. Behind the servants, a high offical is seated on a throne." (de Graeve 1981: 44-45). British Museum, London (BM 124660). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 32, pl. LXIV

Shalmaneser III Period 9th Century BCE

Figure 8: Band III, upper register. "Two cargo boats are decorated with an animal headed prow and stern and are propelled by curved oars at either end, used for rowing and steering. The men manipulating the oars look to the shore which is seen on the right. The boat which is about to arrive is towed by two men, wadding into the sea. Each of them tow the boat by means of a rope which is attached to the prow". Band III, upper register. (de Graeve 1981: 63). British Museum, London (BM 124661). See also: L.W. King, Gates, p. 23, pl. XIII.

Figure 9:  "Two cargo boats cross the water. Each of them has an animal-headed prow and stern and are rowed by one man who holds a sweep with ellipsoid blade and looks backwards. The boat to the right is being loaded and is about to start. The boat to the left, similarly loaded, arrives at the other bank. In addition the latter is towed by four men, walking two by two with a rope on their shoulders." (de Graeve 1981: 63-64). Dimensions: 8.5cm x 36.5cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 14038). Formerly Schlumberger Collection. See also: F. Lenormant, in Gazette Archeologique 4, (1878), pp. 119-129, pl. 22-23.

item.title: Khorsabad Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
8th Century BCE

Figure 1: "The fragment shows the forepart of a heavily loaded boat towed by four men who hold a rope upon their shoulders. The boat is of a large cargo boat type with high upturned, abruptly ending prow. Into the gunwale a stick seems to be set on which the towing rope is fastened. Above the scene the cuneiform text mentions a campaign against the Chaldean king, Merodach-baladan, after which this tribute was evivdently transported." (de Graeve 1981: 46). Dimensions: 45cm x 121cm. Oriental Institure Museum, Chicago (A 11258). See also: H. Frankfort, OIC 16, p. 92, fig. 58; G. Loud, Khorsabad I, p. 58, fig. 72

Figure 2:  "Two boats are shown in the water near a kind of pavillion, traditionally called the "Ionic temple". The vessels have rounded edges, prows in the shape of horse's heads and sterns with widening tops, which makes it clear that the boats are facing in opposite directions. The scene is part of the lower register of a large relief depicting a banqueting scene in the upper register and a royal hunt in the lower one with an inscription between the registers." (de Graeve 1981: 46). Field Museum, Chicago (A 11255-11256) See also: P.E. Botta, Monuments, II, pl. 114; G. Loud, Khorsabad I, p. 72, figs. 83, 89

Sargon II Period 8th Century BCE

Figure 3: The relief is depicted on five slabs (two shown here) that show the stages of "bringing logs into a city." The towed logs are attached to the stern of twelve boats which take them to their destination, the boats pass cities and arrive at a hill where a another city is built on. The vessels are described as having a bilge rounded at both ends, a prow at the shape of a horses head and a stern like a fish tail. The crew of these vessels usually consist of 4 men although the number is adjusted with more space means more men. they stand upright and manipulate the oar, which is slightly curved at the end. (de Graeve 1981: 66). Dimensions: AO 19989: 293cm x 408cm; AO 19890: 283 cm x 230cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 19889; AO 19890). See also: P.E Botta, Monuments, pls. 31-35; W.S Smith, Interconnections, pp. 121-122, fig. 156.

item.title: Kuyunjik Archaeological Site - Nineveh
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
8th Century BCE Reliefs

Figure 1: Depiction of a raft in elevation which is supported by seven inflated animal skins and fastened to the platform by ropes; on the raft there are 4 people: an oarsmen seated holding a long oar, two passengers seated facing each other, and a kneeling figure. The other vessel in the relief is an elongated boat with upturned ends. Carrying seven people: two oarsmen, four passengers, and a helmsman standing on a platform holding a ling paddle with ellipsoid blade." (de Graeve 1981:47-48). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 8, pl. 49

Figure 2: Fragment has 3 registers: rives with reed beds, a row of conifers and reed beds in the second register, and four rows of boat towers in the third register. At the first register, a raft and a quffa are depicted. (de Graeve 1981:48). British Museum, London (BM 124822, Nineveh Gallery 54). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 6, pl. 24

Figure 3: Boat rafts are navigating to the left carrying Assyrian soldiers who are active in battle. All vessels have a upturned prow and are made of reeds tied together with three single bands. To the right an Assyrian solider is depicted leading a row of prisoners through the palm grove. (de Graeve 1981:48-49). O.D IV, 42: drawing of fragment. See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 13, pl. 93

Figure 4:  "Six boat-rafts are depicted, they form two groups: the three on the raftt are manned by Assyrians , the three on the left by natives of the marshes (soldiers and women). All the boats, which are nearly flat, are made of reed bundles tied together with several bands. The boat of the Assyrians are clearly longer and are punted at the stern. Both groups are fighting, while the top of the fragment of natives are deported by the Assyrian soldiers. The battle scene is bordered by reed beds which are traversed by small channels. The reed beds to the left lie horizontally because of the lack of perspective. To the right Assyrian horsemen hide in the reed beds.' (de Graeve 1981:49). O.D IV, 33: Drawing of two fragments. See also: O.D IV, 33: Drawing of two fragments

Figure 5: The slabs show three riverboats and six men supported by animal skins. The boats ate elongated with upturned ends, "two of them have a double bottom line" Only one boat is seen in its entirety, two men stand on either end of the vessel. Two other vessels that are transporting hores are fragmented. "five naken soldier swim while they lie astride on large animal skins. (de Graeve 1981:49). O.D IV, 77: Drawing of three fragments with traces of sculpture, two of which are discussed here. See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 8, pl. 49 

Figure 6: Vessel is a kind of barge which is characterized by a higher prow "somewhat pointed at the top" and the double line and the circular knobs on both sides at the front and rear which the ropes are tuned. The barge is towed In front by four rows of boat-haulers. A third group of workmen bring other materials like long beams and ropes. The upper register depicts a river on which float a buoyed raft with a second platform that is supported by inflated animal skins. This transport is surveyed by a man who stands in a boat which is partially preserved with one oar he may be in a barge or a quffa. (de Graeve 1981:50). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 6, pls. 27-28.

Figure 7: Barge carries the "bull-colossus lying on its side" that has a upturned prow and rounded top. The relief is slightly damaged at the bottom of the barge. Th barge is raised by a lever and is towed at the front by four ropes. The three men on top of this colossus coordinate the activities of hauling, putting bars, and bringing necessary material. A river is depicted which has three quffas; seem to be made of rectangular pieces of skin which is attached to the gunwale by cords forming a cross-shape design. Two quffas on the left show a rope motif on the gunwale. the boats are all propelled by four curved oars. Between two pairs of oarsmen building material is piled up. "At either side of the first boat a man sitting on an inflated animal skin holds a fishing line with both hands and carries a basket which is fixed by a rope around his neck." (de Graeve 1981:50).British Museum, London (BM 124823, Nineveh Gallery 55). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 6, pls. 25 (complete slab), 26 (the Quffa on the right).

Figure 8: The vessel carries a statue - the barge moves on the bars and us towed in the front by ropes turned around circular nobs and is lifted by a lever in the rear. "The horned bull colossus is maintained in a fixed position between four upright poles." two of the horizontal poles are the protective frame work at either side and the vertical poles pass through the planks laid upon the gunwale of the barge and the ends are at the outer side of the vessel. forks are ropes are fastened which are held by 2 men and the other workmen put bars in front of the barge or transport bars and ropes - these activities are monitored and directed by a man that stands in front of the statue (de Graeve 1981:51). Vatican Museum (no. 2). O.D II, 65 and O.D IV, 48 . See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 6, pl. 23.

Figure 9: "The barge which is still in the water carries a huge load, probably a stele or a wrought stone laid sideways. It seems to be towed by means of three ropes, one which is fastened at the barge; the two others pass through holes in the stone block. The load is maintained in a fixed position by means of vertical bars. On top of the load a man is seated, probably to direct the activities of dragging. Three rows of men haul the vessel in the presence of supervisors. A large number is still wading in the water while the others are already on the riverbank. The ropes they hold around their shoulders and heads are depicted in different ways." (de Graeve 1981:51). Asariatika, Müzeleri, Istanbul (no. 25). O.D IV, 62-63. See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 11, pl. 87.

Figure 10:  The barge is raised to the river bank; "a primitive sluice made of a kind of dam and three dalias", built to form a dock and facilitated work. At the rear lever there is a cut off corner of the barge to lift it up; in the front four rows of men tow the load. Only one double rope at the rear is visible; at the top there are four men which are coordinate the work, the second of the men blows a blazon. at the front of each row and next to the rows are supervisors that direct the work. To the right of the slab, there is another group of men working the activity is under the supervision of the king. The upper register depicts a landscape overgrown with conifers, grape-trees, pomegranate trees and fig trees. "This is the only slab which represents rows of boat-haulers dressed in Assyrian fashion." de Graeve 1981:51-52). British Museum, London (BM 124820, Nineveh Gallery 51-52). O.D I, 57. See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 7, pl. 32-33.

7th Century BCE Reliefs

Figure 11:  "The upper part of the relief, which is badly damaged, shows four soldiers who lie astride fairly large skins which they hold between their legs and grasp with the left hand. They are armed with helmet, shield, quiver, and spear. In the upper left hand corner, a fragment has preserved the figure of a soldier on an inflated skin who accompanies the horses crossing the stream. Below, on the river bank, two horses and the royal chariot precede a group of soldiers who prepare skins upon which they will cross the river." (de Graeve 1981:51-52). O.D IV, 74; Drawing of a fragment. See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 8, pl. 46-47.

Figure 12: Relief depicts a fight between the Assyrians and the Marsh Arabs hiding in the reed beds. The Assyrians dominate most of the relief - being large number in boats which are made of reed bundles tied together in several bands. The ends of the boats are upturned and are of a light structure. The vessels of the opposition are in various shapes and smaller in size. "The vessels below is nearly cigar-shaped, narrowing at one end." other vessels are boat-rafts or flat-rafts with lightly upturned ends. Only one boat shows an Assyrian rowing prisoners, by means of an oar or a blade that widens out.British Museum, London (BM 124774, Nineveh Gallery, 4-8). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 8, pl. 50.

Figure 13: "Marsh Arabs embark under the supervision of Assyrian soldiers, while the fortress is conquered. Part of three boat-rafts remain. They are made of reeds tied together with several lashings. In the boat at the top, an Assyrian soldier hits a captive who looks behind. The second boat is being pulled ashore by means of two ropes held by two soldiers who stay on the riverbank near the city. Another soldier pushes 2 captives into the boat while 2 carries an Assyrian soldier and four seated natives with their hands tied behind their backs. The city has a double wall upon which the natives stand with raised arms to ask for mercy. An inscription upon the city wall mentions the name of the city: alqi..." (de Graeve 1981:54). Baghdad Museum, Iraq (IM 26230). See also: M. Falkner, Die Reliefs der assyrischen Könige, No. 4: Zwei assyrische Reliefs in Durham, AFO 16 (1952-53), p. 250, fig. 40.; F. Basmachi, Treasures of the Iraqi Museum, p. 40, No. 154.

Figure 14: Divided into four registers. The complete register set depicts a river with five boat-rafts made of reeds with upturned prows and sterns with several lashings. Three of the registers depict people marching carrying bags on their shoulders while towing a raft of boats. From left to right: Only a drawing on the first register remains. The second slab register depicts a scene in which the Assyrians besiege a city. Five boats carrying men, women and children are depicted on registers 2 to 4. (de Graeve 1981:54-55). The fourth panel is in the Loouvre, Paris (AO 22202). The fifth panel was in Istanbul but, according to Jeremias, A. (1929). Handbuch der altorientalischen Geisteskultur, Berlin-Leipzig. p.486, it can no longer be found there. See also: J.E Reade, in Iraq 26 (1964), p.4, pl. Ib; R.D Barnett, Ashurbanipal, p. 41, pl. XXII. J.E Reade, in Iraq 26 (1964), p.4, pl. Ib; R.D Barnett, Ashurbanipal, p. 41, pl. XXII.

Figure 15: "Captives are being transported across the water in a boat-raft. The vessel is made of bundles of reed tied together and is propelled by a captive by means of a long punting pole. Two women, sitting on bundles which may represent their luggage, face each other and appear to complain. At the stern an Assyrian solder holds a long spear and gives directions. In the water lies the body of a slain captive." (de Graeve 1981:55). Dimensions: 51.4cm x 45.7cm. MOMA (32.143.5).

Figure 16:  Slab with four registers (top to bottom). In the two top registers marsh dwellers are carrying goods are deported by Assyrians. The third register depicts a building along the water and reeds where three people are hiding. Six reed boat-rafts having several lashings and slightly upturned ends are shown in the scene on the fourth register. The boat at the bottom of the panel is towed from the riverbank by two men each holding a rope.  In the top left of the fourth register, a vessel in which three figures are kneeling can be seen. The first holds a bow, the second looks behind and has arms are bound behind his back, the third man is partially preserved. The boats boats depicted here each carry seated individuals amidships and in the bow with two standing individuals in the stern - an Assyrian soldier and a man punting (de Graeve 1981:56). Fragments of the panel are dispersed amongst Leningrad Museum (7389), Louvre, Paris (AO 19923) and the Vatican (acquired for Pope Pius IX, by G. Bennhi, in 1855). See also: R.D Barnett, Ashurbanipal, p. 40, pi. XX, a, b and c. E. Weidner, in AFO Beiheft 4 (1939), p. 20, fig 18. 

Figure 17: "The small fragment shows only the upper edge of the raft. The vessel is manned by three natives and an Assyrian. The first native is kneeling, the second is punting and the third - may be a women - is seated on a blade of goods (?). The Assyrians, holding a spear and a stick, gives directions." (de Graeve 1981:56). Dimensions: 31cm x 37cm. British Museum (BM 131122, Nineveh Gallery, East wall).

Figure 18:  The panel shows four reed boats between the island and the riverbank. The vessels are long and have a pronounced upturned prow and stern, as well as several lashings at least five for 2 boats. The vessel on the left is punted, in the three other vessels natives are deported, and the vessel at the top is rowed by an oarsman that is seated in the prow. (de Graeve 1981:56-57). Dimentions: 22cm x 38.4cm. See also: R.D Barnett, Ashurbanipal, p. 44, pl. XXVIII.

Figure 19:  A hunting scene is depicted in two slabs that stand at a right angle. The largest slab depicts a royal ship of the hippos type. The prow is in the shape of a horse's head and the stern of a goose's head. The vessel is propelled by 15 oars on each side divided into 2 rows. "The oars of the upper row are propelled from over the gunwale by oarsmen whose heads are visible. The oars of the lower row pass through oar ports." The two helmsmen stand upright at the stern steer the vessel by means of two long steering pars at the quarters. In the other slab a river boat "conveying two saddled horses follows the royal ship." vessel has straight upturned ends widening at the top, it is propelled by four oarsmen of which two are seen above the gunwale. Four ellipsoid blades are depicted under the hull. Original slabs were probably about 170cm high. (de Graeve 1981:57). See also: R.D Barnett, Ashurbanipal, p. 52, pl. LIV; V. Place, Ninove et l' Assyrie, pl. 50 bis. 3. 

Neo Assyrian Period 912 to 612 BCE.

Figure 20:  "The most important object of the mould is a rectangular amulet. It represents a boat with upturned and incurving ends and nine lashings. In the boat stands Lamashtu, who holds two objects one a string which have been identified as a comb and a spool. Two animals standing in the boat place their forelegs on her body. In the field are the moon crescent, the winged disc and the seven dots (= Sibitti). Besides the plaque the mould contains those of a human figure, two animals and four symbols which would have served as earrings and pendants." (de Graeve 1981:60-61). Dimensions: Mould - 8.6cm x 7.8cm. Plaque -0 3cm x 2.2cm. British Museum, London (BM 91904). See also: A.H Layard, N&B, p. 597; D.Opitz, Altorientalische Gussformen, in AfO Beiheft 1(1933), p. 212, pl. X, fig. 26.; H. Klengel, in MIO 6, 2 (1958), p. 336, No. 10.

Period 705 to 681 BCE

Figure 21: "The forepart of the ship is preserved. The prow, as far as distinguishable, is upturved and slightly incurving. Therefore the ship is obviously not a war galley, but a symmetrical merchant galley. It is a bireme propelled by 8 (2 x 4) oars on each side. The lower row goes through rectangular oar ports, while the upper row is worked over the gunwale by oarsmen whose heads and shoulders are visible. The vessel has a superstructure composed of a row of squares alternating plain and cross-hatched, and another part being the pavesade of the upper deck provided with shields. The upper deck is manned by soldiers with spears and by a women (?). A crab and fish are in the water." (de Graeve 1981: 67).

Figure 22 (and 22a - original): The relief shows five seagoing ships - one war galley and four merchant galleys "of a symmetrical type are recognizable." To the right, part of a gate remains where a man hands a child over to a women in the boat.The drawing (fig. 87) shows 12 Phoenician ships of 2 types; six ships have a rounded bilge and a symmetrical prow and stern highly upturned with widening top, which is propelled by 8-9 rowers. 4 to 5 of these rowers are visible above the gunwale. the oars have long looms and blades which widen out. The second category is distinguished by a curved stern high raising above the superstructure and a ram at the prow. (distinguishing them as war galleys); vessels have a mast with sail yard which hands a furled sail. they are fully equipped with forestays, brails and branxes. The oarsmen on these boat are 8 to 11. Women and warriors are on the upper deck, where a row of shields are hung. (de Graeve 1981: 67-68). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 4, pl. 10; R.D Barnett, in Antiquity 32 (1958), pp. 226-7, pl. 22b; R.D. Barnett, Ezekiel and Tyre, in Eretz-Israel 9 (1969), p. 6, pl. I, 1-2; I, 2 is the only reproduction of the old photograph.

Figure 23 (and 23a - original): Part of the fragment is preserved (the left side specifically - Figure 23a). It Depicts a war galley going to the right, characterized by 2 decks and the presence of a ram. The oars are 17 in number and have blades which widen out. 2 first oars start from the lower level. eight of the oarsmen are seen above the gunwale. The drawing of the complete fragment (Figure 23) show the central part which has a second ship. "It is a bireme of which thirteen oars and two steering oars are visible" with a superstructure as the first ship." (de Graeve 1981: 68). See also: A. Paterson, Sennacherib, p. 4, pl. 11 (= BM 124772); C.J. Gadd, Stones, p.63 (slab is mentioned); O.D, unpublished.

Figure 24:  "The forepart of a war gallery is preserved showing the ram, five oars in two levels and three oarsmen. Of the superstructure the stanchions and the row of squares are missing. The upper deck is manned by three figures, probably two soldiers and a women. On the shore are an orchard and soldiers in battle" (de Graeve 1981: 68).

Figure 25: War galley characterized by a ram and a superstructure that goes to the right. Six oars are shown in an unusual way, "one oar of the lower level alternated with two of the upper level and the steering oars start from the top of the superstructure." The ship has a classical superstructure with a row of squares and a row of shields which is manned by three soldiers and one women on the upper deck and by four oarsmen at the gunwale level. (de Graeve 1981: 69).

item.title: Lagash Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Neo-Assyrian Period 912 and 612 BCE

Figure 1: Divided into four registers. In the middle of the lowest shows a depiction of an elegantly curved boat with animal headed prow and stern, in the shape of a lion and bulls head; the rest of the registers depict the same as the other plaques about Lamashtu and the sick man on the bed...etc. (de Graeve 1981: 58). Dimensions: Height (with head) 13.5cm (without head) 11.5cm x 8.5cm. Louvre, Paris (AO 22205) Formerly Collection de Clercq. See also: M. De Clercq, Catalouge, II, pp. 213-16, pl. XXXIV, top; H.Klengel, in MIO 6,2 (1958), pp. 334, No. 1.

Figure 2: Surmounted by a Pazuzu head and by two other demon heads at the corners, one is missing; the plaque is divided into four registers; Lamshtu can be found kneeling in the curved boat which is decorated with animal protomes. The relief is poorly preserved and of the three holes of suspension at the bottom only one remains. (de Graeve 1981: 58-59). Dimensions: 15cm x 8.5cm. Possibly from Istanbul Museum. See also: M. De Clercq, Catalouge, II, pp. 216-221,, pl. XXXIV, bottom; H.Klengel, in MIO 6,2 (1958), pp. 335, No. 2.

item.title: Assur Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Neo-Assyrian Period 912 to 612 BCE 

Figure 1: "A flat elongated boat with five paired lines (lashings), and animal headed ends of a lion and a bull carries a beautiful horse. Upon the horse remains the knees of a figure, which has a long rope around the leg. Fish are in the water, a rhomb, a comb, and a crab are in the field" (de Graeve 1981:60). "The plaque was placed as a gift in a tub shaped sarcophagus in tomb 864 under the floor of a Neo-Assyrian house; Field No Ass. 8592" (de Graeve 1981:60). Dimensions 5.3cm x 6cm. See also: A.V. Haller, Die Gräber und Grüfte von Assur (WVDOG 65), p. 77, pl. 17, 1

item.title: Karatepe Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tiglath-Pileser III Period 8th Century.

Figure 1: The relief depicts a galley characterized by a prow with a ram that ends abruptly and a high upturned stern in the shape of an animal's head looking towards the prow. Ship has a second deck supported by stanchions, and a platform at prow and stern equally supported by stanchions. "They are reinforced by strengthening members, two at the prow and stern."; there are 5 oars which are short and have oar blades made in 2 parts that form 2 angles. The steering oar is exaggerated in size. (de Graeve 1981:64-65). Dimensions: 130cm x 60 - 100cm. See also: E. Weidner, Ausgrabungen in Karatepe, in AFO 15 (1945-51), p. 158, fig. 19; H. Cambel, Karatepe, An Archeological Introduction to a recently discovered Hittite Site in Southern Anatolia, in Oriens 1 (1948), pp. 155-156, pl. IV, b.

Sargon II Period Late 8th Century BCE

Figure 2: "Two figures have taken place in a rounded canoe-like boat. The one at the prow seems to be a man handling a net; the one at the stern may be a women. Two oblique lines along the side of the boat are vaguely discernible, but they are too indistinct to identify them as the contour of the loom of a paddle. Under the boat a fish symbolizes the river. Without transition a hunting scene appears underneath. A man holds a spear horizontally, the tip of which is missing for lack of space. In his left hand he seems to hold a bird. Below, a larger animal symbolizes the hunt." (de Graeve 1981:65). Dimensions: 125cm x 50cm. See also: H. Bossert, Karatepe (Ancient Oriental Civilizations , 3), Istanbul 1947, pl.XXV, 124-125; XXVII, 133; XXIX, 214; H. Bossert, in Orientalia NS 17 (1948), pl. XXXI, fig. 3.

item.title: Selling memories next to Hotel "O Escondidinho"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Walking outside the Hotel "O Escondinho", located on a small square, one could oftentimes find Henrique Ali selling all sorts of African-made objects, mostly made of different types of wood. This friendly young salesman strategy is to choose a place where visitors on the Island of Mozambique often pass by. The daily goal is to sell souvenirs to tourists. Born and raised on the Island (Ilha), his organized stands sell bracelets, key chains, masks, pens, necklaces, statues and the list goes on.

Henrique Ali

Salesman, 24 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Henrique Ali: It’s a nice place. Tourists, when they come, they stay very relaxed. It’s a place with no fights, very relaxed environment.

Do you know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The WHS classification…?
H. A.: No. I know the Island is World Heritage.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
H. A.: The buildings have changed and so as the lives of the people with the culture.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? The WHS classification helped boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
H. A.:Tourist don’t come that often. It works in waves. Their either come a lot or do not come at all.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
H.A.: To Vasco da Gama [the statue].

What do you consider to be your heritage?
H.A.: For me, heritage is the monuments where’s Vasco da Gama, the fortress, the museum, and also Luís de Camões. Monuments mostly.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as a historical place?
H.A.: Yes, they do.  

Did you visited any museum? If so, what is your opinion about them?
H.A.: I think they are nice, the things that are there.

What do you think about the fortress? (São Sebastião Fortress)
H.A.: I think they should leave the things they have found there in their original place, instead of taking them some other place.

item.title: The Fishermen Beach
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
The main mosque rised amonsgst the ground level houses that surrond it, painted in green and white. Behind it, a busy beach begins appearing. The cobble street gets replaced by sand, and every step takes us to a a progressively crowded coast. The golden sand grains now share their space with pieces and patches that instinctively lead us to one main activity - fishing. Guiding us is Cassimo Abdurremane, the President of the Fishermen's Association, at the time.

This is Fishermen Beach (Praia dos Pescadores in Portuguese), at the southwestern end of the Island. As the name indicates, it is where all the fishermen meet and set out for another day of fishing. It is where they build and repair boats, and dhows, take care of the nets, and all the in-between logistics needed to get fish to their families and to sell at the local market. We meet Nuro Ambassie, leading us to understand futher down the location.

Nuro Ambassie

Fisherman and President of the Community Council of the Fishermen, 64 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What is your role in the association?
Nuro Ambassie: My activity is to work for the community, explain how to work, how to fish, how to fix some things…

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
N. A.: This is a historical place where I can live. I feel like at home.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
N. A.: Yes. There are more houses, the houses are rehabilitated, and we receive more people from far way countries like you. You came all away from Portugal to tell stories abroad about what you saw here. To show what is like here.

Did you visit any museum of the Island?
N. A.: No, only outside. What I would see inside the museum it wouldn’t have any interest for me. I don’t need to go inside. I see how it looks from the outside.

What do you consider to be your own personal heritage?
N. A.: I would like to see a lot of sponsors to the fishing activity. I’m in fishing.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
N. A.: I like to tell that the Island is from all of us.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island?
N. A.: I like it a lot. A lot. I would like to go abroad and catch some fish, and that people would come fishing with us.

[smartslider3 slider="25"]

Cassimo Abdurremane display us the resourcefulness that the chronic lack of materials on the Island leads to. Flip flop soles are reutilized as fishnet floaters. Lone patches don't last long on this beach. Everything is useful to repair equipment. We strike conversation with another fisherman, and Cassimo translates the conversation from Macua, the local dialect, to Portuguese.

Amisse Ali

Fisherman, 46 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

About his occupation.
Amisse Ali translated by Cassimo Abdurremane: He works in the sea fishing, fishing fish through manual labour. They make manual fencing and dive to catch fish. They do not work with a scuba tank. They do everything manually, daily. There are days that they go fishing and there is no good return. They then bring the fish to the market. They sell it in boxes and calculate it, there is no scale. Fish is worth about 4 meticais [local currency]. The price varies. There is no scale. There are days that is worth more and there are days that is worth less.

Interviewer: Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
A. A.: Life is getting worse. In other countries fishing is not like here. We are suffering from the lack of means to fish and this is the main activity of the Island. That's why I think life is getting worse.

What is improving on the Island of Mozambique?
A. A.: I’m liking these changes, it’s improving [the buildings and roads].

Did you visited any museum? If so, what is your opinion about them?
A. A.: Never went.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
A. A.: There is no material. You have nowhere to buy. The island of Mozambique suffers from many storms and the result is that it destroys everything and then the boss has no way to rehabilitate the materials, the boats. The fishing life is difficult. It is a problem there are no materials. There is no wood, no nails, no nets. We suffer greatly from the lack of material.

Not far from here, we see a man caulking the a boat's hull and he kindly stops his activity to get to know us. Once again, some interactions from this interview were translated from Macua with the assistance of Cassimo.

Assane Amisse

Boat Caulker, 63 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

About his profession.
Assane Amisse translated by Cassimo Abdurremane: Since his childhood he learned how to build boats.

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
A. A.: The Island for me means employment. I don’t feel the well-being on the Island because of the lack of jobs. I can be 3-4 months without mend anything. If this goes on like this in 4-6 years I will be without a home.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
A. A.: I don’t feel anything different. It’s static. My problem is that I have nothing to do. Fish dies. There is nothing.

What is improving on the Island of Mozambique?
A. A.: The Island remains the same.

Did you visit any museum of the Island of Mozambique?
A. A.: I only pass by them. Everybody just passes them. See them through the outside. What am I going to do there?

What do you consider to be your own personal heritage?
A. A.: My heritage is this. What I am doing right now [caulking the boat].

Mostly man are on this beach. Working, preparing launch, arriving or leaving on the dhows, even carrying by hand some of the chickens that sometimes approach us. External sponsors ocasionally support the fishermen with new vessels and fishing materials. However, the increased intensity of the already frequent ciclones that fustigate the Island destroy everything it finds on the beach.

item.title: Old UaQ 2 (Early 17th to early 19th century)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This settlement is named as Old UaQ 2 as it is thought to be the place where Old UaQ 1 people moved to. According to the finds, this second settlement had its most flourishing period from the early 17th to early 19th century. The occupation can be dated by the presence of blue-and-white porcelains exported from China during the late Ming and early Xing (Ching) dynasties, including possibly Kraak Ware and Batavian Ware. This settlement was probably established around the time Julfar declined, as part of a decentralization of the early modern pearling industry. The oyster shell middens next to this settlement are much larger than those of the first. This was either due to the erosion of the oyster middens in the first settlement as these are older in age, or the pearl industry gained a lot of momentum in the second settlement around 18th century. This pearling boom was fundamentally important to the emergence of the Emirates.

This second town was destroyed on 18th January 1820 by a naval squadron despatched to the Arabian Gulf by the British East India Company to deal with the issue of piracy. A rare coin of Shaikh Sultan b. Saqr al-Qasimi, the powerful ruler of Ras Al Khaimah, has been discovered on the site. He signed the General Maritime Treaty of 1820 that brought hostilities to a close and laid the foundation for the modern United Arab Emirates.

The ruins of the second town were described by a British naval survey in 1822, which noted that it had been abandoned in favor of the present site of Umm Al Qaiwain town, situated on the mainland immediately opposite Siniya Island (https://wam.ae/en/details/1395303022785).

item.title: Is this a village? Contemporary with the Christian Monastery?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The recent (2023) archaeological excavations revealed that towards the south of where the church complex situated, there are dense buildings which might be indicating a settlement. The buildings of that are contains relatively intensive domestic activities such as "tandurs", storage pots, ashy layers etc. This is the reason for now the team mentions about this sector as "village".

At this sector, the archaeologists was found an unexpectedly large multi roomed (11 separated spaces?) building. What all these finds mean needs more field work and study on the finds.

item.title: Unexpected Usage of Sultanahmet Historical Structures
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Kaan Koç: Now the old stories, are interesting. In the past, of course, nobody had refrigerators, but we had them because we were a wealthy family. Frigidaire etc., we had a refrigerator even in 1940, but my eldest aunt told us about the situation even before these years, she would have been -more than- 100 years old if she was alive now. She was born in 1910 or 12, my father’s eldest sister.

At that time, over there, just opposite this house it was private property, a large high-walled mansion with orchards. The existence of the “Basilica Cistern” was unknown until this place was nationalized, to build the City Hall. But that didn’t happen, World War 2nd broke out. It's 1938-40's the Basilica Cistern appeared. The door number of this building is 6, but number 2 and number 4 were demolished already, (because they demolished and excavated some buildings at the beginning of that expropriation project), but ours were left intact, when the war begins, the funding for the project was stopped. Anyway, houses did not have refrigerators. The ground floors were always used as a ‘sofa’ (means in Turkish shared room/living room), and everyone has their well.  Where does the well go? To the Basilica Cistern! The inside of the Basilica Cistern, of course, is cool, everyone uses  “file”s (means a bag made of string net-had a common usage in the past before plastic bags) or baskets, to swing down watermelons, grapes, meat, everything was underground hanging. They pulled the food up in this well when needed, then swung it down again.

Anyway, my late grandfather used to tell us, there was a man called Mehmet Agha, who was the keeper of this mansion because the walls were already demolished in my time, there was a flimsy fence, and we would be able to see inside through the cracks. Now -imagine- everyone was hanging the nets down, Mehmet Agha knew every house, of course. Among the supplies, there was also Raki (a traditional anisette spirit), so he was helping himself when he goes down in the cistern, such as a glass of Rakı from someone’s bottle, a few grapes from another’s basket, a peach from the other ones’ bag. In sum, Mehmet Agha makes a living from there. Therefore, to wash the stone floors and house cleaning, all are taken from below and drawn from the Basilica Cistern.

Nurcan Yalman: So is the water level that high?

Kaan Koç: It was full of water, maybe three meters high, still, the water level sometimes gets even higher in winter. So it was used as a cistern in the past. I don't know how many meters high but the height of the cistern is about 12-13 meters I think. And it was where the water was taken from. Everyone was getting water to wash their flowers although there is not a proper garden here, and to wash clothes, and floors.

Nurcan Yalman: Maybe even today the water level rises up but maybe they are pumping it out.

Kaan Koç: This was one of the rare houses with coal gas and electricity. Here we had electricity and coal gas, it was a huge luxury at that time, so in the 30s having, gas, electricity, and water, was a huge luxury, but I guess there used to be water tanks. My father used to say, on Sundays,  the water was boiled in big cauldrons, the water is heated downstairs and all the kids in the house were washed.

Having bath was a big problem even in my childhood. You could only take a bath twice a week, Wednesday, Sunday, remember how many days a week?

Nurcan Yalman: Yes I do remember as well, there used to be wood stoves to get hot water.

Kaan Koç: Yes there used to be wood stoves but even before that there were not those stoves but copper cauldrons. Eh, think about it there are grandparents, parents, kids, and crowded (extended) families, you should wait until it’s your turn. On top of these, there are dishes, and clothes to be washed, so, not an easy life. But all the houses have the same conditions. Of course, I haven’t experienced these but my grandpa and my dad told me about that.  When my father’s mother died, he said that they washed her body downstairs, my father lost his mother very early, but he remembers, he was about 6 years old at that time.

It is very interesting when there is no heating, houses are heated by brazier (mangal). There was a funny saying about that; they used to say "eight feet for one brazier". Imagine! There is a brazier, and everyone in the house placed their feet on it. Because of that, all the carpets had burnt spots, because the sparks from the brazier were scattered all over the place. If you manage to find such an old house, you will see that all the carpets are burned, we also had the carpets in my grandfather's house.

.

item.title: Crafting a Turtle-made bracelet
item.dc:creator: Salama
item.content:encoded:
A concentrated Zé Luís caught my attention. A repetitive scrapping with determination and diving the piece on the water, intrigued me tremendously. What was he crafting? As I approched him, Zé, which is short for José, soon told me about all of his talents.

José (Zé) Luís

Craftsman, 43 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What are you doing right now? [Displaying on the photo above]
Zé Luís: Now, I’m doing a turtle bracelet. Besides turtles, I also craft on ivory, pau-preto (Blackwood)… I work with a lot of materials.

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Z. L.: It is a historical Island. A place of history.

But for you, personally.
Z. L.: Well, if I think about my handicraft job…Some days there are meetings amongst craftsmen. They never invite me! And I don’t know why. They know me, even in the House of Culture, they know that I’m almost one of the first artists in this Island. The first artists. But they don’t recognize me. I’m a sculptor, a turner, a carpenter. You are seeing it right? I’m all this things they call art. I just don’t paint. But in sculpture I do everything. For example, with wood I can do jewellery, bracelets. If you want to see my art I can show you.

You know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The WHS classification…?
Z. L.: No, I don’t.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time? Especially after 1991?
Z. L.: No. The Island haven’t changed at all. Everything is still the same. Just some buildings are different now. In that aspect, it has changed a bit, yes.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as an historical place?
Z. L.: That I don’t know. Some people do, some people don’t.

What do you consider to be your own personal heritage?
Z. L.: A part of the Island that I can say, that it is continuing there for another while, it is the fortress. It is from a craftsman. In those times, the arts almost started in the Island of Mozambique. So I think is best for the Island to continuing to have craftsmen.

Is there any story or anything else you would like to share?
Z. L.: No.

Did you visit any museums of the Island? If so, what is your opinion about them?
Z. L.: Yes, I did. It tells a good history. Some things are not represented there because some people took things from there. I think it has a good representation of our history.

item.title: Pudding Shop Lifestyle of Hippies
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
NAMIK BEY: It is all about the Hippies. They would camp here, stay in the cars, and  sleep in the park with those sleeping bags. This place was a bakery shop back then. Our first place was a patisseriee. When it was a patisserie, we were serving only breakfast.  The people were in the need of meals though.  There wasn’t any place around for that. After 70’s we transformed the bakery shop into a restaurant. They needed the restaurant here and have anywhere to go. 

They would come and go as if this was their home. Our family profession was a patisserie so we used to offer Turkish Delight to everyone, for free. They don’t have customs like that, Europians don’t have…That’s why they liked it here. They felt this place as their home.

For instance, two friends from England were traveling. One of them stayed in Greece and the other one came here. They said “let’s meet here”. There was a communication board here. They would write on it “at this time, we will meet at Pudding Shop. All would come and check the bord. Just like this, it was a meeting place.

SİNAN: Both a place for meeting and communication…

NAMIK BEY: They played guitar, everyone had fun. They’d read books . It was good, all of them were educated and cultured. However the community here, felt uncomfortable when the tourists came. they couldn't adapt and live in harmony. Many locals left the area and settled to other places.

SİNAN: Locals moved out…

NAMIK BEY: Back then this place was a big good neighborhood area. When the hippies came, people felt uncomfortable. They couldn’t accept the situation at first. Now it is different (than a neighborhood).

item.title: The Journey of the Stolen Salt Holder: A Tale of Guilt, Forgiveness, and Redemption
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
NAMIK BEY (interviewee): Hippies, their belief was like this “no war, there is love” This was their slogan. They were good people, we never had any harm from them. Some didn’t have money, they would eat and go. Then they’d send the money in an envelope. They had carbon envelopes, and the money in them wouldn’t be recognized. They sent their debts in those envelopes. We always received our money. They were loyal to their debts.

SİNAN (interviewer): They were loyal to their debts and paid everything…

NAMIK BEY: back then, there wasn’t any order-taking paper. They come and say “I ate this and that” Turks however forget, they don’t remember all the details of their order. In other words, payment is forgotten, but tourists were different. For example, I told about the salt holder. We were sending goods to India as charity. Busses came here every day. The traffic wasn’t like this then. One bus was going east one was going west road.   We were finding traveling customers for the busses, and they go. One of them bought some tomatoes, cucomber and bread fort he trip. Young people used to eat those kind of things back then. He didnt know what he would find to eat on the way. He took the salt from us and forgot about it. He was German. He returned to Germany and kept the salt holder for 20-30 years, thinking that he was a thief and taking it, that he should have asked for permission. He took the salt holder and put it in a beautiful place in his house so that he wouldn’t break or harm it. It was glass material. Sometime later he came to us with a box of chocolate. He said “I am sorry, I did this and that… I brought you chocolate, please forgive me”

SİNAN: He, himself came…

NAMIK BEY: He did, yes.

SİNAN: He didn’t send it by cargo instead he came.

NAMIK BEY:  He came
item.excerpt:encoded: I remember one tourist in particular, a German man who had bought some food from us for his long bus journey. He had taken a salt holder from us without asking and didn't even realize it until he got back to Germany. He felt guilty for taking it and keeping it for so long without permission, and he kept it safe and well-preserved in his home for 20-30 years.

item.title: Christian Monastery (Late 6th century-Mid 8th century)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Christian monastery that has been discovered on Al Sinniyah Island, shows unique details about its residents (monks) such as refectory (dining hall), cisterns and some structures possibly reserved for monks.

Radiocarbon dating and assessment of pottery excavated at the site suggests the community flourished there between the late sixth century up to the middle of the eighth century, meaning it could have been established in the pre-Islamic era (.

item.title: Communal / Gathering / Dining Room
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Archaeologists have found a rectangular room next to the church building, that has seats along the two long walls, facing each other. It is understood from the remains that the walls of this room were plastered. Although it is clear that a group of people gathered in this room, it is not easy to say the exact function of the space for now.

item.title: Old UaQ 1 (13th to 15th century)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
One of two settlements identified on the south-west coast of Sinniya island, named Umm al Quwain 1. The first town flourished between the 13th / 14th and 15th centuries. It can be dated by the presence of green-glazed pottery exported from China under the late Yuan and early Ming dynasties. This settlement is contemporary with the peak of Julfar in Ra’s al-Khaimah, the leading pearling center of the Lower Gulf during the later Middle Ages.

This first settlement is the larger of the two recently identified on Siniya Island. It seems to have had an urbanized core of stone buildings surrounded by suburbs of palm-frond houses. A large oyster shell midden was found to the west of the settlement, pointing to the importance of the pre-modern pearling industry. Occupation subsequently shifted to another area but very close in distance, towards south east.

(https://wam.ae/en/details/1395303022785).

item.title: Old UaQ 3 (19th-20th century)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The foundation of the third town, which prospered between the 19th and mid-20th century, before the focus of settlement once more shifted, this time to the extensive suburbs of the modern city. The reason for establishing this third settlement differs in various sources. For instance while one document (https://wam.ae/en/details/1395303022785) says that "...this second town was destroyed on 18th January 1820 by a naval squadron despatched to the Arabian Gulf by the British East India Company to deal with the issue of piracy. A rare coin of Shaikh Sultan b. Saqr al-Qasimi, the powerful ruler of Ras Al Khaimah, has been discovered on the site. He signed the General Maritime Treaty of 1820 that brought hostilities to a close and laid the foundation for the modern United Arab Emirates...." the other one (https://www.bayut.com/area-guides/old-town-uaq/) says "...according to historians, the people of the Al Mualla tribe came from Al Sinniyah Island to Umm Al Quwain when the island’s drinking water ran out. They followed the occupation of their descendants and earned bread and butter through fishing and pearl diving...".

item.title: Sinjirli Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Alternative name: Zincirli Höyük, Samʼal, Yaʼdiya

7th Century BCE

Figure 1: "According to the catalogue description the obverse depicts a boat, the stem of which is shaped like the head and neck of an animal. However, this cannot be verified from the published photograph. The hindquarters of a hoofed animal standing in the boat are preserved. On the back of the animal kneels a human figure or a demon which holds a curved stadd toward a small horse. The reverse of the amulet shows an imaginary creature resembling a griffin; on the narrow side unidentifiable signs resembling script are engraved." (de Graeve 1981: 69-70). Dimensions 5cm high. Vorderasiatisches Museum, Berlin (S 5913). See also: H. Klengel, in MIO 6, 2 (1958), p. 338, No 31. 

Figure 2: Plaque is narrow at the top and perforated for suspension whereas the bottom is rounded. The boat that carries Lamashtu is small in comparison to the demon, it is slightly curved and has little details which seem to "be standing on a dog". (de Graeve 1981: 70). Dimensions 9.2cm high, 1.4cm thick. Vorderasiatisches Museum, Berlin (S3604). See also: F. Von Luschan-W, Die Kleinfunde von Sendschirli, p. 146, pl. 9c

Neo-Babylonian Period 612-539 BCE

Figure 3: "Large clay model broken at one end. The bottom is completely flat while the sides of the boat curve slightly inwards. At the gunwale eight projections are visible which suggests the presence of stanchions." (de Graeve 1981: 74). Dimensions: 12cm high x 46.5-60cm long x 15.9cm wide. Material: Clay. Vorderasiatisches Museum, Berlin (S 3152). See also: F. Von Luschan-W, Andrae, Die Kleinfunde von Sendschirli, p. 72, pl.36 n.

item.title: Babylon Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Neo-Babylonian Period 612-539 BCE

Figure 1: A boat is depicted with upturned ends carrying two men in long garments. The stern is incurving and is the highest. The steering oar with the rudderpost is manipulated by a helsman facing aft. Above the stern figures, a star. (de Graeve 1981:71). Dimensions 0.23cm x 0.15cm x 0.12cm. Vorderasiatisches Museum, Berlin (VAB Bab 16Vorderasiatisches Museum51-13955. VAN 8599). See also: L. Jacob-Rost, Die Stempelsigel im Vorderasiatischen Musuem, Staaliche Museen zu Berlin, Vonderasiatisches Musuem, Berlin, 1975, p. 56, pl. 12, No. 260. 

Figure 2:  "On the one side of the conical seal stone the stylus of Nabu appears upright on a stand ina boat with animal-headed prow and stern. Two worshippers, kneeling at the sides in the lower part of the field, raise their hands in prayer to the symbol in the boat above. Between them is an Aramaic inscription: šns/rsr: Sin-Shar-usur. On the other side of the seal is a priest in a fringed garment standing before the symbol of Nabu. On the base is a god in a fringed robe with cylindrical tiara standing in a crescent. He raised one hand; in the other he holds an emblem."(de Graeve 1981:71). Dimensions 0.26cm x 0.20cm x 0.14cm. Louvre, Paris (MNB 1842). See also: L. Delaporte, Louvre, II, p. 171, pl. 92, 1 a, b, c (A 732).

Figure 3:  "Model of boat with flat bottom and high prow and stern, one of which ends on a thick flattened top" (de Graeve 1981:72). See also: R. Koldewey, Babylon, p. 251, fig. 176 bottom. 

Figure 4: "Model of a boat with high straight upturned prow and stern, one of which ends in a kind of bird's head which is turned to the inside. The other end is broken" (de Graeve 1981:72). Dimensions: 22cm lenth. Vorderasiatisches Museum, Berlin (Bab. 1296) See also: A. Göttlicher, Corpus, p. 30, pl. 7, No. 99.

Figure 5: "Fragment of a boat which one end is partially perserved. The boat has a flat bottom and a thickening at the end. In the middle a "seat" is placed." (de Graeve 1981:72). Dimensions: Height at gunwale: 5.1cm and at Seat: 2.5cm; length 14.6cm; diameter at seat 4.3cm. Material: Red-brown clay reddish and green surface. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 47103; Field No. B 41159).

Figure 6: "Model with a flat bottom and a slightly upturned prow. A serpent-like animal crouches in the bottom." (de Graeve 1981:72). See also: R. Koldewey, Babylon, p. 251, fig. 177 bottom left.

Figure 7:  "Fragment of the centeral part of a boat with a flat bottom and slightly incurved sides which make a sharpe angel with the bottom. In the centre stands a roughly modelled creature. It is made separately and stands on a clay base." (de Graeve 1981:73). Dimensions: Height at gunwale 5.2cm and of Animal 3.1cm. Length 9.5cm and Animal 5.1cm; Length of clay attachment 7cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 47101; Field No. B 55283).

Figure 8:  "The boat has an upturend prow with small horizontal projection. The bilge is prolongates with what seems to resemble a ram." (de Graeve 1981:73). Dimensions: 5cm high x 9cm long x 6.5cm wide. Material: Red-buff clay with glitter. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 40416; Field No. 37841).

item.title: Uruk Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Alternative Names: Warka, Warkah

Neo-Babylonian Period 612-539 BCE

Figure 1: "The boat model has an upturned prow and stern and is divided into five parts by four thwarts, the second of which has a cavity for the mast. The mast foot proves the vessel is a sailing boat. The stern has a piercing hole and is decorated with bitumen and white inlay. The model is provided with 4 wheels and carries an animal and a square object, identified by H. Lenzen as a "dromedary" and a "Censer" (de Graeve 1981: 73). Dimensions: Height total 21cm, at gunwale: 9.3cm, at censer 4.7cm, at animal 10.9cm. Length of boat 38cm, of censer 4.7cm, of animal 14.3cm. Width of boat 16.5cm. Thickness thwarts 1cm, mast thwart 1.8cm. Diameter of wheels 14.5cm. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (IM 66811). See also: H. Lenzen, UVB XXI, pp. 9-10, pl. 12 a.  

Figure 2:  "The boat model is reconstructed of several fragments but is still incomplete. The hull is divided into five parts by four thwarts. The second of which has a holde for the mast. On both sides of the last thwart the gunwale has several knife-notchings and the stern is provided with a cross-piece, probably all features to hold the rigging. The boat is partly covered in bitumen." (de Graeve 1981: 74). Dimensions: 23cm long x 10.2cm wide. Material: Yellowish clay. Iraq Museum, Baghdad (Field No. W 20 556).See also: H. Lenzen, UVB XX, p. 27, pl. 21 a.

item.title: Being Children in old Kadırga
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Betül Ayhan (Interviewee)

-My mother’s memories are more important but I have also spent a very well childhood here.

We had a mobile ice cream seller who comes to this neighborhood, I think his name was Hakkı, and he was coming with his bicycle. We were (as kids) waiting for him all day, he was selling real ice cream, homemade, it was in a small cauldron/pot, which had a kind of manual roller in it (to mix the ice cream).  We would take money, stand in line, and wait for the ice cream seller. We used to race with the girls next door to get on the ice cream seller's bike…. Besides that, I remember eating bread and cheese in front of the house doors.

Nurcan Yalman (Interviewer):

-Tomatoe paste on bread?

Betül Ayhan:

-Yes! That too..

We used to play ‘hopscotch’ a lot, playing house, dodgeball, “istop”(*), playing jump rope, “Violet Violet! Who comes from us to you!?” game, do you remember they were holding hands and you try to break that barrier by knocking on them… I used to play marbles a lot, and play with crown caps…

I've read a lot of Texas Tommiks, Tom Braks, I have read also many pocket- photonovels.

(*) İstop is a ball game: the ball is thrown into the air by saying a name, the person whose name is called has to catch it. If he can't catch it, everyone runs away and he tries to hit them with the ball. If he catches it, he immediately calls the ball another name and throws it into the air).

Nurcan Yalman:

-You love reading then

Betül Ayhan:

-yes I love it.

NY:

-You know what they say when you start reading with these kinds of books, you gain the habit to read.

Betül Ayhan

-Yes, I do… For example, tomato paste, and pickles were made here, for instance, the house opposite made very good pickles, they were from Kayseri.

Her Mother (Türkan Ayhan):

-Next house of the opposite one was also from Kayseri. They both were making pickles, and “tarhana”(**), I was telling them that I will bring them materials (needed for tarhana and pickles) and do it for me too. But in any case, they would give anyway. Her husband was working in Gedikpaşa, and she was making “mantı”(***)  at home very often, I'd say "what are you doing, Rabiye?”, while I was cleaning the windows upstairs, and I would say, “save a plate for me too!” and she would bring me my portion.. then they bought a house at Koca Mustafa Paşa, they moved from here, but we visited each other very often. Because they were young when they first come here and since I was older, they were always entrusted to me. For instance, we used to go shopping together, they would say ‘you, be our mother’. Rabiye was young, she was walking ahead and I would say if you walk that fast how could I catch you up, you should have to match my pace, then we would walk together. They would always take me with them.

(**)Tarhana: sun-dried sour soup made of curd, tomato, and flour.

(***) Mantı: turkish ravioli, dumplings boiled and covered with yoghurt, garlic tomato souce.
