item.title: Becoming a Tailor
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Tucked in Litine neighourhood, in the Macuti part of the Island, is Ibrahim's tailor shop. Bright and vivid fabrics contrasted with the dark walls. There were sewing threads and garments everywhere we looked. Some were from clients, waiting for a fix repair, others were old materials, soon to be recycled. Ibrahim was sewing next to two of his workers, using manual sewing machines, with a treadle. Adults and children, waited patiently by the door.

Ibrahim Mamade

Tailor, 64 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Note: This conversation was translated from from Macua, the local dialect, to Portuguese, by Hafiz Jamu.

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Ibrahim Mamade: The Island of Mozambique has a great meaning for him, but especially the profession he has. It is hard to get the tools necessary to do this work. Even the lines used to soak, or the needles…are hard to get. In a negative way, there are not great living conditions here but he have nowhere to go. We can’t steal.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
I. M.: After the independence things were ok, because they were materials that was left from the colonial time but now the Island is declining.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? The UNESCO World Heritage Site classification helped boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
I. M.: He personally doesn’t see many foreigners but when he was informed that the things would now be good he believed it and thought that it would be beneficial but in reality he isn’t feeling anything changing.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as an historical place?
I. M.: He feels that yes. But they don’t see nothing changing. The reality is that everyone would like to see the Island renovated, good looking and nice but it is not happening. What he is hearing from people is that another elections are going to take place and other people will be in charge to improve the Island of Mozambique’s quality of living and will be again a good place to live. Nothing happens. People go there and vote but nothing changes. And another year, again voting and still nothing. The Island still has things to improve. We are waiting and our day of death will arrived and things still weren’t done

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
I. M.: He told how they got this machines. He was an apprentice from 1966 and a tailor since 1970. He went to learn the job with a master. The financial system, back then, they used to pay in advance the machines and then there was a system of tax collection, a very simple one. But very strict. Not like today. Today some random person appears and they go to the market according to the economic activities that are taking place. There is a difficulty to work because there are no materials to work with. No needle, fabric, pieces for the machines, it is very hard. This machines were bought by 2250 escudos [former Portuguese currency] and then he was taught the art of soaking with the master. Right now he is teaching some students also. He is the master now. Everything on the Island is like this. A person learns with the master.

item.title: Carrying on with the traditions
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Amina Chazama João

Works in an NGO, 24 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

About her occupation.
Amina Chazama João: I am in a generation and life program where I advise girls, those who do not study. We have trainers who help with the project and when we have difficulties they help us.

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
A. C. J.: The island for me is a wonderful city. It has very beautiful history and for that reason I’m proud of it. Although it is not from here, I like this city. I'm from Nampula and then I came to live here.

You know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The UNESCO World Heritage Site classification…?
A. C. J.: No. I heard you have a special status but I do not know.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
A. C. J.: Yes, it has changed. Now things are improving and we are enjoying for it.

What is improving on the Island of Mozambique?
A. C. J.: They are improving the roads that used to had rocks and mud. Now we already have markets, and gardens and a lot that is going on and we compliment and we like it. The island is recovering.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Did the WHS classification helped boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
A. C. J.: Yes, I’m seeing more foreigners now. I’m seeing university projects. Every time they come to the Island they do some training sessions. 

Do you feel connected to some monument in the Island of Mozambique?
A. C. J.: The museum of the Island.

What is your opinion about the museum?
A. C. J.: It tells the story of Mozambique and of Vasco da Gama as well. It tells the history of the Island of Mozambique.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as an historical place?
A. C. J.: Yes, a lot.

What do you consider to be your own personal heritage?
A. C. J.: The painting, the stencil/ imprint represents us.

Do you identify to any part of the history of the Island of Mozambique? If so, which one?
A. C. J.: I like everything.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
A. C. J.: In the old days, I've seen ladies painting themselves. They have their own traditional make-up, the mussiro, I do not know how to say in other languages, we have the shells too. We also have popular dance for girls. They are traditional things part from the colonial time. We have old traditions and we imitate what people used to do in the previous years. Here there are many women who like to paint themselves and who walk in plana and scarf, with bineira, sell paint... we also do that.

What is Bineira?
A. C. J.: We have our own arts. People with bineira have their own liquid, have the very paint they put inside and sell. This [the bineira] is made of straw. Some zones do this. There are people who do and others sell it and others who do draw. All Island dances the Tufo.

item.title: Shurrupak History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From the Epic of Gilgamesh: Preceding a flood sent by the gods, Utnapishtim was instructed to build an "ark" to take a sample of every living thing. The hull is waterproofed with oil, pitch and asphalt and the ship was launched with rollers, suggesting a flat bottomed hull. Following the flood, Utnapishtim and his wife settled in Dilmun (Paine 2015 p. 61).

item.title: Failaka History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Falaika traded with Dilmun (Qatar), then later Bahrain Island (Alpers, 2014 p.22), and was the port from which Ubaid pottery was exported into into the Gulf.

Sumerian traders exported grain, pottery and bitumen and imported copper, stone, timber, dates, onions and pearls from the Gulf (Alpers, 2014 p.22).

Alexander the Great's fleet commander, Nearchus, established an outpost on the island around 330 BCE and built a temple there. Greek pottery is found in the island's archaeological sites (Alpers 2014 p.28).

item.title: al-Sabiyah History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Archaeological evidence of reed ship building dating back to about 5000 BCE has been found at al-Sabiyah (Abulafia 2019 p.54)

item.title: Persepolis Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Persian Period 559-331 BCE

Figure 1: War galley with a curved bilge terminating as a ram spur at the prow. The stern of the vessel is upcurved ending in a head of an unidentifiable monster; the stern is also decorated with a stylus. Twenty one oars are depicted suggests three rows of twenty one oars on each side; at the prow is a kind of horn-like projection on which a brail and a brace are fastened, a bral and brace are fastened in the stern at the spar. the impression is partially damaged; the boat might have an upper deck which two figures are on either side of the mast. On label PT 4.550 only the ram, the horn like projection with brail, the mast, and the four passengers are partially preserved"(de Graeve 1981: 75). Oriental Institute Museum, Chicago (P 274 C). See also" E.F. Schmidt, Persepolis II, p. 30, pl. 9.

Figure 2: Detailed galley similar to the previous one - clusters of twenty one oars in three levels; two steering oars and a horn-like projection are present as well as 4 passengers. Two masts with a furled sail, brail and braces suggest two galleys one behind the other. E.F Schmidt seems to have confused these two seals (DG106-107). "He mentioned one seal (DG032) being impressed on both labels PT 4 847 and PT 4 704 (de Graeve 1981: 75). Oriental Institute Museum, Chicago (P 4001). See also: E.F. Schmidt, Persepolis II, p. 30, pl. 9

item.title: Dilmun History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The extent of Dilmun is unknown, but it has been accepted that texts referring to Dilmun refer to a central city in modern-day Bahrain. However, it is possible that Dilmun had outposts across the Gulf, in Qatar and as far east as Abu Dhabi (Abulafia 2019 pp.65-67).

Dilmun became part of the Gulf maritime trade routes around 5000BCE. At the time, it included parts of Qatar, but later the name became associated with modern day Bahrain (Alpers 2014 p.22). Although Dilmun is an important node on the trade routes (metal, wood, stone) in the Gulf from the fifth millenneum BCE, it was not until about 2900 BCE that it rises to prominance as Mesopotamian traders shift their focus from the Mediterraean in the west, towards the trade markets in the east (Paine 2015 p. 61). Dilmun became an intermediary port between Mesopotamia and the northwest Indian Ocean (Alpers 2104, p.22). Stone, especially alabaster, was imported from the interior of Magan (Oman/UAE) and wood was brought from northwestern India.

Dilmun itself is an "oasis" in the otherwise arid Gulf. It has fish, dates, and fresh water, making it an important node for replenishing ships sailing the Gulf. Merchants from Dilmun capitalized on this and their geographical location as a middle point between two rich trade regions (Mesopotamia to the north and Magan and Meluhha/Harappa to the east) (Paine 2015 pp. 61-62).

Merchants traded up the "copper river" (as the Euphrates was known in Sumerian) with cities such as Ur. Pottery from Sumer is found in burials in Dilmun archaeological sites.

Dilmun was the home of Utnapishtim (from the great flood in the Epic of Gilgamesh - see Shurrupak) (Paine 2015 p. 61).

Like other prominent trade ports, Dilmun declines rapidly at the end of the Bronze Age when invaders, including the Sea People decimate the Bronze Age empires between 1200 and 1100 BCE (Paine 2015 pp 74-79).

item.title: Delma History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: By the late 6th millennium, dates were being traded at Dalma indicating early maritime trade networks

item.title: Umm al-Nar History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Magan is the area encompassing the UAE and Oman (possibly southern Iran).

Magan was a source of copper, timber and diorite.

Magan's strategic significance is bourne out by the fact that Sargon's predecessors built a fleet of ships to sail against the 32 cities of Magan. This is on of the first instances of ships being build purely for military purposes (Paine 2015 p. 64).

Umm al-Nar was the access point for traders coming from the northern parts of the Gulf to Magan. It was viewed as a "warehouse" for Magan goods being dispatched northwards (Abulafia 2019 p.61)

Accounts of Sargon I, the Akkadian conqueror of Sumer around 2400 BCE, mention the ships of Magan.

item.title: Ras Al Jinz Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Multiple archaeological finds originating from Harappa (20% of finds - Alpers 2014 p.23)

Broomcorn millet, a grain of Chinese origin reached the Arabian Penisula, probably by sea, as early as 2000 - 15000 BCE (Alpers 2014 p. 25).

Archaeological excavations of sites dating to 2500 - 2200 BCE show evidence of shipbuilding. A site, believed to be a shipyard, has yielded over 300 fragments of bitumen imprinted with reeds, reed bundles, mats and lashed timbers. Barnacles have been found on the smooth outer faces of some of the fragments. These provide important evidence of how materials were used in ship construction (Paine 2015 p. 64). Importantly, the evidence shows how reed bundles, 4 - 12cm in diameter were made up and assembled into sailing vessels. Reed bundles, once assembled were covered with reed mats or animal skins and coated with bitumen (Paine 2015 pp. 64-65).

item.title: Sutkagen Dor
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sutkagan Dor (or Sutkagen Dor) is the westernmost known archaeological site of the Indus Valley Civilization. It is located about 480 km west of Karachi on the Makran coast near Gwadar, close to the Iranian border, in Pakistan's Baluchistan Province. The site is near the western bank of the Dasht River and its confluence with a smaller stream, known as the Gajo Kaur. It was a smaller settlement with substantial stone walls and gateways.

Though inland at present, the site may have been near navigable water in ancient times, on a trade route between other centers. A coastal route existed linking sites such as Lothal and Dholavira to Sutkagan Dor on the Makran coast.[4] It has been suggested that the site may well have been an important trading post, connecting seaborne trade from the Persian Gulf and the Arabian Sea to the hinterland (wikipedia).

item.title: Sokta Koh History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sokta Koh was a trading port linking Harappa and Indus Valley to Gulf, Arabia Peninsula and African coast.

item.title: Mohenjo-daro Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Built around 2500 BCE, it was the largest settlement of the ancient Indus Valley Civilization and and one of the world's earliest major cities. Mohenjo-daro was abandoned in the 19th century BCE as the Indus Valley Civilization declined, and the site was not rediscovered until the 1920s. Significant excavation has since been conducted at the site of the city, which was designated a World Heritage Site in 1980.

https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/138/

item.title: Lothal Archaeological Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Lothal archaeological site, excavated from 1955–1960, includes the historic ruins of an Indus valley civilization dating to 3700 BCE. It was Harappa port town and center of trade between Harappa/Indus Valley and the Gulf.

Lothal is a UNESCO World Heritage Site

item.title: Harappa/Meluhha Civilization
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Harappa was and early Indus valley civilization around 2600 - 1900 BCE. Harappa was known as known as Meluhha by Akkadians.

The location and extend of Meluhha and the Harappan civilization are unclear. In the early first milennium BCE Meluhha was associated with parts of East Africa (Abulafia 2019 p.61). Meluhha is one of the least know Bronze Age civilizations (Abulafia 2019 p.62)

Traded lapis lazuli, "black wood" (probably ebony), semi-precious stones, ivory (Abulafia 2019 p.63)

Although land based, linked via significant maritime trade to Magan and the Gulf. Sargon I text refers to large Meluhha cargo vessels trading in the Gulf (Alpers 2014).

Meluhha was Mesopotamia's "maritime frontier" in the late third millenium BCE (Paine 2015 p.57).

Harappa was a "highly organized commercial society with state control of artisan production" (Alpers 2014 p 22, Paine 2015 p. 63, Abulafia 2019 p.63), but merchants at coastal trading colonies of Lothal, in Gujurat, and Sutkagen Dor and Sokta Koh on the Makran coast of Pakistan.

Traded pots (probably carrying ghee), ritual axe blades for burial, carnelian beads, wood, and seals and weights (Harappan weights became the standard in the Gulf) with the Gulf.

Meluhha traded with Africa and made open water crossings to Ras al-Junayz (Ras al-Jinz) in Oman on the eastern tip of the Arabian Peninsula (Alpers 2014, p.23)

Broomcorn millet, a grain of Chinese origin appeared around the north-western Indian Ocean as early as 2000 - 15000 BCE. Sorghum and millet domesticated in northern Africa appear in the Late Harappan period (1900 - 1300 BCE) (Alpers 2014 p. 25).

Harappa World Heritage Site

item.title: The "discovery" of the Monsoon System
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In the 1st century BCE, Hippalus, a Greek navigator, "identified how the Southwest Monsoon operated. This allowed ships leaving the Red Sea and entering the Gulf "to sail directly to India" (Alpers 2014 p. 28)

item.title: The periphery of Bronze Age shipping
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Greek sailors known as Yavanas sailed as far east as Sri Lanka in the time of the Ptolomy rulers (305 - 30 BCE) (Alpers 2014 p.28)

item.title: Muza History
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The ancient port of Muza was described in the "Periplus of the Erythraen Sea" (Alpers 2014 p.19). It had trade connections with Barygaza by 1st Century CE and also traded with the African coast and Broach or Bharuch (later Gurarat, India), a vital trade port.

item.title: The Land of Punt
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Evidence of trade between the Red Sea and Nile Valley through Pharonic voyages 2600-1150 BCE. Burial sites in Egypt include cowrie shells, mytth, incense and ebony from Punt (Alpers 2024 pp.23-24). Tis trade system is contemporary with expansion of trade between the Gulf and Indis Valley, but at the earliest stages does not include direct trade between the Red Sea and the Gulf and Indus Valley (Alpers 2014 p. 23).

By 2000 BCE, however, there is botanical evidence suggesting contact between Punt with the Indian Ocean trade system including the Gulf and Indus Valley. Analysis of botanical evidence shows exchange of plans and animals between Africa, South Asia and Arabia, most ;ikely driven by small-scale coastal trade and interaction between fishing communities (Alpers 2024 pp.24-25).

Evidence suggests that around 2200 BCE a major climate shift towards drier and more unpredictable environment drove the movement of domesticated African crops of sorghum, pearl millet and finger millet towards India, skirting the northern reaches of Arabian Sea. (Alpers 2024 p. 25).

Zebu cows made the journey from India to Africa possibly around this time, but the timing of their appearance is significantly varied over locations. The cows are an important marker for intentional maritime trade in livestock unlike the appearance of rodents and weeds from India that were almost certainly transported by accident.

If I have to preserve something I will preserve that food that I remember when I was a kid. Clothes that I remember as a kid that's what I would do. That to me it's everything.

item.title: The Inevitable Change Of The Cankurtaran District
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Interviewer (Nurcan Yalman)-NYalman

-Why do you wish to leave here? But why?

The interviewee, Mukhtar of Cankurtaran District

(Nevin Taş)-NTaş

- I don’t feel comfortable here anymore... even though I was born and bred here.

NYalman

- So, do none of your friends stay in this neighborhood?

N.Taş

-I don’t think so, the residential population is not many anyway. Those who already exist usually have come from outside. The locals are not more than ten houses.

NYalman

-Are they also planning to leave?

NTaş

-Yes. Obviously, they were made to leave from here.

NYalman

-And according to you, how this has happened? Is it Tourism?

NTaş

- I don't blame tourism either, No! No! I get angry with those who allow, I get angry with those who give way.

NYalman

- How do you think it should have been then? Because tourism has to exist, namely Sultanahmet, Topkapı Palace, etc.

NTaş

- Well, it's a place with palaces. Tourism, of course. We are not against tourism anyway.

NYalman

- So what could it be? If you had run this place from the beginning, how would you do it? What would you do?

NTaş

- I would do a lot of things. I would open nice kindergartens, I would open schools, I could do very good things.

NYalman

- So are you saying that you would protect the residential-neighborhood culture?

NTaş

- Of course, I would protect it. The neighborhood culture was something very different here. We would have weddings, we would do it outdoors. It is difficult to explain, I am very emotional, oops, I loved our neighborhood culture very much. We, about 10 families, are still continuing our own neighborhood culture. For example, we have our Roman (gypsy) neighborhood down there, it is Ahırkapı Roman neighborhood. There aren't any people left there either. Now, most of them are the people who came from Taşlıtarla, Gazi Osman Pasha, Mimar Sinan, and such places.

NYalman

- Is there a road connecting to Ahırkapı from here?

NTaş

- Sure, if you go under that bridge, you turn from the first right, you arrive at a square, it's quite a big area.

NYalman

- Living with the Romans (gypsies) must be something fun.

NTaş

-But, we love them.

NYalman

-No need to say “but”, I also like them.

- Our henna nights and weddings are lovely, they are very entertaining people. They enjoy their days, there are no such things as sadness or gloom, and they are very relaxed people, I love them, and I know that they love me too. For example, whether on a wedding day, whether somebody is ill or dead, we stick together in good and hard times. I'm carrying our neighborhood culture down to Ahırkapı as well.

NYalman

- How do they view this situation? (Tourism and the change it brings)

NTaş

- They hardly know the past of this place.

NYalman

Are they new here?

NTaş

- of course, of course. Those old ones are already gone, some of them died, and the rest are very few, but most of them came later and do not know the past/history of this place.

item.title: Christian Monastery
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The discovery of a historic Christian monastery on Siniyah Island, located along the Persian Gulf in Umm al-Quwain, sheds new light on the early Christian presence in the region. Carbon dating of samples found within the monastery's foundation dates between 534 and 656, indicating that the monastery was established in the early Christian era. The monastery consists of a group of community buildings, a church, a refectory, and cisterns surrounded by isolated rooms for monks. The walls and floors of the buildings were covered with lime plaster, and the monastery was constructed using local beach rocks.

From an aerial perspective, the floor plan of the monastery suggests that early Christian worshippers prayed within a single-aisle church at the monastery. The monastery's cluster of buildings includes a kitchen, storerooms, a cistern for collecting drinking water, and an oven for communion bread. The rooms within appear to hold items such as a baptismal font and an oven for baking bread or wafers used for communion rites. Archaeologists discovered an altar and bowls that are thought to have been used for mixing wine and a large cistern found close to the altar could have potentially been used for baptisms A nave discovered within the site also likely held an altar and an installation for the communion wine used during religious rituals. Adjacent to the monastery is a second building with four rooms, thought to be the home of an abbot or even a bishop in the early church. It is believed that the early Christian community celebrated mass at the single-aisle church, prayed seven times a day, chanted prayers, and sang hymns.

Pottery and glass artifacts excavated from the site indicate that the monastery's inhabitants had links to international trade that extended from Iraq to India. Radiocarbon dating of coal samples and the study of pottery extracted from the site indicate the monastery's prosperity lasted from the late sixth century to the middle of the eighth century AD. This suggests the Christian monastic community on the island of Siniyah witnessed the emergence of Islam in the seventh century AD.

The monastery's architecture and artifacts offer a glimpse into the religious practices and daily life of early Christian worshippers, shedding light on the rich history of the area. Overall, the discovery of the Christian monastery on Siniyah Island provides valuable insights into the early Christian presence in the region and the international trade links established by the monastic community.

References: 

Power, Timothy, Federico Borgi, Michele Degli Esposti, Robert Hoyland, and Rania Hussein Kannouma. “Archaeological Survey of Sīnīya Island, Umm Al-Quwain.” Études et Travaux, no. 35 (2022). https://doi.org/10.12775/etudtrav.35.007.

“Ancient Christian Monastery Found off Coast of United Arab Emirates Could Be 1,400 Years Old, Pre-Dating Islam.” CBS News, CBS Interactive, 3 Nov. 2022, www.cbsnews.com/news/christian-monastery-found-united-arab-emirates-siniyah-island/. 

“UAE..Discovering a Historic Christian Monastery on al-Siniyah Island in Umm al Quwain.” Pledge Times, 3 Nov. 2022, pledgetimes.com/uae-discovering-a-historic-christian-monastery-on-al-siniyah-island-in-umm-al-quwain/. 

Wam. “UAE: Ancient Christian Monastery Unearthed in Umm al Quwain.” Uae – Gulf News, Gulf News, 5 Nov. 2022, gulfnews.com/uae/uae-ancient-christian-monastery-unearthed-in-umm-al-quwain-1.91755403.

item.title: Bishop’s House
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This part of the structure has been identified as the home of the bishop. Like other Christian sects, the Nestorian Church organized itself into a hierarchy, through which doctrinal interpretations and faith-practices were determined and disseminated. High-ranking officials, like bishops, were in residence within particularly important Church communities, where there were not just the usual daily and weekly religious services to perform but there were administrative needs that connected directly to church leadership concerns. Through the presence of a bishop, particularly one in need of a residence of rough equivalence in size to the entire church structure, is an indication of the significance of this site within the Nestorian order.

Nestorian Christianity is an offshoot of the Eastern Orthodox Church, formed in the 4th and 5th centuries in regards to Church controversies over “the person and nature of Christ.” Essentially, different factions within Eastern Christianity backed rivaling interpretations of Jesus of Nazareth as divine, as human, and as both. Although the matter was solved from an institutional perspective at the Council of Chalcedon (451 CE), the Nestorian interpretation, that Jesus had two persons in one body, one that was divine and the other that was human, was deemed heretical; Thus, the Nestorians were expelled from the Eastern Roman Empire, which became the Byzantine Empire. It was at that time that Nestorians relocated first to Syria and then eventually to Arabia and Persia. The construction of this church is therefore consistent with the timeline for Nestorian relocation.

The Nestorians, like other Christian sects, actively prosthelytized, thereby spreading their doctrine widely throughout Syria, Armenia, Arabia, Persia, northern India and even western China. By the 6th and 7th centuries, Nestorianism had become the dominant Christian sect in Arabia. After the emergence of Islam in the early 7th century, Nestorians received recognition as a “people of the book,” which allowed them to continue to expand under the protection of Islam. In fact, many high-ranking Nestorians from within the Church hierarchy found themselves employed in Arab state administrations because of their associations with learning, particularly medicine. With the emergence of the Abbasid Caliphate in the 8th century, the Nestorian Church moved its headquarters to Baghdad, the new capital of the Muslim world. Nestorian Christianity continued to thrive for centuries, though its community was gradually eroded through the conversion of its congregations from Nestorianism to Islam. 

The discovery of this site in the UAE, long associated with a strong Islamic identity, speaks to the region’s crosscultural and interreligious history. In fact, Umm al-Quwain is a testament to the openness of the country to new beliefs and identities, as a sect of Christianity was not only able to relocate to this location but to thrive for centuries. Thus as an illustration of the pluralistic nature of the country and its communities, Umm al-Quwain contains Nestorian relics as well as undeniable evidence that a multicultural and multireligious community interacted in what is now the UAE long before the UAE had assumed its current reputation as a ‘melting pot’ of cultures and nations.

References:

Akopian, Arman. "10. The split of Syriac Christianity: “Nestorians” and “Jacobites”" In Introduction to Aramean and Syriac Studies: A manual, 199-216. Piscataway, NJ, USA: Gorgias Press, 2017. https://doi.org/10.31826/9781463238933-013

Baker-Whitelaw, Gavia. "Ancient Christian Monastery Discovered on Island off United Arab Emirates Coast." Sky News, May 3, 2023. https://news.sky.com/story/ancient-christian-monastery-discovered-on-island-off-united-arab-emirates-coast-12737047

New York: Harper & Brothers, 1894. Biblical Cyclopedia. Accessed May 3, 2023. https://www.biblicalcyclopedia.com/N/nestorians.html

item.title: The Secret Recipe from East Turkistan: The Journey of Sultanahmet Köftecisi's Meatballs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
BEGÜM: So, was there a meatball shop here before?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, i don’t know if you know, the Sultanahmet was the center of Istanbul. Everything was Sultanahmet and everywhere was Sultanahmet. All newspapers, furnishings, and clothing centers were in Sultanahmet and its surroundings. They call it inside the wall. It was the center of Istanbul. But somehow here was touristic. I guess it also was touristic back in those times. It used to be a place where people lived, but not now. Currently touristy. The name of the road is divan(sultan) road, it is called the road to the palace.

BEGÜM: Do you have any connection with Inegöl, considering you said there was never a kebab restaurant here before?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, my great-grandfather's father was from East Turkistan. He comes from Kashgar, a region currently under Chinese oppression. The meatball he first made was similar to the meatballs from that region. They still use the same recipe, but the format has changed. Previously, with only 30-40 customers per day, the meatballs were served on skewers. As customer numbers increased, the format was changed to individual servings. The recipe he brought is traditional and he brought it from there to here. I later met with Coskun Aral and he said that your meatballs reminded him of the meatballs from there. So, it seems that my great-grandfather's father brought a traditional dish from there to here.

NURCAN: Do they come directly from there or are they from there?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: His grandfather's father came here as a child by himself. At that time, he was setting out for the pilgrimage. At that time, the pilgrimage route seems to have passed through Istanbul, there was something like that. When you leave China, there is transit through Istanbul, not directly to Arabia. Then the First World War breaks out in Istanbul and he stays here. After staying here, he begins to grow his life and settle down.

NURCAN: Did he start by opening the shop?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, as I said earlier, he starts by working in printing presses. This place used to be the center of journalism and printing. He starts working there and then he wants to open his own shop and chooses to sell meatballs. He rents the front of a coal shop and sells meatballs in front while coal is sold at the back. The business starts. Not here, but follow this road, there's the Yerebatan Cistern which has a million stones. The shops were in front of that million stones. I don't remember. It was expropriated later. The million stones were inside the shops. For example, they used to lower baskets into the Yerebatan Cistern like a refrigerator so that perishable food items like meat wouldn't spoil because it was cold and humid. He rented the front of a coal shop that supplies coal to homes and businesses.

NURCAN: So it might have been the location where the current sidewalk is.

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: Yes, it was the location of that sidewalk. It can also be seen in the old photos, even inside the store.

NURCAN: So what about Inegol Meatball?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: We don't have any relationship with Inegol Meatball, but every region has its own type of Kofta. Every mother has her own way of making meatballs. The meatball my mother makes is different from the meatball your mother makes, even though they make the same thing, there is a difference in taste. I respect Inegol Meatball and Tekirdağ Meatball.

NURCAN: The thing you call Sultanahmet meatball has always been referred to as İnegöl meatball.

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, that's not true. We don't have any relationship with Inegol Meatball. As I said, every region has its own unique Kofta. As a meatball maker, I feel obligated to try the unique Meatballs of any region I visit, but I love Meatball and I want to try the best Meatball in any place I visit. They say "Are you feeding Meatball to a Meatball maker?" but let's have a Meatball here. Let's taste it.

NURCAN: Is there garlic in it? Is there any difference in the Meatball?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, there are no spices. Zero spices.

NURCAN: So you're not going to give us the secret?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: Even if I give it to you, you won't be able to do it. This is a 100-year-old shop and many people have left and opened their own shops, but failed. Even if I give it to you, you won't be able to do it.

NURCAN: But there must be a secret tip because when you say Sultanahmet Meatball, it means something.

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: The fact that the secret tip is not important. I can tell you the ingredients right now. You can go home and make it, but it won't be like the Meatball here. I know that. Many people have left here and opened their own shops, but failed. I know that. One of our 20-year-old employees left, opened a shop, and came back and said, "We failed." and you will fail too.

item.title: Perspectives from her home
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
"Hey lady! What are you doing with your camera? Came take a picture of me".

Through the allies and narrow streets of Macuti Town, this voice grabbed my attention and so did her request. I introduced myself to Zainabo Sumaila, and shoot a couple of portraits, in front of her home.

Zainabo Sumaila

Unemployed, 50 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Zainabo Sumaila, translated by Hafiz Jamu on a few sections: I feel the Island is isolated. There are no jobs. The children go to school, study and when they finish there are no job opportunities. It is complicated. People sometimes leave the Island to get jobs, but when they reach the cities, where the employment is, for example, in Nacala they are charged money to be able to join the companies.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time? Especially after 1991, the year Island of Mozambique was classified as UNESCO World Heritage Site (WHS)?
Z. S.: Nothing changed.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Did the WHS classification help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
Z. S.: I see tourists coming. I like tourists, and students coming to make research. A thing that I don’t like is that…We do not have money or jobs or good living conditions. And they leave nothing here. We don’t see the direct benefits of it. We do not gain anything from them. People only appear and leave without any visible benefits to the Island.

Did you ever visited one of the Island’s museums?
Z. S.: I don't. I don't leave home.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
Z. S.: It’s hard to identify a heritage for me because I don’t leave the house. I see on TV that other countries, in other parts of the world, can have support from institutions for disadvantaged people and I don’t feel that. My house is falling apart and there are no support or jobs that promote people’s life here on the Island.

Is there any story or anything else you would like to share?
Z. S.: I don’t have a family story to share. What bothers me is that I’m not supported. Nobody supports the restoration of my house or the improvement of my living conditions. My house is a traditional house that belongs to my parents and grandparents. Until now nobody seems to like to support this house.

People sometimes leave the Island to get jobs, but when they reach the cities, where the employment is, for example, in Nacala they are charged money to be able to join the companies.

item.title: Tales from another time
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Amina Momade

Retired, +70, possibly 80 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Note: Translated from Macua language to Portuguese by Hafiz Jamu.

About her former life on the Island.
Amina Momade: Her life boils down to the fact that she made candy – of cocoa, sugar, and other things - She used to cut it and take that candy to Mister Feliz [can be Felix], a white, nonlocal gentleman and dealt with it. She would deliver this candy for 10 escudos [name of the currency before 1975] and carry 1 escudo to this lord as profit. And she lived on it. There were also priests here, Father Lopes, who lived on the Island for 50 years. This priest Lopes helped her in some economic activities of her and other people. They all lived harmoniously.

Interviewer: Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time? If so, how?
A. M.: For her, ways of life have changed because people who had the knowledge have all died. Now some young people are not aware. So there was a lot of change. The way of life has changed, and the culture has changed. There is no longer respect and closeness. The people who spread the good culture have all disappeared. The young people who remain do not know how to go down with social activity.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? The UNESCO World Heritage nomination helped boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
A. M.: The foreigners at the time when they came had good hearts and approach. She is a person who has needs and they helped people. They have to come. They have to come as they always did the same way they built their houses and these houses stayed. That area of the city of stone, no longer has the brightness it had. There are no people who know how to treat that area.

Do you feel connected to some area/monument/other on the Island of Mozambique?
A. M.: She always lived in this neighbourhood. There were people she knew, who were friends. Now she does not go outside where she lives because she is used to dealing with the usual people. Some have died, and others are elsewhere. There is nobody she knows. Now, she stays here. Does not go outside.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
A. M.: Events that it reflects come from the inheritance process. If the people sit down and say that this asset stays with the guy, it stays with him. Older people decide that this asset is for themselves. But then when the person leaves, we get upset that that thing was for that person and we get angry that it stays that way. And this happens a lot here.

At this moment there is nothing good on the Island. The atmosphere is not good. In the old days we lived better. There were (???) Indians, (???) [can’t translate], there were goldsmiths to make earrings… That is all over. It changed because we only stayed between us macuas. Because a macua ruler came. And the macua sense is a hostile government, unaware.

They have to come as they always did the same way they built their houses and these houses stayed. That area of the city of stone, no longer has the brightness it had. There are no people who know how to treat that area.

item.title: Heritage and an unexpected Tour
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Close to Amina Momade, was this young man named Yunusso, born and raised on Island of Mozambique. As such, we talked for a few minutes.

Yunusso Ahamada

Unemployed, 22 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

About his employment situation:
Yunusso Ahamada: Now I don’t do anything. But a few months ago, I was in a project name LAMBDA. It’s a project about homosexuals, the LGBT community, and lesbians. We were doing an awareness campaign to help others like them not feel discriminated against, not to hide, to not feel ashamed to be who they are. To help them come out and stay united.

Interviewer: Is this a special project in Island of Mozambique or is it all over the country?
Y. A.: It’s in all of Mozambique.

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Y. A.: The Island is very important to me. I’m proud of being born on the Island. To know that I live in a place that is a World Heritage Site. I’m very proud of that.

Do you know what are UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The World Heritage Site (WHS) nomination?
Y. A.: Yes. I know what UNESCO is and about the classification, but that is it.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
Y. A.: If time is enough, things can change. From my point of view, the Island has changed just a little bit. It’s not changing fast as expected. I’m remembering when I [was learning] Portuguese in 2006, the island had this project with young people and children. It is a good initiative and opens horizons for young people so they can have more skills. So when the Island was classified I thought this type of project would take place on the Island as well to form young people too. But in 2006, 2007, 2008… I saw everything was calm. It didn’t gain the life I was expecting. One day the Island can change but it’s not there yet.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Did the WHS classification help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
Y. A.: UNESCO people, tourists, researchers, they all show up here. Some people say they come here but don’t do anything, they don’t work. I don’t think that. I just ask that they come here more often, with new initiatives, do their job with professionalism, and move on.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
Y. A.: For me, it’s the fortress, because in 2006 when I was a child I remember that I used to play there, in the fortress, with my friends. My teachers said we couldn’t play there but we would go anyway. We were children. The fortress says something to me because of my time playing there.

Did you visit any museums? If so, what is your opinion about them?
Y. A.: I visited during school. I haven’t returned since. The museum looked good. They showed me Samora’s bed. And they have that boat at the entrance. A boat of Vasco da Gama. For me, it was very interesting. Since 2006 I don’t go there. People on the Island don’t often go there. Only tourists. Local people lack the will to go to the museum. If people had good jobs or good salaries maybe they would have the will to go.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
Y. A.: My heritage is the food. I like matapa de siri siri (a typical dish). They prepare this outside the Island but here as well. Since I was 6 I remember that I tasted matapa. And I like it very very much. It marks me. It is a food that represents our culture.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
Y. A.: I remember that I was with my friends and a Spanish woman, named Cristina. He [a friend] arrived and knocked on my door. He was saying that we should do a tour to the island for some pretty tourists. But we had school so we had to go fast. I agreed to go with them. They introduced to me this Spanish woman, named Cristina, and an Argentinian woman, as well, named Marcia. So we went on the boat to the island of Goa. We crossed the ocean to the island. When we were kids, we would bet who could reach the deepest depths at sea. The winner would gain 20 meticais [local currency]. We arrived at the Island of Goa and did a bonfire. I had the dream of being a musician. So a friend brought a guitar and knew that I had this dream. But I ignored him. I didn’t want to do anything in front of them, in front of the ladies. But they encouraged me. Said I shouldn’t be ashamed of singing. So I started to sing for them, and they applauded me. They said I needed to improve a bit but I should follow the dream. We caught some fish, although I didn’t have any previous experience. It was just for them. We stayed there for 2 days on the island of Goa. The Spanish girl also sang a lot, and very well. And we did a singing duet, one in Spanish and one in Portuguese. It was very nice.

item.title: Mother and Son conversations
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
It was one of the first houses I've entered on Island of Mozambique. The colours striked me. A beautiful contrast between the pastel-tone walls and a red floor. I first met the mom, Maria Camussi Cassimo. She was very shy. As soon as her son, Numati, got inside the room and started to answer she agreed with everything that was said and laughed. It set a positive mood on our interaction.

Maria & Numati Camussi Cassimo

Unemployed, 55 years old & unemployed, 28 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Numati: It is a world heritage site that has a lot of ancient history and it tunes the Island. Our beaches, and fortress, are places of prodigy, symbolizing the island of Mozambique.

Maria: Is where it is world heritage and tourism. People come here to take a sightseeing tour.

Do you know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The World Heritage Site (WHS) nomination…?
N. C. C.: We have little knowledge about it. We have heard about this, but I do not know what area UNESCO acts in.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time, especially after the WHS nomination:
N. C. C.: Formerly the island was somewhat ... After being classified, came more tourism and everything gained more life. Day after day is evolving and people like to come to stroll to the Island.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Does the WHS nomination help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
N. C. C.: It is a pride that we have if a European came to question our Island, what the name, how are things here… It’s an advantage that they come to our island, is a pride. One day we may also have the opportunity to go outside asking about the history of Portugal, for example. It is a pride that the government is allowing people to come and accept Europeans to come and create an idea of us as we are and how we can live on the other side, and access other places. We also create an idea. We may have a very broad idea but with the succession of people we can have a better idea.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
N. C. C.: They want to know about our island. It's the old people that passed here who are the ones with the best stories and history. They clarify well about our Mozambique’s history. Our point of view is a little cultured. The others have a wider view.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as a historical place?
N. C. C.: Of course. The government itself has financed and created a nucleus of the population that cleans the entire island so it does not get dirty.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
N. C. C.: It is an honor to have a heritage like this one on the Island of Mozambique. It is a doing. The island is working on keeping for visit the museum, the statues of Vasco da Gama and Luís de Camões. It's very important.

Did you visit any museums? If so, what is your opinion about them?
N. C. C.: I already entered the museum, in high school. I went to the fortress. The way museums are... there can is no interaction. It has to be as it is. There can be no change because it is historical and we can consider its heritage. People there explain to you step by step.

What do you think about the fortress? (São Sebastião Fortress)
N. C. C.: The most essential is to make construction work and sightseeing tours. It is not good to have a university there, at least for the tourist, I do not know about other people. The government should build another building for the university. The fortress is just fine. Then come the people from Europe to visit and as there is the university they may not accept the people there to walk. Tourists may not be accepted.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
N. C. C.: The island of Mozambique is a very wonderful place but in terms of living, we are living here according to the tides. The island sometimes gets bad for living because the main activity is fishing. There are worse places than the island of Mozambique.

item.title: "The Island is like a mother to me"
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Just as I was saying goodbye to young salesman Henrique, a friend of his stops by. Unlike him, Cláudio was continuing with his studies at Ilha. He had a little time to chat.

Cláudio Lino

Student, 20 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Cláudio Lino: The island means a great place for me to live. Because on the other side what you find is a lot of fighting. The island is like a mother to me.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
C. L.: I do not care about them. I see them and listen to things about the museum and other things related to that. I like them but I’m not interested.

Do you think the island has a lot of communities or just one big one?
C. L.: It has a lot of communities.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
C. L.: Its history. The history that exists on the Island. The traditional dances on the island, Tufo, Modi. That for me is very good. 

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as an historical place?
C. L. : Yes.

Did you visit any museums? If so, what is your opinion about them?
C. L. : Yes, I did. The museum is nice, the things inside are well organized.

What do you think about the fortress? (São Sebastião Fortress)
C. L.: They found old things in the fortress but didn’t leave them there. They didn’t put it in the museum either. They should leave the fortress the way it is.

item.title: Preserving identities
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Fefe Indigg Loy

Craftsman and worked for the government, 60 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Note: Fefe Indigg Loy passed away in 2021. We are deeply grateful for having had the opportunity to meet him, his house and hear the stories he kindly shared.

Interviewer: What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Fefe Indigg Loy: I wish that the Island could improve. By the time I was born, few people lived on the Island. People respected the culture and our identity. Now this doesn’t happen. People say they are from the Island but they don’t know its history. They must have moral values. People don’t respect each other and the elderly. When I was a kid we would go to neighbors’ homes to listen to their stories. And we respected them. We had morals.

Do you know what are UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The UNESCO World Heritage Site (WHS) nomination…?
F. I. L.: Yes, I know.

Do you think the WHS classification changed the way people perceive the Island of Mozambique or the way they interact with it or the Island itself?
F. I. L.: Things didn’t change that much. But UNESCO has a particularity. If the Island is a WHS, not only for the people but also for the material things are disappearing. I surveyed a girl that came from Denmark, and we did a book about the Island. We interviewed the older people of the Island, asked about local traditions, about the houses of the Island, observing the houses with construction styles from the Arabs, and Swahili ones, from Portuguese colonial times. And macuti houses they are few left. Because they are transforming the houses without any care and people are not calling it out. This used to have macuti houses in the macuti part. That is why is called that. But today, things are changing. It is losing its credibility and identity of being macuti. They are putting in zinc and doing brickwork. There are things UNESCO said it was important to defend. But this is only on paper. For example, in front of Escondidinho [hotel], they are putting up pavement, but who is supervising? Where are the responsible people from the town hall or UNESCO? Where are the people defending the Island’s heritage? I don’t agree with the role UNESCO has on the Island. They are not defending the Island’s heritage. We, the sons of the Island, even if we complain about the situation to the people in charge, they don’t listen to us. We have complained so many times that the houses are being destroyed, but nobody listens. I and Hafiz try to do something. Why UNESCO, which has the role to train new people, not only the youth… Youth today does noise, doesn’t have history, is noisy and it is annoying, they don’t have morals. In my time, there used to be Religion and Morals, and we know how to respect others. Today it doesn’t exist and children don’t have morals. Where are we going from here..?

Overall, do you think people are about the conservation of the Island of Mozambique?
F. I. L.: People don’t care, I say that clearly. People here don’t know the importance of having a macuti house. They don’t know what it is to preserve heritage. They don’t seek knowledge. If there are conferences there are all in the stone city part. They are never in the macuti part. Here we have people with a very low level of education. A team should be formed that went from neighbourhood from neighborhood explaining the importance of preserving heritage, of respecting our own identity. So people don’t care.

Did you visit any museums? If so, what is your opinion about them?
F. I. L.: Yes, I visited many times and exhibitions. As I said I’m a goldsmith, a sculptor…The museum that we have here represents more the history of the colonial time than the history of Mozambique. Some children cannot know their history because African history is not represented anywhere. The museum has shown some African history but it is the one from Nampula. We should portray the wars, with photography… To turn this around, a person must be conscious of its history, and that doesn’t happen. There is no African history there…It is very expensive to take people from here to Nampula. And people are not accustomed to moving to a museum. Even the closes ones, don’t go.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
F. I. L.: My heritage is to preserve my own culture with its unique traces, like the cuisine, the language, the way of dressing, and the respect. Today everything is modernized. Occidental style is mixed with African style. More and more people reject their culture to be like somebody else. The Europeans, for example, never had the desire to dress like Africans. They respect their own culture and identity. But we don’t. We diversify our culture. Certain people in government jobs don’t let their children speak macua. They feel embarrassed. These people are denying their own culture. There’s no national identity like that.   

What do you think about the current state of the Fortress of San Sebastian [Fortaleza de São Sebastião]?
F. I. L.: That fortress is not in great aesthetic condition. Or they do a museum, so people could visit it. It is something that attracts tourists to the fortress. Could have something that explains its history. A part could have a laboratory for engineering or anthropology of a University, for example. The money collected from the entrance tickets could then go to restore something else.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Did the WHS classification help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
F. I. L.: Yes. It gives light to the Island. It would be good to have tourists here all the time. It would be good that the people that receive the tourists respected them. They are our guests and should be respected. Should have support and somebody to guide them to the places on the Island. I know people should be educated to guide tourists. It is revenue that can help pave more roads and rehabilitate houses. There should be a House of Culture, to tell stories to the tourists. Because the young people that tell stories to the tourists on the streets are adulterating them. Their own history. The history of the Island of Mozambique is on one side, the macuti side, and the stone city. For one or two dollars they say something to tourists that is not true. The tourists then don’t come to the macuti part. They don’t tell the history and stories correctly. Some books that are edited and I read about the Island of Mozambique this and that… But then I open another book and it says another different thing. They don’t match. The Island is mine and I have to tell the real stories. Each neighborhood has its own history.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
F. I. L.: Regarding that part, I cannot quite respond. I distanced. People don’t know moral values and the idea of being of the monuments. I saw a story on TV, about a kid that was asked “Where did Luís de Camões lose his eye?” and he answered, “In a nightclub”. The tourist that comes here knows that we don’t know the history of our Island. I know how to explain where he lost his eye because I’ve studied and know who he is and how many years he stayed here on the Island of Mozambique. Two years. There is an old door in the house where he used to live. He wrote part of the Os Lusíadas here. They think he was born in a nightclub and they think it was where he lost his eye. There is also a story that a woman tells, on TV, that the origins of Tufo were that the sailors used to play on their pans. I mean. How come? The true origin is from Zanzibar! From Arabic people. Tufo is from our culture here also because Arabic was one of the first to inhabit the Island. So it stayed. And they show this on TV but don’t bother to tell that this is not a correct version of history. It is necessary to align the facts and know our history. You, the Europeans, can tell your history and even ours, things that we can’t do. Because in Europe they investigate. I spent almost my life in Germany. I know and respect Germany. I feel black but also German. The education that I got is different, I’ve learned to respect others. And to respect the things of my country. This is missing in the mentality of the inhabitants of the Island. People don’t take care of public spaces, like gardens. They should know that you can’t take things off the garden. And then children grow up thinking that this is normal behavior. There are monuments on the Island that are not respected. People build sheds around the monument. Where are the people that confiscate this sort of thing? Or they are not there or people don’t respect their orders.

Is there any story or anything else you would like to share?
F. I. L.: I was born in a very religious family, a Muslim family. In my family, there is a mix. My great-grandmother was born were on the Island and so my great-grandfather. So my family started to grow. My grandfather left to do business somewhere else, in the continental area. When I was young my parents were afraid that I would screw up, because I didn’t give importance to religion. To go to school, to assimilate, the child must have a house, a bed to sleep in, eat with cutlery, a Portuguese name… So we used to go to a “regular” school and then were taken to a Portuguese school, to be next to a white person. Because you already had a civilization, know how to behave around other people. Until now, a part of my family is practically Muslim, almost radical. 

Do you feel people are becoming more religious or Muslim, over time?
F. I. L.: We can say that the Island is a bastion of the Muslim community. 99% are Muslim on the Island. Few Catholics and zero Hindus now. I learned the arts with an uncle. He is living in Maputo. He is much respected and respects others as well.

You are a goldsmith and a sculptor. Did you want to learn those arts or it was something imposed on you?
F. I. L.: No, it was my own will. I have a group of goldsmiths on the Island: the Association of Craftsmen and Goldsmiths of the Island of Mozambique (ASSOUIMO). I’m the president. I also paint. I like art because it is the only way to express our feelings. We inspire ourselves and create.

There should be a House of Culture, to tell stories to the tourists. Because the young people that tell stories to the tourists on the streets are adulterating them. Their own history.

item.title: The "Informal" Tour-guide
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
It is the golden hour. The sun is slowly descending into the Indian Ocean. Sellers at the stands are starting to put away their materials, preparing everything for tomorrow. We are at the pier, in Stone Town, watching the sun, the colour palette of the sky, and the people. I'm approached by Capitãozito, a nickname translating to "little captain", asking if I would like to go on a tour with him. He didn't share what was his real name.

Capitãozito

Informal tour guide, 21 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: You know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The WHS classification…?
Capitãozito: I know what UNESCO is. The rest not really.

What do you think about the impact of UNESCO on the Island?
C.: It is a company that trains tourist guides. Some historical monuments are here. They trained some guides that now have UNESCO badges. Like they are official guides.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
C.: Yes. The houses were abandoned and now they are restored. The houses were bought, and when they do, they make people restore them. People now see the roads cleaned.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Did the World Heritage Site nomination help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors..?
C.: Some people don’t like it, but some do.

Are there a lot of guides like you?
C.: Yes. We find people on the streets and ask if they want a tour of the Island. We take the tourists on boat tours to the other islands. I’m not officially connected to anything, no company.

Do you feel connected to some monument on the Island of Mozambique?
C.: The fortress doesn’t have anything in there. It only has history and that means a lot to me. The Island is divided into two parts, the macuti part, and the stone part, the city of Stone. The stones used to make the fortress came from the macuti part. The Portuguese constructed it. To make their castle.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as a historical place?
C.: Some people don’t care, most of them. Only a few care about that.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
C.: The fortress, its history. I feel connected to traditional clothes also.

As a guide, do you show the immaterial side of heritage to the tourists?
C.: Yes, I do. I show the capulana [traditional fabric for clothing], the mussiro, and the local dances. There is a dance that is called Tufo, only for women. When they dance it they put on the mussiro [sort of white “make-up” that covers the all face].

Did you visit any museums? If so, what is your opinion about them?
C.: Yes, they are nice. They have old things and beads. There is the navy museum and the religious art museum. I’m happy with what exists.

What do you think of the current state of the Fortress of San Sebastian?
C.: There used to be things there that were taken to the museum. I like to see it like this, empty. When a person goes there it must notice that it is a fortress, a military force. One should keep the fortress intact. They shouldn’t have things to the fortress. The museum, for example, closes at 16h30. If tourist appears after that, they stay outside, because it is already closed. But in the fortress, they can come in after that. I like that people can enter the fortress at all times.

item.title: Kadırga Sports Club: As a Community Identity & Memory Keeper
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
00.13- NURCAN: Did your childhood also pass here?

PİRHAN BEY: Yes, we were always together here. But let me tell you how old I am, I came when I was 6-7 years old.

MURAT: Did you play in the same team, sir?

PİRHAN BEY: No.

MURAT: You were not in the same generation.

AYHAN BEY: Of course, we used to play together in our childhood. But we played football together here... MURAT: Because there are many who played together in Kadırga.

PİRHAN BEY: Yes, many.

-00.35- NURCAN: But how far back does the history of this sports club go?

AYHAN BEY: It was founded in 1952.

MURAT: There is an old captain of Galatasaray, Mehmet Abi. He often comes here. He may come soon. ?: Look at the pictures from 2002, all the national players came out of here.

NURCAN: Let's see, yes.

AYHAN BEY: For example, one of them made a jersey for Beşiktaş on their 100th anniversary, and the names of all the footballers who came and went are written on it. There are about 19 from Kadırga Sports Club. From those years, a long time ago.

-01.08- NURCAN: Very interesting. So, there seems to be a connected tradition that has been established here for a very long time.

PİRHAN BEY: 80% of those who come here always sit outside. They come from over there, I come from Yedikule. There are those who come from Bakırköy, from Avcılar. But what?

AYHAN BEY: Especially today, it gets very crowded.

PİRHAN BEY: I'm a taxi driver, I put my family in the car and came here. It's like this place will save me. I got out, parked. I came to Kadırga with the car.

NURCAN: Interesting. So, there is some kind of emotional attachment here.

AYHAN BEY: Of course, of course. For example, Kadırga Sports Club, which is loved and respected, is like the Real Madrid amateur sports club. We can say that in that way.

-01.58- NURCAN: But it doesn't just seem like a sports club to me, there is something else here, like an atmosphere.

AYHAN BEY: Yes, there is everything.

NURCAN: Is it in the park here?

MURAT: Here, in front of our school, ma'am.

NURCAN: Oh, on the street.

PİRHAN BEY: Hot food...

MURAT: On the sidewalk.

AYHAN BEY: That Imren Restaurant across the street really makes good food. They don't work during Ramadan. We pay them monthly and they make food for us. For example, it was 4000 liras before. We give 4000 lira, and we give food to 200 people every night.

NURCAN: Every night?

PİRHAN BEY: Every night, every night.

MURAT: Everyone in the neighborhood also comes, ma'am.

NURCAN: Oh, so you are doing it as a club again.

PİRHAN BEY: Of course, as a club. But what are you saying? You say, "I will pay for tonight's dinner, ma'am."

NURCAN: I understand.

MURAT: They make a list.

PİRHAN BEY: They ask, "How many people will come? 15 people, 10 people, 5 people." They prepare a table for you. Whoever comes by the road.

item.title: The History of Sultanahmet Köftecisi Restaurant and Its Founder￼
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
BEGÜM: As far as we know, was your great-grandfather the one who opened this place and was the concept his own?

Mr. İsmail Timur: Well, yes. Allow me to introduce myself, I am İsmail Timur Tezçakın, the fourth proprietor of the Historic Sultanahmet Köfteci Restaurant. My brothers and I currently run the business. I serve as one of the representatives. Our founder was Mehmet Seracettin Tezçakın, who is my great-grandfather. We are now in the fourth generation and I hope it will continue to the fifth.

BEGÜM: Did he establish the famous Sultanahmet Köfteci restaurant first?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, my great-grandfather began working at a printing house in the 1890s to  early 1900s. He wanted to open a food shop and chose meatballs as his main dish. Although the establishment actually dates back to the 1914s, official records indicate the 1920s as the official establishment year.

NURCAN: Did you say the 1914s?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: He first attempted in the 1910s, but we think so because the insurance documents and documents we have are from 1920. My grandfather doesn't remember either. My grandfather was born in 1927. But in 1920, there was such a date based on the documents we have. We are now going to the 103rd year.

BEGÜM: So, was there a meatball shop here before?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, i don’t know if you know, the Sultanahmet was the center of Istanbul. Everything was Sultanahmet and everywhere was Sultanahmet. All newspapers, furnishings, and clothing centers were in Sultanahmet and its surroundings. They call it inside the wall. It was the center of Istanbul. But somehow here was touristic. I guess it also was touristic back in those times. It used to be a place where people lived, but not now. Currently touristy. The name of the road is divan(sultan) road, it is called the road to the palace.

BEGÜM: How would you describe the changes and evolution of the place over the past 100 years? What was it like before and what is it like now?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: I've been coming here since I was little in my own life. I actually started working when I was 13-14 years old. I was both studying and working. In fact, my father provided me the first vacation money by working here. Yes, I have lived freely. When I was 14-15 years old, I used to travel alone to places like Bodrum for vacation. I would work and save money, rather than relying on financial support from my father. If we talk about the transformation of this place, the main change I witnessed was the difference in the customer profile. Because celebrities used to come here. Many of you have already viewed the photos inside the shop, they frequently came here. But when this place is opened to pedestrians and closed to cars, those celebrities stopped coming because they can't come. How they would come? So I understand them too. Bülent Ersoy used to come here in his car once a week, every two weeks, and take his package and go home. I remember those times, but day by day this place started to become more touristic. It started to host more tourists. As it started to host more tourists, the type of customer changed. Currently, we serve 30% of domestic customers and 70% of foreign customers. We have remained the same, only the type of customers visiting us has evolved. Our operations and service quality remain the same.

NURCAN: Do visitors come here intentionally, as tourists?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: First-time tourists in Istanbul often come here after hearing about it from a friend. Those who come a second time definitely try it out because we have done what we were trying to do. We have established trust here. People can eat and leave safely without any harm to their stomach, and we can bid farewell to our guests without any hidden costs, just as the prices appear. This trust has been instilled. We continue this way with trust and flavor.

BEGÜM: Do you have any connection with Inegöl, considering you said there was never a kebab restaurant here before?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, my great-grandfather's father was from East Turkistan. He comes from Kashgar, a region currently under Chinese oppression. The meatball he first made was similar to the meatballs from that region. They still use the same recipe, but the format has changed. Previously, with only 30-40 customers per day, the meatballs were served on skewers. As customer numbers increased, the format was changed to individual servings. The recipe he brought is traditional and he brought it from there to here. I later met with Coskun Aral and he said that your meatballs reminded him of the meatballs from there. So, it seems that my great-grandfather's father brought a traditional dish from there to here.

NURCAN: Do they come directly from there or are they from there?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: His grandfather's father came here as a child by himself. At that time, he was setting out for the pilgrimage. At that time, the pilgrimage route seems to have passed through Istanbul, there was something like that. When you leave China, there is transit through Istanbul, not directly to Arabia. Then the First World War breaks out in Istanbul and he stays here. After staying here, he begins to grow his life and settle down.

NURCAN: Did he start by opening the shop?

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: No, as I said earlier, he starts by working in printing presses. This place used to be the center of journalism and printing. He starts working there and then he wants to open his own shop and chooses to sell meatballs. He rents the front of a coal shop and sells meatballs in front while coal is sold at the back. The business starts. Not here, but follow this road, there's the Yerebatan Cistern which has a million stones. The shops were in front of that million stones. I don't remember. It was expropriated later. The million stones were inside the shops. For example, they used to lower baskets into the Yerebatan Cistern like a refrigerator so that perishable food items like meat wouldn't spoil because it was cold and humid. He rented the front of a coal shop that supplies coal to homes and businesses.

NURCAN: So it might have been the location where the current sidewalk is.

İSMAİL TİMUR BEY: Yes, it was the location of that sidewalk. It can also be seen in the old photos, even inside the store.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Msikiti wa Ijumaa wa Malindi umejengwa katika mwaka wa 1831 na watu wa ukoo wa Mafazi na mmoja kati ya wanafamilia alitoa kipande cha ardhi cha Miafuni kiwe pesa zinazotokana na wakati huo ziusimamie Msikiti akijulikana kwa jina la Mwinyi Sheikh bin Haji Omar al-Mutafi

The Malindi Friday Mosque was built in 1831 by members of the Mafazi clan. One of the family members was given a piece of land in Miafuni so that the money generated at that time should be used to manage the Mosque known as Mwinyi Sheikh bin Haji Omar al-Mutafi.

Msikiti huu ulikuwa ukisaliwa na wingi wa waumini katika Mji Mkongwe. Sheikh Muhydin al Shaikh bin Abdalla Qahtani ambaye nishamuelezea katika makala zangu kabla ni mmoja wa masheikhe ambao aliotoa mchango mkubwa wa dini visiwani na kuwasomesha wengi kati ya waliokuwa maulamaa wakubwa na kutegemewa Zanzibar wakiwa kina Sheikh Ahmad bin Salmin,  Sheikh Shauri bin Haji Al-Shirazy wa Donge, Sheikh Abdul Azi bin Al-Amawy, Sheikh Suleymna Hayatt akiwa mhindi Khoja, Sheikh Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Mlomry, Sheikh Hassan bin Yussuf Mngazija, Sheikh Ahmad bin Salmin As-Sabahy, Sheikh Fadhil bin Ali Mngazija. Sheikh Muhydin ndio aliokuja akaupanua Msikiti wa Ijumaa wa Malindi kwa msada wa Mfalme Sayyid bin Said na darsa zake baadhi akizisomesha hapo Msikiti wa Ijumaa wa Malindi.

item.title: Ma Bronze Age Boat Project
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Bronze Age Boat project was inspired by Umm an-Nar, the 4000-year-old archaeological site found near the Abu Dhabi airport linked with the early Arabian shipping routes. The middle-east has, throughout history, been a crossroads of civilizations. Trade, culture and human development have emerged, flourished and converged in the region facilitated by an expansive maritime tradition that linked the Arabian Gulf to Asia, Africa and Europe as reflected in the rich heritage and cultural landscapes of this cultural junction.

Despite this, little is known about the construction and use of the ships that enabled long-distance oceanic travel. This project built an 8-meter experimental archaeological reconstruction of a merchant vessel that sailed to and from Magan (the ancient name for the UAE and Oman) in the Bronze Age.

Using iconography, historiography, ethnographic data and archaeological information, the project tests the evidence for technologies, tools, construction methodologies and materials through the construction of a full-sized hypothetical model boat involving shipbuilding expertise that still exists in the region of the Gulf and the Indian Ocean. The reconstruction produced a composite craft, built of reed, wood, date-palm and bitumen components.

This research and educational project was developed by DHAKIRA – Center for Heritage Studies in the UAE as a collaboration between Zayed University and New York University Abu Dhabi. The project was generously funded by the Zayed University Research Fund and the NYUAD Research Enhancement Fund.
