item.title: The Islamic Town
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Perfectly preserved in the archaeological record of Sīnīya Island, the ruins of a classical Islamic town paint a vivid picture of a complex settlement hierarchy, economic system, and international relations that flourished between the fourteenth and eighteenth centuries.

The archaeological record of Sīnīya Island remarkably preserves an entire classical Islamic town within its landscape. It is argued that the period of highest occupation of the Islamic town appears to have been between the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, when Old Umm al-Quwain 1, was constructed, and between the eighteenth and early nineteenth century when the settlement relocated to Old Umm al-Quwain 2. In 1820, the British destroyed the town, after which it was rebuilt as the Old Umm al-Quwain 3, which is the modern city of the same name. As of now, most material culture of the town has been excavated around Old Umm al-Quwain 2 in the southwest region of the island which is under extensive excavation. 

The town provides an exceptional record of hierarchical settlement. It is likely assumed that the lime kilns discovered at some of the contemporary survey sites produced building materials for the stone town. Other survey sites from the same period consisted of surface pottery fragments that may have originated from palm-frond villages involved in fishing the lagoon. The settlement seems to have had a central stone town that was focused on pearl fishing and international trade, with subsidiary settlements and workshops that produced lime or supplied fish to the town.

It also boasts several notable architectural features, including graves, cairns, and shell middens. Islamic graves are individual inhumation burials with stones set at the head and feet, while cairns are sub-circular stone features that may represent burials or fishing markers. Additionally, circular stone-lined shafts, and shell middens, were also discovered surrounded by ash and shell. These features provide insights into the practices and construction methods of the Islamic period and require further research surveys for a more comprehensive understanding.

Archaeological material cultures such as coins, pottery, and artifacts provide significant insight into the functioning of the Islamic town too. The seventy-four coins found in and around the town offer valuable information on the economy and trade of the time, mainly Iranian civic series dating between the fourteenth and eighteenth centuries issued under the Qāsimī confederation. A few sherds of possibly late pre-Islamic pottery discovered nearby offer insight into the cultural exchange and the history of the region. Although the hypothetical identification requires further study. Additionally, the stone net weights found at the late Islamic town provide evidence of the significance of maritime industries and the role of fishing in the local economy.

Civilization on the island likely underwent many changes as Islam flourished throughout the region including several diverse ethnic groups merging into a new, unified civilization under the Islamic state, the formation of a more centralized political system and access to trade networks that connected the region to the wider Islamic world. Therefore, the cultural significance of the Islamic Town of Sīnīya Island is an example of the site’s Outstanding Universal Value since it relates to Criterion 5 of UNESCO’s list of criteria for World Heritage, as an example of a traditional settlement which is representative of Islamic culture and human interactions with the environment of the Islamic empire.

References

Potts, Daniel T. In The Land of the Emirates: The Archaeology and History of UAE, 2012, pp. 138-139, 142–59.

Power, Timothy, et al. “Archaeological Survey of Sīnīya Island, Umm Al-Quwain.” Études et Travaux, no. 35, Dec. 2022, pp. 135–62, https://doi.org/10.12775/etudtrav.35.007.

item.title: The Sultan’s Palace and Royal Cemetery
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Also known as the Beit-el-Sahel, the Sultan’s Palace and the adjacent Royal Cemetery constitute one of the most important historical sites in Zanzibar, having been the place of residence and later burial of the family of Sultan Seyyid Said.

Sultan Seyyid Said was the ruler of a vast and prosperous empire in the nineteenth century (1870-1888), stretching from Oman to the Mozambican borders. He established his base in Unguja, the main island of the Zanzibar archipelago, benefitting from the island’s privileged location within the network of trade in the Indian Ocean, and leading a major economic transformation project that is imprinted on the many structures that came into existence during his time.

The Sultan built the Beit-el-Sahel on the waterfront to be his primary residence after his first visit to the island in 1828. The large three-storey rectangular building was finished in the 1840s, displaying a traditional Omani form with a central courtyard and small rectangular windows. The palace’s windows and balconies overlooked the town's harbor, representing the duality of Omani expressions of power and prestige through military presence at the nearby Gereza (The Old Fort) and an economic expression of material wealth at the Sultan’s Palace.

The palace has undergone several modifications throughout its history. It was partially destroyed during the Anglo-Zanzibar war in 1896 and later reconstructions added an additional tower to the palace’s roof. Subsequent Sultans of Zanzibar continued to use the palace as a place of residence until 1964, including Seyyid Khalifa bin Harub (1911–1960), who renovated the building’s façade and created a new garden. Most of these sultans and their families are buried in the cemetery adjacent to the Palace, including Sultan Seyyid Said and his sons Khaled, Barghash, and Khalifa. 

The Sultan’s Palace and the Royal Cemetery are today open to the public as a museum, displaying pieces of furniture, paintings and other artifacts from Zanzibar’s pre-revolutionary period, commemorating the period of the British Protectorate and the achievements of the Arab Sultans that once walked through the hallways of the Palace.

The significance of the Sultan’s Palace and the Royal Cemetery in the context of the larger heritage site of Stone Town illustrates the sites’ outstanding universal value as a manifestations of the intense maritime activity between Asia and Africa that led to the rise of Zanzibar as a major and prosperous port city in the Indian Ocean, with Sultan Seyyid Seid being the motor behind this economic reformation. This responds directly to UNESCO’s Criterion III for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Sultan’s Palace and the Royal Cemetery, then, contribute with the Stone Town’s complex heritage narrative, made up of stories of encounters and exchanges that continue to be told by the walls, balconies, and windows of this and the many structures that still stand on this World Heritage Site.

Bibliography & Further Reading

Colin Breen, Wes Forsythe & Daniel Rhodes. “A Maritime Archaeological Survey of Stone Town, Zanzibar”.  International Journal of Nautical Archaeology (45)1, (2016):191-199, DOI: 10.1111/1095-9270.12143 

Folkers, Antoni. “Early Modern African Architecture. The House of Wonders Revisited.” Docomomo Journal, no. 48 (2013): 20–29. https://doi.org/10.52200/48.a.fkxy01xv.

Hoyle, Brian. “Urban Waterfront Revitalization in Developing Countries: The Example of Zanzibar's Stone Town.” The Geographical Journal 168, no. 2 (2002): 141–62. https://doi.org/10.1111/1475-4959.00044. 

Sheriff, Abdul. “Zanzibar Old Town.” Essay. In The Swahili World, edited by Stephanie Wynne-Jones and Adria Jean LaViolette, 529–40. London: Routledge, 2017. https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315691459-46/zanzibar-old-town-abdul-sheriff

UNESCO. “WHC Nomination Documentation: The Stone Town of Zanzibar.” (2000). https://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/173rev.pdf.

Wilkinson, Joe. "Out and about in Zanzibar." Historian (134) (2017): 36-39. http://proxy.library.nyu.edu/login?qurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.proquest.com%2Fscholarly-journals%2Fout-about-zanzibar%2Fdocview%2F1927463624%2Fse-2%3Faccountid%3D12768.

item.title: The Aga Khan Mosque
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Also known as the Jamat Khan or Ismaili Jamatkhana, the Aga Khan Mosque stands today as a testimony of the multicultural landscape that formed over the centuries at the Stone Town, resulting in a complex sociocultural fabric that makes up this living heritage site today.

The Aga Khan Mosque was built between 1905 and 1907 by the Ismaili community in Stone Town, a religious group that had grown exponentially since Zanzibar’s economic expansion in the nineteenth century. The Nizari Isma'lli Khohas, or Ismailis, are a sub-sect of Shia muslims who believe that the Imam, or the successor of the Prophet, is always present in the world and provides its diving guidance to his followers. While they are found today throughout the Middle East, Syria, Iraq, and Egypt, the early Ismaili communities were composed of converted hindus from North-Western India who migrated to East Africa in the 1800s looking for better life opportunities.

The economic bonanza of nineteenth-century Zanzibar and the increase in trading activity with India resulted attractive for the migrants, who, by the 1870s, had surpassed the 700 families already established on the island. Over time, the Ismaili communities constructed clusters of residential houses and religious buildings around Zanzibar, resulting in the creation of the iconic Aga Khan Mosque, the first Jamatkhana to be built in the entire East African Region.

This imposing architectural work features a great hall with massive stone pillars and carved wooden capitals.  The building’s carved wooden Gujarati-style entrance doors echo the style of other architectural works around the Stone Town such as the Old Dispensary, a space that today hosts the the Aga Khan Cultural Centre. Besides embodying the Stone Town’s diverse cultural and religious narrative through its symbolic meaning, this structure serves as a tangible manifestation of the cultural fusion that took place throughout the history of this port city.

The significance of the Aga Khan Mosque in the context of the larger heritage site of Stone Town illustrates the building's outstanding universal value as a manifestation of cultural fusion and harmonization, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion II for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Aga Khan Mosque, then, tells stories of encounters and transformations that constitute the backbone of the Stone Town’s complex heritage narrative, stories that continue to be told by the walls of this and many structures that still stand on this living World Heritage Site.

Bibliography & Further Reading

Aga Khan Mosque (Zanzibar, Tanzania). Archnet. (n.d.). https://www.archnet.org/sites/9206

Schacht, Joseph. “Notes on Islam in East Africa.” Studia Islamica, no. 23 (1965): 91–136. https://doi.org/10.2307/1595256. 

UNESCO. “WHC Nomination Documentation: The Stone Town of Zanzibar.” (2000). https://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/173rev.pdf.

Walji, Shirin Remtulla. "A History Of The Ismaili Community In Tanzania." (1974). Order No. 7418963, The University of Wisconsin - Madison. http://proxy.library.nyu.edu/login?qurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.proquest.com%2Fdissertations-theses%2Fhistory-ismaili-community-tanzania%2Fdocview%2F288086557%2Fse-2%3Faccountid%3D12768.

item.title: Interior Design of Medusa: The Enchanting Journey of Transforming Objects into Lampshades￼
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Handan Hanım: I have always loved old lifestyles. I have a special interest in everything I see, but I started getting into auctions. I started following online auctions during the pandemic and started collecting things from there. I thought, since I already had some things, maybe I could turn them into lamps. For example, I would see a vase or a water pitcher and think about turning them into lighting fixtures. That's how the story began. It started with lighting fixtures. I started working on each one by hand, putting a charm on each one and decorating them with precious stones. Then I wanted to add candles to them. We had these "Murano" bowls in our old houses, which we know from our childhood. I find glass objects or light shows very captivating. You have to see it when the sun hits them. Those lights have always fascinated me. I came up with the idea of making candles out of them. And then, I started doing other things…

01.20 - Nurcan Yalman: Glass is also impressive...

Handan Hanım: Yes, glass is of course... We also changed them one by one. They also have a way of reflecting on the ground, I love it. They have a great effect, like in churches.

01.30 - Nurcan Yalman: I was telling my friends about it, showing them La Sargrada Familia and its...

Handan Hanım: Isn't it incredible? It really is... And then we got into the topic of pillows. Even while making pillows, we turned towards decorating their edges. Now, for example, the idea of making pillows out of scarves came up. I took some things that my mother kept hidden away, like headscarves and other things that people give as gifts, or bring from the village and leave aside. I wanted to make use of them. Then I got into kaftans. How the idea of kaftans came up... Sometimes I don't even understand how it came up.

02.15 - Nurcan Yalman: Are the kaftans original?

Handan Hanım: They're very old. My brother bought it. It's a very old kaftan. I don't really know its story or how old it is exactly. But I do know that it's very old, of course. Since it arrived, I haven't moved it from its place except to clean it. It's been there all along, with its own character.

02.35 - Nurcan Yalman: But it's interesting, isn't it?

Handan Hanım: Maybe we should ask someone who remembers well. There are professionals in this business, actually. What I do is, I buy some fabrics from the covered bazaar and decorate each of them with handmade details. Apart from that, there is also a set of Michelangelo's two-person ceramic dinnerware decorated with scribbles, and so on. It's always like this, and sometimes I surprise myself. There is a constant desire to create and produce.

03.25 - Nurcan Yalman: Because you are changing. As you change, there are other inspirations. And you want to turn them into products.

Handan Hanım: The region feeds this. I mean, it's exactly me, old and new. Now it's an old building, but with a new understanding. By preserving the old while adapting to the new system, it can serve as a service, food, etc. I have this at my home too, always bringing the old and the new together. I really love this. I think it's important to always respect the old. There are truly valuable things there, places where we need to nourish and learn from. But we also need to incorporate the new. We cannot just stick to the old unfortunately.

item.title: Tourism viewed by a Moz. Islander
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Zeina

Unemployed, 22 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Zeina: I like the Island because it’s safe, it has no problems.

Do you know what is UNESCO and its role regarding the Island of Mozambique? The World Heritage Site (WHS) status…?
Z.: No. But I know it has some special classification.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time?
Z.: Yes, it has changed. They are making some construction work for people to live in. And they are doing some things also in the fortress, and people have jobs with this. I haven’t seen the Island like this yet. It’s been changing for the best.

What do you think about the coming of foreigners to the Island? Does the WHS nomination help boost tourism or the coming of foreign investigators and investors?
Z.: Tourists are coming more. The Island is doing very well. The tourist comes and he is happy that he can buy things, buy some beers… And we make some money with this. We can make money without tourists, but it is not the same. It is good that they come.

Did you visit any of the museums on the Island of Mozambique? If so, what is your opinion about them
Z.: Yes, I did. It has many things from the past, from our grandfather’s times. It has things about the history of the Island.

Overall, do people care about the conservation of the Island as a historical place?
Z.: No. They don’t care.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
Z.: It’s a song. The songs that I sing here on the Island and that I dance, I play and I like it. Not traditional songs, but ones that I like.

Is there any story or anything you would like to share?
Z.: I’m living here with my family, with my uncle and sister. My mom already died. I’m living in this world. I play with my children now. I don’t have any more stories to share.

item.title: More than fishing
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
We met at Associação Ilha de Moçambique. Cassimo Abdurremane was eager to share his stories as an inhabitant of the Island but also discuss about the hardships of the fishermen. After the conversation at the Associação's office, we took off to the nearby Fishermen Beach where he guided me through the mix of sand and fishing nets.

Cassimo Abdurremane

President of the Fishermen Association of the Island of Mozambique, 60 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

Interviewer: About his background and the Fishermen’s Association:
Cassimo Abdurremane: I was born on the Island. I went to school here. Then I went to the military and also after the independence, on the 25th of April 1975. Then I was my own boss. From the bottom of my heart, I like to live here on the Island. But where did I get my willpower to help the fishing community? 20 years ago, I used to go to the Island to buy fish. The boats have like 4 or 5 bosses. For example, one owns a little of the fishing net, Antony has the engine, José has the boat...They do partnerships. So the fisherman was always under pressure. Those bosses stay inshore. There is a group of fishermen that goes fishing. And they fish by the box, which one with 30 Kilos maximum. Sometimes they catch 300 kilos of fish, 10 boxes. But other times they return with only one fish, named the 1 metical [Mozambican currency], despite catching the 10 boxes. So he goes fishing very early in the morning, leaves his children at home, has rent to pay…returns very late only to return with one fish, for 1 metical, because all the other fish stays for the bosses they fight between them for it. Then these bosses would create debt between the sellers because the bosses didn’t have money to buy fuel…So life is very hard for fishermen. So I started feeling for the fishermen. I approached them and said, “What if we formed an association?”. But the bosses were distrustful about this. But I insisted. And I managed to gather some people. The bosses realized that I was doing something right.

I created the Fishermen Association of the Island of Mozambique which searches for alternatives for fishermen’s work and also has the role to defend nature and fauna. Sometimes the fishermen's community wants immediate results. But we need to apply for funding for this and that organization. That process takes time. The fishermen don’t have the patience to wait. They just ask “I want 20 meters of fishing net”. But that doesn’t work like this. But with requests like this, our association loses credibility. We do credit rotations. The association receives a certain fund and to choose who will receive it, we do a selection. It is indeed hard, especially in African associations, to ask the members to pay for their membership quotas. But it is with quotas that we can make something to make a change. They ask us for things but they don’t give back anything. But ok. We do a rotation credit. We give them the material and do a credit, which they have to pay X per month. There was a time that the Island suffered a lot from cyclones. Almost every year we have cyclones. But some years are worse. We had a partnership with OIKOS, in the years 2007-2008. That time I wasn’t here. We had elections for the president of the association, and the man that won the election didn’t quite understand the fisherman. I lived 11 years in Pemba. So when I returned, I found the association sort of abandoned. When I left we had a project with an Italian organization, that would give us 10 boats and it was already authorized with all the equipment. But we had bad weather and all the boats were destroyed. So my fight now is to try to do the maximum to restore the boats we used to have. Because many people lost their jobs because of the boats, and the destruction. Restore things little by little.

Here on the Island, we don’t have a store that sells fishing materials. The philosophy of the association is to open a store that can serve its member’s needs. Right now I can talk about the association of the fisherman as the main association related to fishing activities because the fishermen believed in what we did. We had the idea to have a freezing arc to store the fish either for the fisherman or for the local people. We also have an idea to have an ice factory because some boats can go to the sea for about 2 or 3 days. But since they don’t have the resources to freeze the fish they don’t go on those fishing trips because they will lose the fish. We can consider that the association is conscious and we search for alternatives for the development of the fisherman because he is limited. They only know when and where to fish. It needs to exist training of the fishermen, needs to exist experience exchange, not only within the country but also from around the world. We must see if we can leave artisanal fishing. This type of fishing just supports a little family, it doesn’t develop. Around 60% to 70% of people fish. Fishing is the main economical activity on the island but it also exists in great amounts around the country. But since the Island doesn’t have local agriculture, the main activity is fishing. The day fishing disappears, the trade will be low, and the movements at the bank will also be low. The main focus of life is fishing.

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
C. A.: It means a lot of things. The Island is the first capital of this county. Second, the Island is a place where the local people are very hospitable. Because of religion. Around 70% to 80% of people on the Island are Muslim. We learned how to welcome visitors. It is not easy. We are people of peace. During the 16 years [of the civil war] people come to Island as refugees. And the fishermen's community as well. I have a project in mind that I would like one day a neighbourhood for the fishermen to be created, in the continental area. Because the fishermen don’t have their own home, here on the Island. The fishermen are not local here, it is an immigrant. In the old day, when a certain person taught the fishermen how to catch fish in a motor boat, they didn’t need to go 60 miles into the ocean to fish. The fish was all here, near the shore. But now, given the amount of people fishing, from other places also, they must go 30-50 miles offshore. They return around 8 pm. And sometimes without any fish. If we manage to find a partner that would help us figure this out, the help would be welcomed. We used to have around 150 boats. Now we just have around 40-50 boats. And more are disappearing. When the engine malfunctions it is very hard to get a new one or to fix it. A new engine is 300000 meticais, around 4,500 euros. And the bosses ask for example 40 meticais to use the engine. But they go fishing without GPS, or some sort of orientation device. But while they are searching for fish, the engine keeps running, it doesn’t stop. So it would be nice to empower the fishermen with a probe, for example, to reduce the engine work effort.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time, especially after the World Heritage nomination?
C. A.: We have to thank UNESCO, despite things did not go as planned. UNESCO had 50 projects for the Island of Mozambique. In general. But it didn’t happen. The “why’s” are questionable. From 91 to today, the Island has changed slowly. For example, our road used to have many holes, and now the main road is fixed. The people can walk. The houses are in the hands of foreigners and they fix the houses. The islanders that owned the houses didn’t have the financial conditions to take care of them. So they sold the houses to foreigners that rehabilitate them. Today we are to be congratulated because the Island is doing better, and is developing. The next generation is indeed the one that is going to benefit from this.

Did you visit any of the Island’s museums?
C. A.: The things that the museum had in the ’70s, during my time, were better than today. The majority of things were reallocated by the government to the Museum of Maputo. With the appearance of the Arqueonautas and everything… and some other people that got permits, nobody knows how they got here, and took all the coins. So it is not fun going to the museum. We could also create a museum with a religious theme. But we don’t have the habit to make museums. A lot of things went missing, and now we are like this.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
C. A.: It is part of myself. We all are heritage. Everyone on the Island is a heritage, is a museum. My parents passed their heritage to me. I know the Island from what was before and what it is now. And it is all heritage. And heritage is also what I am doing. Without fishing there is no life in the Island of Mozambique. We are fighting to improve fishing activity.

item.title: Tour Guide's Choice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Childhood memories evoked by the smell of spices

Kübra Demir-Professional Tour Guide

"....We are currently in front of the Egyptian Bazaar (Mısır Çarşısı). The Egyptian Bazaar is one of Istanbul's oldest and largest bazaars. Both local and foreign tourists, as well as our citizens, come here for shopping. They usually come here for spice shopping and for buying Turkish delights. The importance of the Egyptian Bazaar to me is that when I was a child, my mother and grandmother used to come here with me and buy various spices for holiday meals, family gatherings, and Sunday breakfasts. I have a feeling that I can never forget when I smell that scent every time I enter here. It is because it is very crowded, my grandmother used to hold my hand tightly just so that I would not get lost. Every time I enter here and smell that scent, I remember her..."

item.title: The Persian Baths of Kidichi
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Located approximately 4 km north-east of Stone Town, the Persian Baths of Kidichi commemorate the history of Zanzibar and of those who have ruled the island over the centuries.

Sultan Seyyid Said was the ruler of a vast and prosperous empire in the nineteenth century (1870-1888), stretching from Oman to the Mozambican borders. He established his base in Unguja, the main island of the Zanzibar archipelago, benefitting from the island’s privileged location within the network of trade in the Indian Ocean, and leading a major economic transformation project that is imprinted on the many structures that came into existence during his time. He is known to have married three times during his lifetime, the third of these weddings taking place around the 1840s with a Persian royal named Shihrazad bint Arish Miraz ibn Mohammed Shah.

Contemporary sources refer to Shihrazad as an “extravagant” woman who continued to wear Persian clothing and refused to adopt some of the Omani traditions, such as wearing a veil. There is evidence that the Kidichi baths are related to her, however, it is not clear whether Seyyid or Shihrazad commissioned them. There are records, however, of Persian craftsmen being brought to Zanzibar especially to decorate the baths, contributing with the complex architectural narratives embedded into the many structures around the Stone Town.

The baths are formed by a long corridor with the toilets at one end and a series of rooms ending in the hot bath at the other end. The heating was provided by an external furnace that would have been operated by slaves. The decoration features unique plasterwork with typical Persian representations of foliage and birds, fine carvings, and broad stone seats. The imagery represented around the baths is typical of Qajar art and constitutes a symbolic allusion to Paradise.

The Kidichi baths are only one example of the Persian-style baths that can be found around Stone Town, since approximately eight bath complexes were built during the economic bonanza of the nineteenth century in Zanzibar. One of these structures is the Hamamni bath complex, which is the largest and best preserved in Zanzibar and was built by Seyyid Barghash for public use between 1870 and 1888. The figure of Shihrazad, then, is associated with the introduction of the fashion for Persian bathing to the Arab elite in Zanzibar.

The significance of the Persian Baths in the context of the larger heritage site of Stone Town illustrates the sites’ outstanding universal value as a manifestation of the intense maritime activity between Asia and Africa that led to the rise of Zanzibar as a major and prosperous port city in the Indian Ocean. The resulting economic bonanza translated into architectural structures built by and for the rulers of the island and that survive today as witnesses of Zanzibar’s apogee. The importance of these sites responds directly to UNESCO’s Criterion III for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Persian Baths, then, reinforce Stone Town’s complex heritage narrative, made up of stories of encounters and exchanges that continue to be told by the walls, balconies, and windows of this and the many structures that still stand at this living World Heritage Site.

item.title: The Malindi Bamnara Mosque
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Not only is the Malindi Bamnara Mosque one of the most important architectural works that make up the cityscape at Zanzibar’s Stone Town, but it is also the oldest mosque oft this living World Heritage Site.

Seventeenth-century Stone Town was a traditional Swahili village conformed by numerous clans of immigrants from around the African continent and the Indian Ocean, including the Alawi from Yemen, the Malindi from the Kenyan coast, and the Benadir from Somalia. This was the context in which the Malindi Bamnara Mosque was built in 1834 by  Muhammad b. Abdulkadir al-Mansaby, a wealthy Arab merchant in Zanzibar and a member of the Benadir clan. It is believed that an older mosque had previously stood on the site where the new one was built in the 1830s. As a tribute to al-Mansaby, his remains were buried in front of the mosque’s mihrab. 

The mosque was enlarged in 1841 and restored in 1890 by the Omani Sultan Seyyid Ali bin Said. The most salient element of this architectural work is its unique conical minaret, which is one of the only five mosques that have this feature along the Swahili coast. The stylistic contrast that the minaret introduces to the cityscape of the Stone Town tells a story of centuries of cultural exchanges that remain imprinted on the architecture around the site, bringing different historic periods and buildings into a dynamic and multilayered dialogue.

The significance of the Malindi Bamnara Mosque in the context of the larger heritage site of Stone Town illustrates the building's outstanding universal value as a manifestation of cultural fusion and harmonization, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion II for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Malindi Bamnara Mosque, then, tells stories of encounters and transformations that constitute the backbone of the Stone Town’s complex heritage narrative, stories that continue to be told by the walls of this and many structures that still stand on this living World Heritage Site.

item.title: St. Joseph’s Cathedral
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The history of Zanzibar’s Stone Town is marked by the encounters between different cultures, ideologies, and religions that left their mark on the cityscape and narratives around this unique World Heritage Site.  

Saint Joseph’s Roman Catholic Cathedral was built in Stone Town by the French congregation of the Spiritans in 1896. The first records of Christian missionaries in Zanzibar date back to the Portuguese period, from the sixteenth to the eighteenth century. By the time the first Augustinian friars established themselves on the island, Islam had a strong influence over its Swahili inhabitants but still gained strength during the 200 years of European control of the island. After the Sultanate of Oman took control over Zanzibar in 1698, a few Goan christians remained on the island and continued practicing the religion in private settings. The importance of Christianity began to surge again when Zanzibar became a British protectorate in 1890, resulting in the construction of new churches and buildings dedicated to the practice of the religion in the Stone Town.

In the 1890s, the Spiritans dedicated themselves to the education and pastoral work with the Goan christian community. They enjoyed good relations with the Sultan since their purpose was not the conversion of muslims into christianity, and finally received his permission to build St. Joseph’s Cathedral in 1894. The church was designed in Neo-Romanesque style by M. Berangier, the architect of Our Lady of Marseille. The church was designed in a cruciform shape, with an octogonal dome and two high towers that dominate the island’s cityscape into the present day.

The first mass celebrated in St. Joseph’s Cathedral took place on Christmas day in 1898 and, since then, the church has played an important role in Christianity becoming today the second most widespread religion in Zanzibar after Islam. Currently, the Cathedral’s mission is centered around social and developmental work focused on education, health and women group development, and the peaceful and fruitful coexistence with the muslim majority on the island.

Beyond its architectural value, Saint Joseph’s Roman Catholic Cathedral is a monument to the cultural and religious fusion that took place in Zanzibar throughout its history as a major port city in the Indian Ocean. Today, the Cathedral evidences Stone Town’s outstanding universal value and plays a crucial role in the site’s heritage narrative, emphasizing, particularly, on UNESCO’s Criterion II for selection of a World Heritage Site: the manifestation of cultural and religious harmonization on the history and the cityscape of this living heritage site .

item.title: The Old Dispensary
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Its long-standing role as a major economic hub in the Indian Ocean remains imprinted on the history and the architecture of Stone Town’s Old Dispensary, a building that serves today as living evidence of the cultural exchanges that took place throughout the history of Zanzibar.

Also known as Ithna’sheri Dispensary, the Old Dispensary was built as a hospital in 1887 on the island’s seafront to commemorate Queen Victoria’s Golden Jubilee. British influence over Zanzibar had been escalating in the years previous to the construction of the Dispensary as a result of commerce between the two nations and British interventions to end the slave trade in Zanzibar, which continued well into the 1890s. But this prosperous economic environment was not only attractive for the British. The nineteenth century saw a significant influx of Indian merchants into the island, who, at first, were a minority among the Arab and Swahili traders that had long been established in Zanzibar. The number of Indian traders in the island tripled by the 1870s, attracting wealthier merchants who settled in the Stone Town and built or transformed existing buildings to the taste of the newcoming culture. 

Gujarati haweli houses started to proliferate in the island, featuring intricately carved wooden balconies, windows with semi-circular lintels, and decorations in colored glass to increase the lighting of the interiors. This style began to merge with Omani and British building conventions during the mandate of Sultan Seyyid Said (1870-1888), leading to a unique and truly endemic architectural style that renders many buildings in Stone Town into valuable elements to the cultural heritage of the site.

Sultan Seyyid Said was behind the project for the Old Dispensary, advised by the wealthiest Indian merchant on the island, Tharia Topan. Thopan imported Indian architect Virjee Patel, who planned the structure in line with the palaces that were being built at the time while also incorporating the Indian motifs and styles that were becoming more common on merchant’s houses in the Stone Town. The design included two-stories of broad balconies with a full view of the sea and decorated with intricately cut wood and colored glass, doors and windows decorated with molded plaster, and a large dining room with a chandelier. 

The project for the hospital reflected the context of rapid economic changes and growth in nineteenth century Zanzibar, but its symbolic value overshadowed its utilitarian function. The Old Dispensary was conceived as a gesture and a statement that encapsulated the politics and power dynamics of its time at the same time that it told a story of cultural encounters and stylistic transformations that took place in the local architectural practice. The ostentatious structure that dominated the northern area of the waterfront never opened as a hospital due to the depletion of the funds for the project, serving as a dispensary and an apartment house after its completion. The 1964 revolution left the Old Dispensary uninhabited and in very poor condition. Nearly 30 years later, it was reconstructed by the local government and opened as the Aga Khan Cultural Centre in 1997, a space that currently hosts cultural events and contains a small museum dedicated to the history of the town and the building. 

The significance of the Old Dispensary in the context of the larger heritage site of Stone Town illustrates the Dispensary’s outstanding universal value as a manifestation of cultural fusion and harmonization, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion II for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Old Dispensary, then, tells stories of encounters and transformations that constitute the backbone of the Stone Town’s complex heritage narrative, stories that continue to be told by the walls, balconies, and windows of this and the many structures that still stand on this World Heritage Site.

item.title: Christ Church
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Also known as the Anglican Cathedral, Stone Town’s Christ Church is considered to be the most prominent example of Christian architecture in East Africa. Beyond representing the multicultural history of the island, the Church stands today as a monument to the Anglican church's role in the abolition of the East African slave trade.

The first records of Christian missionaries in Zanzibar date back to the Portuguese period, from the sixteenth to the eighteenth century. By the time the first Augustinian friars established themselves on the island, Islam had a strong influence over its Swahili inhabitants but still gained strength during the 200 years of European control of the island. After the Sultanate of Oman took control over Zanzibar in 1698, a few Goan christians remained on the island and continued practicing the religion in private settings. The importance of Christianity began to surge again when Zanzibar became a British protectorate in 1890, resulting in the construction of new churches and buildings dedicated to the practice of the religion in the Stone Town.

The construction work for the Christ Church began in 1847 at the site of the last slave market that was active in Zanzibar. The history of the slave trade in East Africa goes back many centuries, with Zanzibar playing an important role in the trade with Europe and the rest of Africa. While Great Britain had been pushing for the abolition of the slave trade in Zanzibar since the 1860s, it was not until 1909 that slavery as an institution was officially abolished in Zanzibar, a British protectorate since November 1890. Sultan Seyyid Barghash bin Said, ruler of Oman at the time, signed a Treaty with Great Britain in 1873 that prohibited the export of slaves from the African mainland. It was also agreed that the main slave-market in Zanzibar would be closed on the same year that the Treaty was signed. It was at this time that the construction project for the Christ Church began, spanning until its consecration in 1903. The long process of abolishing slavery in Zanzibar was, then, metaphorically represented by the construction of the Church, reaching its final stage almost at the same time that the last slaves were traded on Zanzibari soil.

Designed by C. F. Hayward, the Cathedral has the shape of a traditional basilica with a long central nave and a transept. The altar is said to be located where the whipping post for slaves was located in the old slave market. A unique aspect of the architecture of Christ Church is the interaction between Gothic and Islamic motifs around the structure, illustrating the myriad of stylistic and cultural exchanges that took place throughout the history of Zanzibar and that remain imprinted on Stone Town’s cityscape. Perhaps the most significant aspect of the building, however, is its symbolic value in the memorialization of the victims of the slave trade in East Africa. An artwork by Swedish sculptor Clara Sornas at the exterior of the Cathedral represents the thousands of slaves who passed through Zanzibar, contributing to the building’s heritage narrative and serving as a permanent reminder of a past that must never be repeated.

The significance of the Christ Church for the cultural landscape of the Stone Town is an illustration of the site’s outstanding universal value, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion VI for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Christ Church serves as a monument to the suppression of slavery in one of the main slave-trading ports in East Africa, contributing to the rich and intricate heritage narrative that remains imprinted on the walls, towers, and gateways that make up this living World Heritage Site.

item.title: Tippu Tip’s House
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Zanzibar’s strategic location in the Indian Ocean made it a strategic point in the trade of slaves, ivory, gold, and spices from Africa to the Persian Gulf, India, and beyond. The slave trade left its mark on the structures that stand today around the Stone Town, with Tippu Tip’s House being one of the remnants of the island’s past as a major port in the slave-trading industry.

Mohammed Ibn Hamid, widely known as Tippu Tip, was born in Zanzibar in the 1840s. Still in his teens, Tippu Tip had established his trade caravan in the East African mainland for the trade of ivory and slaves. He became the largest dealer in ivory and slaves in the entire African continent and gained such control over the African inland that he was able to support Henry Morton Stanley with his expeditions to the Congo, claiming Eastern Congo for the Sultanate of Zanzibar in the 1880s. It is believed that his name was given to him by locals who spoke about “a man whose guns went ‘tiptip’ in a manner too terrible to listen to”.

The story of Tippu Tip’s wealth and influence over the island continues to be told by the walls of his former residence in the Stone Town. This fine example of a vernacular Arab townhouse displays the stylistic exchanges that took place in the island, featuring Arab, Swahili, and Indian motifs around the structure. As most of the residential doorways in the Stone Town, his was adorned with an elaborated carved wooden door that contrasted against the black and white marble steps that led inside the house. 

The lavish residence served as a haven for Tippu Tip when the slave trade was abolished and he moved into retirement in Zanzibar. Although closed to the public and in a poor state of maintenance, the House still stands today as a symbol of the power that the slave traders held over the African territory. The significance of the Tippu Tip’s House for the heritage landscape of the Stone Town is an illustration of the site’s outstanding universal value, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion IV for selection of a World Heritage Site. The House serves as a reminder of the history of slavery and its later suppression in one of the main slave-trading ports in East Africa, contributing to the rich and intricate heritage narrative that remains imprinted on the walls, towers, and gateways that make up this living World Heritage Site

item.title: The House of Wonders
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Known in Arabic as Beit–el–Ajaib, the House of Wonders serves today as a living example of the encounter between the past and nineteenth-century modernity in the architectural landscape of Zanzibar’s Stone Town.

Sultan Seyyid Said was the ruler of a vast and prosperous empire in the early nineteenth century, stretching from Oman to the Mozambican borders. He established his base in Unguja, the main island of the Zanzibar archipelago, benefitting from the island’s privileged location within the network of trade in the Indian Ocean, and leading a major economic transformation project that is imprinted on the many structures that came into existence during his time.

In the beginning of the nineteenth century, Zanzibar was a typical Swahili town with cajun huts as a few stone buildings that made up the landscape. The arrival of the Omani did not only revolutionize the town’s economy, but also influenced the architectural style that characterized the town, resulting in an endemic “Zanzibar-Arab” type that made an important contribution to the period’s architecture in the western Indian Ocean. Coming from a desert land where rain is scarce, the Omani integrated their traditional concept of an ideal beyt (home) with the materials, building conventions, and weather conditions of the island. The model of the whitewashed square fortress with a flat roof and an inner courtyard for various household activities, then, dominated the nineteenth century Zanzibari cityscape and were the stylistic foundations on which official structures like the House of Wonders were built. 

The House of Wonders was built in 1883 as a ceremonial and administrative palace for the Sultan. Sultan Seyyid Said began the project after a 1875 visit to the European cities of Paris and London that motivated him to push for the modernization of Zanzibar and install, among other infrastructure projects, a piped drinking water system. The modernizing project extended into the Sultan’s palace too, which, besides being the tallest building in the town, also became the first building in Zanzibar to have electricity and the first building in East Africa to have a lift. Baptized with its present name by the startled Arab population in reaction to the building’s modern features, the palace was both a statement of domination and a display of power and wealth. Its strategic location among other administrative and residential palaces, a lighthouse, gardens, a bath complex, and a water cistern all connected by sky bridges turned the House of Wonders into the most important building in the city as it dominated over its most important space: the waterfront. 

The palace is constructed in the traditional Omani square shape, with galleries facing the internal courtyards and leading to long and shallow rooms. The external walls of the building are decorated with verandas and intricately carved wooden doors that reflect both the Indian and traditional Zanzibari influence on the architectural style of the House of Wonders. Floral and animal motifs, along with gilded verses from the Qur’an, decorate the palace’s doors, further contributing to its uniqueness on the Stone Town’s cityscape.

After the death of Sultan Seyyid Said in 1888, British influence on Zanzibar grew stronger, leading to the island becoming a protectorate in 1890. The House of Wonders was bombarded by a British fleet during the Anglo-Zanzibar war of 1896 and its later reconstruction led to the addition of a clock tower and the removal of some of the verandas that were present in the original design. After the Zanzibari independence in 1963, the palace was restored to its original function of ceremonial and administrative palace for the government of Sultan Seyyid Jamshid, but it was looted shortly after during the 1964 Revolution. It later served as the headquarters of the Afro Shirazi Party Ideological College and Revolution Memorial Museum until it was returned to the Zanzibari government in 1992. The building was converted into the Zanzibar House of Wonders Museum in 2000, displaying a broad collection on the history of Zanzibar, containing, among other valuable artifacts, a set of unique examples of carved “Zanzibar doors” that are characteristic of the island. Illustrating Zanzibar’s Stone Town’s outstanding universal value through UNESCO’s Criterion III for selection of a World Heritage Site, the House of Wonders constitutes a meeting point of cultures and architectural styles that make it a unique landmark in the town’s urban landscape.

item.title: The Old Fort
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Also known as the Gereza or Ngome Kongwe in Swahili, the Stone Town’s Old Fort stands today as a witness of the complex cultural fusions that took place throughout Zanzibar’s history as a major port city in the Indian Ocean. 

The fort is the oldest standing structure in the Stone Town, dating back to the early Omani occupation of the islands. Archaeological studies have shown, however, that the site had already been in use during the Portuguese occupation in the sixteenth century, and that a church with the shape of a cross had previously stood on the area before the year 1569. A weakening of the Portuguese domain over the Gulf in the 1620s led to the Omani liberation of Muscat in 1650. A series of subsequent liberation efforts followed on Portuguese-dominated territories overseas, with Zanzibar fully passing onto Omani hands shortly after 1698 for the three centuries that were to come.

 The first descriptions of the Old Fort date back to 1710 and point towards the assumption that parts of the previous edifications on the area were reused and fortified for the new building’s intended purpose. The fort was built in an irregular quadrilateral shape with square gateways and fine towers that were joined by crenelated walls. The Fort’s appearance continued to change over the years to cater for the needs of the contested territory, which was still being disputed between Portuguese and Omani forces well into the eighteenth century.

Writing in the early nineteenth century, Sir Henry Hart, a British naval officer and diplomat, described the Fort as: “... The only place on the island of Zanzibar where there are any guns is at the foot of a white round tower, — it cannot be called a castle. It consists of a square fort or prison [a murabb ʿah?], with four walls, and a small tower in each corner; the guns, eight or nine in number, are out of condition, and outside of the tower close to the beach: a jolly boat would take it, or knock them down. It is said His Highness intends to build a new fort…”. His accounts match the period when Zanzibar became the Omani capital and the Sultan began projects to build a palace next to the Old Fort, which was being used to lodge and enslave soldiers.

The nineteenth and twentieth century history of the Fort is marked by several reformations on the building’s structure. After the bombardment of the Fort in 1896 during the Anglo-Zanzibar war and its subsequent abandonment, the Old Fort was used as a depot for the Zanzibar Railway and as a ladies’ club until the 1990s, when an amphitheater was added to the structure and the site became a cultural hub in the Stone Town. Today, the Zanzibar International Film Festival is held every year at this location, adding to the touristic value of the site as a witness of complex political and cultural exchanges throughout its history. 

The significance of the Old Fort for the cultural landscape of the Stone Town is an illustration of the site’s outstanding universal value, responding directly to UNESCO’s Criterion II for selection of a World Heritage Site. The Old Fort constitutes a tangible manifestation of the cultural fusion and harmonization that took place in Zanzibar throughout centuries of history, resulting in a rich and intricate narrative of connections that remains imprinted on the walls, towers, and gateways that make up this World Heritage Site today.

item.title: The Stone Village
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A series of three stone towns was believed to be built during the fourteenth to twentieth centuries. The first two towns discovered are located in the northeast and southwest in Old Umm al-Quwain 1 and 2. Both towns have been shattered into ruins leaving pieces of artifacts, ceramics, and stones indicating different eras and cultures in human history of globalization and trade. The stone village in the northeast is located in Old Umm al-Quwain 1, the earliest settlement found on the island illustrates the remains of ruins of decayed buildings covered by substantial mounds. Similarly, the second stone village located in the southwest is found in Old Umm al-Quwain 2 dating to the early seventeenth to mid-nineteenth century; it is near the oyster shell middens associated with the pearling boom emergence, and it was destroyed by the British navy resulting in new settlement in Umm al-Quwain 3 or the modern Umm al-Quwain.

Even though both towns are left in ruins, there is significant evidence of globalization, trade, settlement of late Antique dates, and religious indicators. For example, there is a soft bowl indicating the spread of late Sasanian to early Islamic glass items, and a total of seventy-four coins made from rare metal bronze coins were collected from the surface are scattered in Old Umm al-Quwain. In the first town, there are exports from China such as the green-glazed pottery under the late Yuan and early Ming dynasties.  Furthermore, there is an assumption put forward about the structure of stone town was based on hierarchy order, and transitioned toward pearl fishing and international trade due to the presence of palm-frond (arish) villages, in contrast to the subsidiary settlements and workshops producing lime or supplying fish and shellfish to the town.  This pattern or structure shows a hierarchical order and members’ settling in Old Umm al-Quwain 2, and it shows the cultural value of utilizing the land and sea to settle socially and economically.  Lastly, there are two shattered historic buildings of towers consisting of an estate of the ruling Al Mu’alla family, a presence of a mosque, a majlis, and a residential compound that was later built in the mid-twentieth century. These evidences are under excavation thus there is ongoing research, assumptions, and hypotheses made to conclude the exact and accuracy of the site.

Both stone towns discovered in the north-east and south-west of Old Umm al-Quwain 1 &  2 dating from the fourteenth to mid-nineteenth century are evidence of human settlement, globalization, trade, and daily habits and rituals from different eras of time, culture, and religion. This is a fascinating discovery because it shows global interconnectivity during the fourteenth century in the Middle East, the transition of religious beliefs from Christianity to Islam, the boom of pearling in the Gulf, and the settlement path of how modern Umm al-Quwain was built. Criteria 5 and 3 of Outstanding Universal Value best correlate with the site because it shows testimony of settlements that have vanished, as well as human interactions, and activities such as trade across cultures.

item.title: The Oyster Shell Dumpsite
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Oyster Dump Shell Dumpsite is a large area of discarded oyster shells which suggest that the town’s primary economic activity was pearling. This site is distinguished from other peraling sites as it has signs of year round inhibition rather than being a seasonal spot. This site serves as a testament for human settlement and pearling activity. This part of the island is where a large number of discarded oyster shells were discovered, indicating human settlement & that the town’s primary trade was pearling – common in the Arabian Gulf. 

Oyster shell dumpsites, also known as shell mounds, are frequent in places where oyster harvesting and eating have traditionally been significant. Shell mounds emerge over time when discarded oyster shells gather in one location. They may give important archaeological data regarding the age of the site by using radiocarbon dating, a technique used to analyze the age of organic materials. This can help in constructing timelines and forming an “understanding of coastal settlement dynamics and human–environment interactions”.  They also aid us in understanding past civilizations' way of living from their dietary practices, social structure and population, and their social and economic networks. In addition, the natural environment and the resources found indicate the nature of activity that took place. For example, the empty oyster shells could suggest pearling practice.  

The discovery of shell mounds may indicate that Sinyah Island was once a pearling town.  After pearling oysters, the shells are usually discarded in coastal areas like lagoons and shorelines. Over time, if these shells keep piling up, they  form a shell mound. Shell mounds can indicate the presence of a pearling town since the collection of shells may be the product of a substantial pearl fishing activity. These shells can serve as tangible archeological evidence of a potential pearling industry that thrived in the area. Given this information, it would appear that the communities that resided on the lagoon were economically dependent on the harvesting of pearls and on international trade.

In addition to the oysters being a source of pearls, the foundation of the town's economy, oyster shells were used as construction material for many of the town's buildings. The remains of the shells can still be seen embedded in the building blocks of the archeological site. Sinayah Island’s shell mounds serve as evidence of human civilization, as well as the importance that oysters played in facilitating that civilization. The shell mounds and other archeological artifacts on the island give concrete proof of prior human settlements and activities in the area, notably pearling, which was once a significant economic activity in the region. The use of oyster shells as building materials on the island adds to the history narrative by revealing the community's creativity in harnessing the island's natural resources to maintain a sustainable way of life.  This tangible evidence helps to shape the site's heritage narrative by highlighting the area's long and rich history of pearling and its relevance to local and regional history. All in all, the shell mound serves as invaluable archeological evidence of Sinayah Island’s history as a bustling Gulf pearling town.

References

item.title: Khor al-Beida Lagoon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Umm al-Quwain’s Khor al-Beida is one of the last remaining historical lagoons on the Gulf Coast. It is a naturally rich lagoon that serves as the best example of its kind within the northern Emirates.

The lagoon in Umm al-Quwain is a partially enclosed basin with its water depth varying based on the location and tide. Its shallowness allows for seagrass beds to flourish and mangrove stands to be plentiful. Because of its abundance of natural resources, those who inhabited the vicinity of the lagoon benefited from its useful resources such as marine shells, fish, and most importantly, pearls.

The lagoon has been in existence since 7,000 years ago, alongside important historical sites such as the Neolithic dugong shrine Ghalla Island, the settlement of the Bronze Age in Tell Abraq, and the Greco-Roman site in ed-Dur. Over time, the lagoon's entrance gradually moved northeast, creating narrow, hook-shaped spits that formed a sandbar to protect the outermost hook from direct sea currents. This process continued for over 3,000 years until the main sandbar breached in the 600s, causing Sīnīya to become a proper island. The inner part of the island, consisting of consolidated sandy hooks, remained almost unchanged.

Its significance started manifesting clearly 700 years ago when Umm Al Quwain became an emirate. The lagoons vary in depth, offering various resources for the locals. They relied heavily on marine shells, crustaceans, and fish for their sustenance. Under the rule of Sheikh Rashid bin Majid Al Mualla, the lagoon gained protection through a set of laws to regulate fishing in the lagoons. The Sheikh also made efforts to section off areas of the lagoon for protected wildlife. 

The lagoon’s significance also lies in the fact that it served as a central trading spot. By looking at where the various buildings were once located in the archaeological remains, it was clear that there was a settlement hierarchy that showed that international trade took place. The eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries were known as the beginning of the pearl boom, and the pearling industry largely influenced the Persian Gulf. This was the result of the expansion of a fully global trading system where markets were open for the Gulf pearls. The pearling industry allowed them to participate in global markets where trade occurred with places like India and Europe. 

The lagoon plays a significant role in the cultural and natural significance of the site in Umm al-Quwain fulfilling criteria 5 and 8 respectively. The lagoon on the Siniyah Island archaeological site satisfies UNESCO World Heritage Site selection Criterion 5 as it is an exceptional example of human interaction with the environment, representative of the region's culture, and is at risk of irreversible change due to urbanization. The lagoon was able to provide the people who settled near it with the plentiful resources needed to have a prosperous economy based on pearling and trade. This narrative is extremely important to the UAE as its history started with the pearling industry. In addition, it fulfills criterion 8 as it represents a significant geomorphic and physiographic feature in the development of landforms.

item.title: The Mosque
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Located in the southwest of Sīnīya Island, the ruins of a Mosque serve as a testimony of the Islamic settlement in the area and of the history of a diverse religious landscape that came to exist on the island over the centuries.

The ruins of the Mosque are under the estate of the ruling Al Mu’alla family, along with a majlis and a residential compound found in the close surroundings. These findings date the mosque to the mid-20th century), along with two areas of shallow mounds with pieces of pottery and stones. The area has been partially excavated, showing largely decayed and robbed buildings and confirming the presence of buried structures under the existing ruins. Fossils and celadon pieces found in the area surrounding the Mosque date back to the 14th and 15th centuries, and enamel and sponge from the 18th and 19th centuries, evidencing a long history of occupation of the area. It might be the case, then, that the Mosque had been in existence since before the 20th and was refurbished then to become part of the estate of the ruling family.

The later history of the mosque is tied to the destructive actions of the British East India Company in the early 19th century. The mosque was part of the second town of Umm Al Qaiwain, which was destroyed on January 18th, 1820, by a naval squadron sent by the British to deal with piracy in the region. Despite the town's destruction, the mosque managed to survive, albeit in a ruined state. In 1822, a British naval survey noted the abandoned site of the second town, which was located on Siniya Island, and described the ruins of the mosque. The British continued to maintain a presence in the region, with Shaikh Sultan b. Saqr al-Qasimi, the ruler of Ras Al Khaimah, signed the General Maritime Treaty of 1820 with them. This treaty brought an end to the hostilities and laid the foundation for the modern United Arab EmiratesThe significance of the ruins of the Sīnīya Island Mosque in the context of this archaeological site illustrates the island’s universal value as a manifestation of the civilization that once called it home. The Mosque, then, plays a crucial role in the complex heritage narrative of the island and the Emirate of Umm al Quwain, whose history of religious encounters mirrors the multicultural landscape that dominates today in the UAE.

References

Power, Timothy, Federico Borgi, Michele Degli Esposti, Robert Hoyland, and Rania Hussein Kannouma. “Archaeological Survey of Sīnīya Island, Umm Al-Quwain.” Études et Travaux, no. 35 (2022). https://doi.org/10.12775/etudtrav.35.007.

UNESCO World Heritage Centre. “The Criteria for Selection.” UNESCO World Heritage Centre. https://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/.  

Onley, James. "Britain’s informal empire in the Gulf." Journal of Social Affairs 22.87 (2005): 29-45.

item.title: Ed-Dur
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The site of Ed-Dur, in the emirate of Umm-al-Quwain, in the present-day United Arab Emirates, lies adjacent to the large Al Beidha lake, a lagoon surrounded by a series of high sand dunes which shields it from direct sea view and from the northern offshore wind prevailing in the region. Ed-Dur has gone through periods of prosperity and population, as well as isolation and desertion through the ages. The strategic location of the site, as the largest and possibly one of the only coastal sites on the Arabian side of the Persian Gulf, between the  of the 1st Century BCE and the 1st Century CE, would have ensured its continuity and prolonged occupation. Despite the existence of multiple theories, the site’s ancient name remains disputed. The site of Ed Dur is often associated with Omana as mentioned in the ‘The Periplus of the Erythrean Sea’ , a Greek sailing manual, attributed to an unknown sailor and dated to approximately the 1st century CE. Speaking of Omana, the author of Periplus wrote:

 “Immediately beyond Syagrus the bay of Omana cuts deep into the coast-line, the width of it being six hundred stadia; and beyond this there are mountains, high and rocky and steep, inhabited by cave-dwellers for five hundred stadia more; and beyond this is a port established for receiving the Sachalitic frankincense.” (‘The Periplus of the Erythrean Sea’: pp. 34-35) 

Scholars however now believe that the author of the Periplus did not himself travel to the Persian Gulf and described those sites based on hearsay. 

Discovery:

Ed-Dur was first  identified by a team of Iraqi archaeologists in 1973, where they discovered the remains of stone houses as well as several coins. Ever since its first discovery, there have been several seasons of excavation by multiple international teams of archaeologists including Belgian, British, French, and Danish archaeologists which has resulted in  a range of important discoveries adding to our knowledge of the site. While much of the site still remains unexcavated, archaeological discoveries at Ed-Dur include the ruins of more than twenty thousand graves, a fort, several dwelling houses, and most importantly, the remarkable discovery of a temple dedicated to the sun god Shamash, excavated by the Belgian archaeologist Dr Ernie Haernick in 1987. A significant feature of the ruins found at Ed-Dur is the use of the beach rock in local constructions; several graves, dwelling structures, and even the fort were all found to have been constructed using the locally-found beach rock.

The most breathtaking and noteworthy structure found from the site is the temple of Shamash, dedicated to the Sun god. Unlike other structures on the site, the rectangular structure is constructed of stones that were possibly made in moulds using mud from the adjoining lagoon. The stones were then covered by plaster, incised with linear design and may once have been painted. The ruins of the temple also include a rectangular stone basin with an Aramaic inscription that reads ‘Shamash’, confirming that the structure is indeed a pagan shrine. This basin could have been used to store water, or even sacrificial blood. The temple has two doorways on the opposite sides, one each on the east and the west, and a small window on the northern wall. Discoveries within the temple structure  included the remains of a fireplace, a Roman bronze oil lamp, incense burners with remains of burnt incense, fragments of a shattered bird statue made of limestone, two figures of a falcon, and a well. Archaeologists also discovered the remains of two rectangular structures within the remains of the temple, which were presumed to be altars, along with a terracotta camel figurine and the head of a male figurine. The area outside the temple indicates evidence of burning of fire, and several other altars are found in front of the temple. Read more on the story of the discovery of this unique temple here. 

Significance: 

The site of Ed-Dur has mostly been discussed as being a significant market place and a center for commercial exchange laying on the maritime routes and the inland caravan routes in the ancient world. What lies neglected in this scholarship is the ritual importance of the site keeping in view the centrality of the monumental temple. The temple has been one of the most significant archaeological discoveries at Ed-Dur, and has several unique features associated with it. For instance, the layout of the temple has led historians to surmise that only visitors of a certain class and status, such as priests, may have had access inside the temple structure; the ordinary citizen may have only circumambulated the temple, given the presence of fireplaces and altars in its immediate vicinity. Another possibility explored by archaeologists and historians is that the temple could have served as the seat of an oracle, considering the presence of a small rectangular opening on the northern wall, which could have served as a channel of communication between the Oracle inside and the people outside. Yet another ritual possibility that scholars have identified at Ed-Dur has to do with the two-hundred cobblestones that were found in the temple structure; scholars have claimed that it is highly plausible that the stones were meant to be taken away by pilgrims visiting the temple after finishing all the rituals. In this sense, the stones allowed pilgrims who came from far-off places to Ed-Dur to be connected by a physical manifestation of their common devotion to Shamash, The presence of a temple dedicated to Shamash in the Iraqi town of Hatra suggests a ritual connection between the two sites , given how pilgrims and certain ritual objects may have circulated between the two sites.  

There is often  a sense of exceptionalism attached to Ed-Dur based on its commercial importance as there is so far no evidence of  another harbor site spanning the entire coast of the Arabian Gulf  between the 3rd  and 1st century BCE.  At the same time this has also diminished the importance of the site in recent academic scholarship merely as a trading port. A vast variety of foreign-issued coins and objects have been discovered at the site establishing its cosmopolitan nature in the ancient world.  Coins  originating from places far and wide such as from the Roman Empire, the Eastern Mediterranean region, southern Mesopotamia, South Arabia, Persia, and South Asia have so far been discovered. Apart from coins, excavations at Ed-Dur unearthed a variety of Roman glass vessels (which could take the form of simple bowls as well as bowls  in the shape of dates, fish, and grapes), a vast variety of glazed pottery from Mesopotamia and Southeastern Persia, numerous beads and bracelets from Persia, as well as fragments of pottery and etched carnelian beads from India. A closer study of beads found in Ed-Dur also reveals ties with Sri Lanka and Tanzania.  The citizens of Ed-Dur also seemed to have been true gourmands who had considerable resources, given the presence of the remains of freshwater fish found in the region. The significance of Ed-Dur has been connected with the contemporary inland site of Mleiha, roughly 75 kilometers away, now located in the emirate of Sharjah. Mleiha and Ed-Dur both served as the primary towns for trade in the south of the Gulf in the years between 1st century BCE and 1st century CE. Ed-Dur  may have served as a harbor and a marketplace for foreign goods that were then further transported into Mleiha, and was also a source for marine food resources such as fish, salt etc. ; On the other hand, Mleiha, lying at the foot of the Hajar mountains, with underground water, may have provided Ed-Dur with agricultural products and other resources that might have been lacking there. Read more about Mleiha here.

Given Ed-Dur’s geographical location, at the mouth of the Persian Gulf with the lagoon providing a natural harbor for incoming boats, as well as the possible availability of freshwater, as indicated by the existence of a well at the site, are considerably some of the most important factors in determining its ritual and commercial significance. As a natural and convenient landing place on the ancient maritime routes across the Persian Gulf and then into the Indian Ocean, Ed-Dur could have served as a hub where people and goods from South Asia, Persia, Mesopotamia, and Europe arrived to be dispersed throughout the hinterlands of Arabia. The fact that this prosperous site was shielded from direct sea view  by the presence of the sand dunes would have perhaps provided traders an enhanced sense of security.  Seen in this light, could the ancient inhabitants of Ed-Dur have decided to erect the temple of Shamash here as a coastal marker and a place of social cohesion for sailors from various parts of the world?

Preservation: 

Since its initial discovery, the archaeological site of Ed-Dur and the structures there have unfortunately faced the wrath of the natural elements in the arid, Arabian desert. Buildings made of mud bricks, stone, and plaster have greatly deteriorated due to continued exposure to sand, sun, rain, and wind. When first excavated, the Shamash temple also carried faint traces of paint which have all now disappeared. 

The site has also faced considerable damage on account of human greed. Before the site was first discovered, in the early 1970s, expatriates living in the UAE would often go to Ed-Dur with metal detectors to collect ancient coins and other artifacts which were then sold off in antique markets. More recently, scholars have made an effort to recover these artifacts by paying hefty sums to bring back these crucial pieces which would help construct the heritage of the site. Considering these circumstances, the UAE has put in place firm measures to prevent the site from further deterioration. The site has been fenced off to restrict access, and is now managed by the Department of Tourism and Antiquities, Umm Al Quwain. 

Read further about the UAE’s efforts to preserve the site of Ed-Dur here.  

Ed-Dur clearly represents a significant moment in the national history of the UAE. The presence of the Shamash Temple is indicative of the region's identity as a cradle for religiosity, tolerance, and cultural diversity. Moreover, Ed-Dur’s role in facilitating global economic and cultural exchanges also reflects the region’s  contemporary pre-eminence as a sophisticated and cosmopolitan hub, lying on the ancient maritime route and embedded in networks of pilgrimage and trade. Ed-Dur’s importance to Emirati national heritage is further justified by the demands of  Umm Al Quwain’s Department of Tourism and Antiquities to include the site on UNESCO’s World Heritage List. The site is currently closed to tourists and visitors. For those who would like to marvel at the discoveries from Ed-Dur can find artifacts exhibited at the Umm Al Quwain Museum (Umm Al Quwain National Museum), and can also often find temporary exhibitions and artifacts from Ed-Dur on loan at the Louvre Abu Dhabi (Louvre Abu Dhabi) and  the Sharjah Archaeology Museum (Sharjah Archaeology Museum). 

References and Further Reading

De Waele, An. “The Beads of Ed-Dur (Umm al-Qaiwain, UAE).” Proceedings of the Seminar for Arabian Studies, vol. 37, 2007, pp. 297–308. 

“Ed-Dur Site.” UNESCO World Heritage Convention, Accessed 25 June 2023. 

Ghazal, Rym. “A rich history uncovered.” The National News, 03 Nov. 2015 .

Ghazal, Rym. “Slowly solving riddles of the UAE’s ancient ed-Dur.” The National News, 02 Oct. 2012.

Haernick, Ernie. “Internationalization and business in SE-Arabia during the late 1st. c. B.C./1st. c. AD. Archaeological Evidence from ed-Dur (Umm al-Qaiwain, U.A.E.).”. Archaeology of the United Arab Emirates. Proceedings of the first International Conference on the Archaeology of the U.A.E., edited by Daniel T. Potts et al, Trident Press Ltd, 2003, pp. 195-206. 

Haerinck, Ernie. “The Temple at ed-Dur (Emirate of Umm-al-Quwain) and pre-Islamic cult in south-eastern Arabia”. Fifty Years of Emirates Archaeology, edited by Daniel T. Potts et al, Motivate Publishing, 2012, pp. 163-172. 

Haernick, Ernie. “International contacts in the southern Persian Gulf in the late 1st century B.C. / 1st century A.D. : Numismatic evidence from ed-Dur (Emirate of Umm al-Qaiwain, U.A.E.)”.  Iranica Antiqua, vol. 33, January 1998, pp. 273-302.
