item.title: Interview on past and future for the Island
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
About Dinho’s occupation and educational/professional background.
I’m the head of the tourism operators association of the Island of Mozambique. My occupation is being an accounting technician but I’m trained in heritage management and historical heritage. I had this training in Norway and I was trained in studies on safeguarding and protecting cultural heritage.

About Amade’s occupation and educational/professional background.
I’m a computer technician. Right now I manage the multimedia center of the community center of the Island of Mozambique and I involves a telecentre and a local radio that has a range of 55 km. I also have a mini training in protecting and safeguarding cultural heritage and I’m an advocate for the tangible and intangible heritage here on the Island of Mozambique.

What is your connection with the Island of Mozambique?
Dinho – The Island of Mozambique is a city that is my hometown, first thing. So it has a big meaning to me because it is the land that saw me growing. Being this Island, listed by its history and classified as a World Heritage Site (WHS), so the island alone with its history has already a great significance and importance. For me, as a citizen, that knows the island before and after the independence day, and has someone who remembers things for those times…It has a great meaning to me. It is where I was born.

Amade – It is where I was born and raised. A place that I’m proud of. And that is a WHS. I’m proud of this and also of my contribution for the World Heritage Site classification to happen.

Can you tell more about that? The WHS process that took place.
Amade – When the Association of Island of Mozambique was created, one of the main goals was to inscribe the Island as a WHS in the UNESCO’s list. So we did a survey of historical monuments. Everything that had a cultural value, either intangible or tangible, until we were able to call the UNESCO’s commission so they could evaluate the value of the Island of Mozambique. They evaluated and we got inscribed on the list. But then, major responsibilities arose in the conservation and preservation and later, the safeguard of the Island’s heritage. They came to do their first evaluation after the Island was a WHS. They didn’t register any damages, bad conservation or bad preservation…nothing. Then they came to do the second evaluation and we had the same result. So we stayed relatively safe to keep ourselves in the WHS list. Because any anomaly detected we would mean we were outside the WHS list, until we corrected the situation. The reason why we are involved in the underwater heritage safeguarding, and why it is a concern of ours, is until the government of Mozambique rectify the convention. But they already accepted to sign it. All this was a fight of ours, together, to pressure the government until they reach a conclusion to sign the convention. And this is a great pride that I have. And I will not get tired of fighting for our heritage.

What is your opinion of UNESCO presence here on the Island, and its role?
Dinho – UNESCO has an important role. First, since 1991, the year of the classification of the Island of Mozambique as a WHS. Their other role is to do a follow up of the situation, is to supervise. It’s try to follow up with every place that becomes a WHS, to evaluate is the state of the situation is critical or not, if the cities are at risk or not, if they are being correctly preserved, using the right conservation materials, if they are traditional materials… Their role is to see if there is not a lot of deterioration of the authenticity. Because there are cities that are at risk because people made a lot of changes…All this related with the control and presence of the UNESCO. We feel their presence because they show up annually here and meetings are organized, and they do follow up although their actions here have been reduced. Before we had a UNESCO’s office here, we had a representation and now we don’t. The follow up it is not on a daily basis like it used to be. It was important to establish an office again so their presence had more impact on the Island of Mozambique.

Amade – They are much needed here. I agree with everything Dinho just mentioned, but I want to add some things. First, the community didn’t understand or knew what UNESCO’s role was. The community realized just thought that: the Island has ancient ruins; UNESCO has classified the Island as a WHS so UNESCO will rehabilitate the Island of Mozambique. So there was a work of sensitization, of communication and education to make the community understand what was UNESCO’s role. We did that through advertising spots and explanatory messages. All these took place in the form of radiophonic debates, in the form of thematic heritage programs in the local radio. Little by little we were able to get some results of this work. We didn’t stop the sensitization work how to conserve, what is UNESCO’s role in the preservation of heritage cities, not only the Island of Mozambique but in a worldwide perspective as well and the community started to understand. Today I can say that the majority of the people already understands all of this.

Dinho – returning a little just to complete. Even before the radio existed, this work of dissemination, of communication of what is a WHS, the community started receiving this messages and in the beginning, in the 90’s the messages were spread within the population though singing, stories... and that started this work.

You think the WHS classification changed the way people perceive the Island of Mozambique, or the way they interact with it?
Dinho – the classification of UNESCO didn’t changed anything. It came to solidify. Because if there was any change UNESCO probably didn’t want to classify the island. This mix of religions, races, and raiment all this elements were important to UNESCO distinguished the island. It’s the cultural reality that the Island has.

Amade – I agree. It didn’t changed the Island.

You think the classification as a WHS has brought benefits or not?
Amade – It has brought great benefits. It endowed the community with knowledge. We have to habilitate the men so he know how to work with that stone, as the saying goes. When I talk about the stone, what I really mean is the structure of the building for example.

Dinho - That is really the most important part. In fact, UNESCO's presence brought another dynamics, in terms of strategies of how to preserve, rescue some polities in terms of conservation. All of this to maintain the convention that was signed in the UNESCO, so we have a follow up of this extraordinary value that the Island of Mozambique has. We need to bring importance to that so that we don't escape from the rules that are implemented.

So The Association of the Friends of The Island of Mozambique was the great engine responsable for the process of classification for the WHS and education of the communities. Given this, how important are the local associations to dinamize the Island? What is their role?
Amade - There is a common role on every association here on the Island, their main goal that is increment the social and economic development of the Island. Then, naturally, every association has its unique goals, more activity especific, according to their main activity. In the case of the Association of the Friends of the Island of Mozambique, it was the only association that existed backthen. Now, more there are more associations of the Island. There was a decentralization within the Association of the Friends OTIOM. Within this one, several associations were born, and creating their specific goals. But all of them have the main goal of contributing for the development of the Island and protect, safeguard and preserve the heritage that is the Island.

Dinho - Not to disagree with Amade but from the different point of view of the different associations... I will give an example about a problem that bothers the fisherman may not bother the salt-work, and vice-versa, and may not be the same problem with the tourism managers. This means that every associations has its own partners. The association where I belong it’s the Association of the Tourism operators and Managers. Today there is a marriage between culture/heritage and tourism. In the Island itself the tourism that it is practiced is the cultural tourism that has several interests. When we talk about this association, has its partners and they are operators from the private sector that has nothing to do with the state. And all this people have different interests. Having all of this associations brings, in my point of view, an advantage that is, if somebody, form example, has a problem with their business in the Island and it is connected to tourism, your problem can be the same as another operator. If there is a union between us, we can join forces to solve the problem and arrange solutions, we can talk to the government. But, like Amade said, all of this association seek to help with the Island's development, and socialwellfare.

In general, do you think people are about the conservation of the Island of Mozambique?
Amade - In a certain way, yes. They worry because the awareness doesn't stop, it is permanent. The Island of Mozambique suffers a great oscillation of visitors. So it is needed that we, the residents, know how to make the visitor understand how to enjoy all his heritage. The reason why this education and awareness isn't only for the new visitors but also for the people of the community of the Island of Mozambique. Day after day, some people are born, they grow, and so, this work of awareness must be a constant and never stop. It is in this way that we are been able to bring this knowledge of protecting and safeguarding heritage to the communities, to the different levels of the community. We even thought the radio we do this kind of show, where we talk about this, in the local language, the macua, the most spoken language here on the Island. Because we are not only interested in the local islander habitant but also in the continental area, in the farthest places, where the radio reaches.  One day this people will come to the Island, and will already know all about the heritage landmarks, why it is a classified place... they will known by the time they come here. They will come informed and will check out everything they had been heard from the radio.

Dinho - The island of Mozambique, as Amade said, is full of monuments, and it is the only city that is classified as a WHS in Mozambique. This city was also the first capital of the country and was this Island that named the country and not the other way around. So, according to our history, these monuments don't only exist on the Island but also in the adjacent region. For example, in the Mossuril district it exists other monuments, there are Feitorias and other historical monuments, a well that Vasco da Gama was there and he reached this region, because the water was always an issue on the Island. The well is in Cabeceira Pequena. And even today, the population from there consumes that very same water would say that if the population is satisfied with the conservation...well, there are rules. To conserve there are rules to respect. If there is satisfaction from the population regarding this, yes there is. But, it is a bit complicated. I will give an example. When we are born, normally they buy me a tricycle. Then I grow, they buy me a bicycle, and my dream becomes of owning a motorcycle, and go on.... Here is the same thing. The "heritage houses" in the stone city...I don't know if you notice that the Island is divided in two: the stone city and the macuti part. People that live in the macuti area are very pour.  The rules of preservation of the macuti city... So the houses had these constructions of stones, dirt, and palm trees with macuti cover. Today those population, talking about the globalization, everyone wants an improved house, showing the success they have in life, they want to upgrade. So the evolution is to change that type of houses and give a better cover to them, with a zinc cover. Those trends also go to the building of the house itself, to the walls. They rather have a cement house. There is a challenge. We need to talk to this communities to preserve the house. So the awareness happens in a daily basis, everyday day working, being careful not to hurt the social fabric.

What is your opinion about the museums?
Dinho - We have the museum of the São Paulo Palace that reveals all the Portuguese mordomy and the colonial area, how the Portuguese lived here, according to the empire. That doesn't reveal the lives of the people that lived on the Island of Mozambique. It has nothing to do with it. It shows a lot of the history of the Portuguese here on the Island. There is also the religious art museum, the navy museum, we have another one on the continent...but none of them shows how the life of the Mozambicans was. We believe, according to this project, the SlaveWreck Project, through this partnerships that exist between the University Eduardo Mondlane and the George Washington University and the Afro-American Museum through the Smithsonian will bring another energy and dynamics to this. It was already identified the Slave's ramp there in the Mossuri area, so the slaves weren't only from the Island, but also caught in more interior zone, in the region of Tete, Zambezia, Cabo Delgado...So the Island was an commercial warehouse, so they were quartered in Mossuril, because of the long journey that they did and there they were arranged and brought to be sold on the island. From here, they were put on ships and exported. That process, with the partners I referred, as planned the inauguration of a Slave history museum. It will not only serve to show how the most sentimental part of the lives of the Mozambican people was. If someone asked for my opinion, I mean, it was a lot of suffering, during a lot of centuries, a lot of shredded blood, massacre. A lot of feeling because it would be our great-great-great grandfathers that would be here portrayed. That affection that they should had given and/or received, they couldn't because they were taken away. If they had stayed we wouldn't had the luxuries of the European technology but those affections are missing. It was only torture during centuries. This museum makes sense to exist because it will bring all the culture of the diaspora not only feeling but also all those connections because it is a lot of people in the Americas, especially in Brazil, in the USA, Cuba, and so on. Here, some boat were loss, there are the in Mauritius, Madagascar… all these islands had so many ships lost. Those islands were populated and founded but with people from the Island of Mozambique.This for me… it was good that we could have a museum, not from the slavers but the lives from the, not the slaves, but of the African people, but the Mozambicans mainly.

Amade – About the slavery…there is a very curious fact. Today we are here sitting on this balcony. We are drinking a beverage, a glass of water, having a meal…but we are sitting in a place where they used to sell slaves [interview taking place at the hotel Escondidinho]. I don’t know if you knew it.

Dinho – This was an ancient trading post [Feitoria], where they used to sell slaves.

Amade – In this balcony was were the buyers used to sit. And the slaves, here where is the pool, it used to be a cistern and it had its slab. So this used to be a stage where the slaves were profiled.

Dinho – They were released and they would throw a piece of bread. The idea was that the strongest slaves would show themselves. Here was one of those types of “houses”. You also have the Casa Girassol…we have a lot of them here. Your hotel is also one.

You think that exists some historical holiday, celebration day that had altered the original storyline, what really happened to reinforce the Mozambican identity.
Dinho – I think it is. There are dates that I don’t understand. Why do we celebrate, here on the Island, the date of the establishment of the Island as a city? It’s on 17th September 1918. They say Nacala Porto it was on the 16th, in Mossuril was on the…how did they come up with this dates? This for me is nonsense. I don’t believe in these one day differences. I don’t know where they are based on. The one from the Island there is an inscription on the building with that date. At least we have something in this case. And we have scriptures also, because it was the first one.

Amade – During the colonial time there was a special holiday on the Island of Mozambique, besides the national holidays from Portugal itself. But especially here they would celebrate the day of the discovery of the Island on 2nd March 1498. The date of Vasco da Gama’s arrival on the Island. It was one of the dates that were celebrated. Back then we never knew about the 17th of September. We just knew that date after the colonial era ended. We stopped celebrating the 2nd of March and started celebrating the 17th of September. It was a holiday that had more to do with the Island. The 2nd March was the “discovery” controversy. He discovered or did he come to the island to visit? Because when he came there was already inhabitants here. Right? But that was in the discoveries era. Now we have that controversy of did he discovered or found it?

The Island of Mozambique was classified has a WHS in 1991. The Mozambican civil war ended in 1992. You think it was a coincidence or there was a reason for this two dates?
Amade – I don’t believe the two are related in that way because the civil war began in consequence of the disagreement between the leaders of two political groups. In which one of the parties didn’t agree with the only political party that existed that was FRELIMO. Reason why the political group RENAMO was formed and they started shooting each other.  And that didn’t affect nothing. After 1982, after the creation the Association of the Friends of the Island of Mozambique, founded with people from all over the country, the founder members. And in the meantime we were at war.

Dinho – We must see that the war only brought back the progress and the work that had been done. There was already a commission to restore the Island ready to begin the works.

Amade – Dr. Ricardo was the first person in charge of that office in 1973.

Dinho – So this caused a setback because the technicians that were already here on the Island in 1985 had to leave because the political and military situation was getting worse. It wasn’t safe anymore. So I think this caused a setback because the UNESCO should had classified the Island as a WHS already in the 80’s in 86/87. After the first report about the monuments and tangible heritage in the Island. The blue book, they made a blue book. That work, if there was no war, it would have already been recognized and the Island would be a WHS. I think the two are not related.

What do you think about the current state of the Hospital of the Island of Mozambique and the Fortress of San Sebastian [Fortaleza de São Sebastião]?
Dinho – There are both two historical buildings. And they are in a critical state regarding their conservation. My opinion about what the fates of the buildings should be is that they should separate the managing of the two buildings. I feel that they are “killing” one building for the other. They are killing the fortress for the museum. Like in the experience of other WHS cities, we should separate the fortress so that it has an independent management, apart from the museum because it only brings disadvantages for the fortress. I believe that the budgets the Government of Mozambique has for the museums, especially the Museum of the Island, that not being enough it always positive, can be reinforced. I would say that with or without the financial support a separated management should be created and then We should try to do the maximum we can and give another life to the fortress, not leaving it has it is. Even if they do a cleaning or if they paint or put a new door to reinforce the safety…after 1 or 2 months, the work is all gone because the fortress is in an abandonment state. Regarding the hospital, we should notice one thing. I’m not an architect but I’ve worked on a project and I was a city Councillor and a pioneer. I was a city Councillor for the area of construction and heritage. People talked already back then that the hospital structures are made of stone and lime and that the medicines will not adapted to those conditions…reasons that for me are absurd excuses. We have architects, we have those traditional materials that were used on the construction of the hospital. Why not use the same materials, restore and that’s it? Today there are specific rules for the construction of infrastructure for the Health Ministry, because of the equipment, humidity, it’s very delicate. We, talking about cutting-edge technology, we have fake walls with cast that I can isolate, not touching the original and existing wall, protecting them and creating good conditions for the operations room, to obey the rules that the Ministry has concerning these types of buildings. So abandoning the building…sometimes there are things that don’t need money to accomplishing things, to have a result.

Like Amade says, we must rehabilitate the man because as long we have people without knowledge we are going to keep messing it up, so we have to must stop people with that kind of conscience. For now we should made understand to every worker, every technician that the Island has particularities, a specific status, it has all these factors, because if we don’t give these the importance they need of course people don’t know, or saw it. They don’t know how things were made. So we must educate people to know how to use the materials and obey rules. I believe that part of the stone used in the constructions would come on boats but a large majority of the materials were taken from the island and from the continent. We should to allocate the resources that are unique to our heritage and this Island.

Amade – All is said.

On the Island of Mozambique can we talk about the existence of communities or a community?
Amade – Well, it is relative. Communities as in it can exist community X and community Y. I can give the example that exists the Muslim community and the Christian community, and the Hindu community, with only one person now, a resident. They have one important temple here and they do a big ceremony here.

Dinho – Hindus came from all over the world. It was declared by the Hindus for a particularity that this temple has. In other temples, they are a type of stone that is placed. But those ones aren’t placed by no one. They were born there, so that brought another dynamics to the place. Management was implemented in the temple. So annually a lot of Hindus from across the world come here to celebrate a mass.

Amade – Yes, but back to the question. I work since a long time in the community area. We always used the term “community” given that community includes all the social and cultural levels. I’m not, when I work with the community, going to discriminate, reason why we use the term community. When I speak on the radio I’m not talking only to the Catholics, not only to the Muslim, not only to the Hindus. I’m talking to everybody. To all of the community.

Dinho – If we want we can separate ourselves in numerous ways, in ethnicity, in men and women biologically speaking…but community, we are just one.

Amade – From all these organized groups that constitute a community I can exemplify with the existence of the associations. Each one has its members but they are part of the community of the Island of Mozambique. The community of the religious groups also belongs to the community of the Island of Mozambique, reason why we treat ourselves like this. The community includes the island itself and the continental area.

What do you consider to be your heritage?
Amade – All this flux. All of these cultural and traditional value that exists in this land that saw me growing.

Dinho – I would say that the Island of Mozambique is everyone’s heritage. But I would say that is MY personal heritage. I am from the Island. I was born here, this is my Island. It belongs to everybody. Talking about the monuments, talking about the beaches, the museums, and the tangible and intangible heritage is talking about my habits and traditions from the Island. I feel the Island is my heritage.

Do you have anything more to add, or a story that you would like to share?
Amade – I don’t have anything.

Dinho – I would say something. That the research work here on the Island is appearing. But the work of planning is taking a lot of years. They are all on paper. We want action. Realistic plans. We want work. We need that people don’t stop with the research and work. He only talks about the history of the Portuguese people. But when they arrived they found the Arabs there.  Where did the Arabs go? They went away because they didn’t feel safe given the militarist posture of the Portuguese when they arrived. They didn’t feel comfortable and they start leaving the island. Where did they go? He should start looking where they went. In the continental area. Search for evidence. Because for me, they are the ones that discovered the Island. How did they live, how they did do things, and how they faced the afterlife for me they were the ones to discover the Island? There is a lot of things and I would like to make an appeal, because all of the Island is what needs to be preserved. We need archaeological research because this Island is a mystery. As you may know, from the shipwrecks, the construction of this fortress, from Oriental Africa this is the biggest fortress in the area. The church of the Nossa Senhora do Baluarte was also the first church of this part of Africa. The lighthouse was the first one built. So they are a lot of elements in this Island that should be respect. If we had support or volunteers that could come from the private sector… I’m talking institutions like UNESCO, either NGO’s or companies related to this area of preservation and restoration…The Island needs to be restored because not only has visible structures on land as also in the bottom of the ocean. And there is also the natural heritage that the Island has, the reefs, the species, and the turtles…so we need specific protection on the Island of Mozambique for all of these things.

item.title: The Island by Hafiz Jamu
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Hafiz was a key part of these interviews shared on HeritageLab. He introduced me to several fellow community leaders, showed the pathways across all of the Island, was a interpreter, and most of all a partner during fieldwork. Finally, it was his time to get interviewed. Early in the morning, we sat by "O Escondidinho" and had a long chat on Heritage, the Island, and Identity.

Hafiz Jamu

Religious leader; President of the Associação Ilha de Moçambique, 46 years old
Excerpted · August 2017

About his background:
I embraced this cause of heritage protection, and heritage in general. What happens is that at the time I realized that there was a separation in the middle of the island between the island where the local population lives, the macuti part, and the part of the stone city that was where the Portuguese administration, the last component was the administration occupy this side. So I thought it was best to create a friendship between these two sides. During this process, it was important to look at the heritage as everyone's, and there I created an organization that should have its headquarters in the stone city part, in the richest part or most favoured part. When this part had only cultural component.

The Island of Mozambique was classified as World Heritage Site for two reasons: material heritage, the houses, and intangible heritage, the behavior and way of being of people - habits and customs, traditions, these sort of things... and that’s it. We are going to embrace it. Over time, I also realized that there was underwater heritage on the island of Mozambique. I went to a meeting and noticed several foreigners at war with each other. And why were they fighting between them? Then I realized that there was an underwater heritage that each wanted to dilapidate.

Interviewer: The community did not know it existed and the outsiders already knew and...
Hafiz Jamu: And they were already taking care of it. So when I went to find out more, I ended up joining that cause that I already had in the foundation (Ilha de Moçambique Foundation) and included the underwater heritage. One must also preserve this to bring benefits to the populations and of various orders, for tourism, tranquility, and peace. Create a friendly environment here on the Island of Mozambique where everyone participates and wins. Heritage is here for everyone.

But was not there a friendly environment before? Were the people divided among themselves?
H. J.: Well… The interests here... If you arrive here you feel that everything is friendly but after some time you realize that there are islands inside the Island. There are interests. Then we went into another dimension where I started to bump into the people who were exploring the underwater heritage. They were really taking it. I was young then. I was 23/24 years old when I realized that the heritage should not be sold, it should be preserved. We would benefit more and better if it was preserved and not sold. And not only would I benefit. The next generations that will stay here on the Island, will too.

So that's what got me excited and because of my interventions, Professor Roberto came to Maputo to talk to Unesco about the underwater heritage. And Unesco invited me to be in Maputo. Then I met Professor Robert Parthesius. The mayor was invited, the director of GACIM was also, and suddenly we were completely on different sides. At the time, in full meeting ... I pull it to one side, the county president pulling it to another and that "no, it cannot be done, cannot be sold! ..." And then I presented my vision at the time blurred but that interested Professor Robert. He had a friend Bill Jeffrey that was there too. And because of this interaction I was invited to participate in a training session, in an interaction on Robben Island with Jonathan Sharfman. There I learned more o what could be done, how it could be done, the best way, the good practices and that interested me. I’ve returned to the Island and started to discuss matters with a little more knowledge...

Discussing with who?
H. J.: With the government and here was a company that was doing the research...

Arqueonautas?
H. J.: Yes, Arqueonautas. So then I'd discussed it without information, but now I had knowledge.

And did Hafiz have the authority to discuss such things?
H. J.: Yes, yes, because of my religious side. So any meeting that happens on the Island, any subject that has to do with the island I’m invited... but I used to discuss with little information. Sometimes I would leave a meeting, because I’d said things I did not know... I was a kid... and I spoke with great euphoria. Then, if I had someone else who was also part of my cause, they would pick it up and employ it and I'd lose supporters and be weakened day after day. I was falling and falling. So I went to work with other NGOs but always at the local level. Once, it appeared a gentleman who employed me in an NGO. Under my contract, there was a conception that he had a social responsibility in the island so there are certain things that the NGO was not willing to do but they had to do because of this employee. So I included some ideas of heritage protection within that NGO. They used to support me, give me strength, I had a salary, I did not worry about my children's breakfast.

Then, I went through another training with Professor Robert Parthesius. He was calling me, giving me more inputs. I was in Dar es Salaam and met others with a cause just like mine. We staying in a network, in touch and we were discussing the issues. I was admitted to participate in the LinkedIn platform with specialists and professionals trained in sub-Saharan heritage. Once I said things... And the teacher explained who I was, that I was like that, to let me talk... Because I used to say things... But today I go there to read and I see that no... I should not talk that way...

But you were too hasty, was upset about things...?
H. J.: Yes I was annoyed. I did not see the Arqueonautas stop. I was young and had no means to make them stop, had no power…

And how did it stop?
H. J.: There were other forces that joined the cause, the case of Professor Ricardo (Teixeira Duarte) who is working now. And when he did, there was a need for civil society intervention, so I would show up - "We do not want to, it's not like that." And these things I've been learning, as one does research, on Robben Island. I got here and demanded - I want a report and so on. A report that brings an interpretation, a history, we want the objects in the museum to be able to observe, we want real knowledge of things.

They would come and…
H. J.: Exactly. They had things we did not even understand. No, this was loot and not research. Then Professor Ricardo appears and then they always said: if we leave, who is doing the things? So, Professor Ricardo fills this place. The Mozambican ability to do this research. It came to the consciousness of the government that they could not continue with this type of activity. And that’s it. Then came the Smithsonian. That it is here now. They came to say that they have the opportunity to fund this - okay.

They came here to “offer” funding or did Hafiz or someone fill out an application?
H. J.: No. Everyone already knew. It has to do with the interest in American slavery/”blackness”, because of President Obama, of the origins of black people... There is talk about a boat that left Mozambique in this part of the “blackness”. So the Smithsonian is keen to enter. The only thing is that we ... since I was part of an American NGO I did my part in attracting another form of intervention. Speaking to the American embassy, ​​talking to the Smithsonian ... But I never wrote anything. I just interacted with them orally, bridging. The Smithsonian comes and according to the formal side of things, the partnerships should be with Eduardo Mondlane University. Until then, it was planned that I would work with the program, according to the ambassador, because I was very involved with the process. But then I was not included. I presented a different way of doing things because I'm not an archaeologist or a scuba diver but the only function I wanted with that was to make society clearly included in the presentation of this heritage.

My organization… I could not make a foundation, but it is known as foundation. For me to make a foundation I needed a million dollars. What happens? To register the foundation I would have had to take some houses, some parts of the estate and suddenly there was a reaction: “Hafiz will keep this.” This is impersonal. “No, this is not mine.” According to the founding statutes, in case of diverting our interests from our foundation, the assets return to the state. It's not personal, I do not sell. But for me to be able to sign official documents I had to formalize an association. This I did. I managed to formalize it. There is an assembly of the traditional groups of the Island. It exists, it is registered.

Which groups?
H. J.: Association of Fishermen, tourism association, all associations, in principle those who are over 50 years old, who contribute to the culture and contribute to people's way of being. The second ones are the formal ones, which were already registered, i.e. Association Friends of the Island, of Fishermen, APETUR. These are three formal ones.

Do people who often form associations also have a religious background like Hafiz?
H. J.: Yes, they all do. Some of the formal ones do not have a religious character, but it is an association and works in the island. It has to do with the sea, there are the majority of the fishermen. At the time it had not to do with the sea, it had to do with employability. The whole island lives on fish and salt. These are the two industries that employ the largest number of people. These are the economic engines, selling fish and producing salt outside the Island.

We have included the Association Friends of the Island because it is the oldest association, there are people there with interests for heritage conservation and interests for the development of the Island. We also included the Association of Goldsmiths and Craftsmen. All the ancient craftsmen are there in that association and are founding members of the foundation and have seat. Let us have a letter saying that so-and-so is our representative, who can come and have a vote. In total we are 17 groups, each with a seat, and a vote. What happens is that we are looking for support, just to be able to keep running it. And to be able to protect other things around the Island according to the emergency of the moment.

Are you satisfied with the current situation of the Island, considering the stakeholders who are acting at the moment?
H. J.: Yes, in terms of stop selling heritage yes. I am not satisfied with the inclusion of civil society. It is not being conducted, there is much to be done. We are saying that the Arqueonautas’s stop is only of conscience is not legal. It only is legal from the moment that Mozambique signs the agreement for the Convention for the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage. Only there it is legal. Now this whole process involves the production of laws, discussion of laws, disclosure of laws, disclosure of modalities, forms and this can not be done to 80% with outsiders, it has to be with people here, we have to be trained for this process . We will evolve institutionally in this process and then we will continue. I had an agreement at the time to share information across the Indian Ocean, from Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique, me, Kenya, Tanzania, Seychelles, Madagascar. We are a network of people who are trained how to conserve heritage, we share experiences, formalities.

To learn from each other.
H. J.: Exactly. We are all enrolled in ICCROM. What is missing from us here is to start having an institutional capacity, so that my colleagues can understand what is this about heritage conservation. We talk about this but, for example, the Smithsonian did not listen to us. They are more interested in ships. But there is a subsystem of these ships, of this ship, which has like others, society is not even involved in conservation.

Do you think that people generally care about conservation of the Island, or do not care because they are not aware.
H. J.: They are not aware.

You think that if they had knowledge, that it would be different.
H. J.: Yes. In this situation we have to realize that I keep heritage and I do not sell it. If I sell I have 100 immediate meticais (local currency). But if I do not sell it, I can have 20 meticais every day for a long time and this heritage is still “mine”. It continues here. Selling low price but it is still here. This is the way that the conservation, the preservation is confirmed. It achieves certain things that are often not spoken in meetings. The fact that I feel proud of myself, of my race, of my history, and that the idea that I am a citizen of the third world is not preserved, because I am black, because I have been through the process of slavery. These are aspects that are never spoken of. We would like that archaeology would help us jump that wall. That is the mission of my organization. Bust this wall, that gap between the most benefited and the less benefited, the enslaved and the colonizers. That no.

And how do you intend to materialize it?
H. J.: It's what I do on a daily basis. I created this organization where all the organizations are there. They keep learning. They should have an institution where they could work and be involved in these processes.

Do people adhere to the associations on the Island?
H. J.: Not now. Before it was more that I belonged to the association and had friends in others. Not anymore. Few. The involvement of young people in associativity has greatly diminished.

Why?
H. J.: There are no stimuli for associativity. We have a room there that should have computers and create three or four young people who are fit for this or that. Now we have a fair – go. Now we have a child recruitment event. Wealth is all here to produce everything. It's all here. All that is needed is the push for things to happen gradually.

Do you think that the coming of outsiders contributes to your mission of destroying the walls?
H. J.: In the way that is being done right now, no. That's why I do not even participate. Not like this. It has no sustainability. When they go, it's over.

But they are with students from the University of Mondlane, Maputo.
H. J.: Yes, and they will stay in Maputo. It does not have sustainability. They go to Maputo and have their life there. It’s not sustainable to call Maputo and say “ah here's a boat!"... No. Like all the other projects on the Island. They modified the Island. They came here, they did. The islanders did not kept anything. There is no sustainability.

Do you think the Island of Mozambique has changed over time, especially after the WHS classification?
H. J.: Yes. The classification of UNESCO has brought negative things. I can only say the following: people, foreigners realized the values of the houses. The islanders only now. We are almost 20 years into it and it is only now that the value of the islands is in the houses, it is in the people. And these people have already changed because, the social free society changes...

Are people becoming more skeptical of outsiders?
H. J.: Exactly. Formerly when someone came from outside, there were receptions, they received people and they were happy and they said: “I was never as welcome as on the Island of Mozambique”. Not now. People are more and more... “Another thief coming”.

So, you are not at all pleased with what is happening on the Island.
H. J.: The way it's being done is no. It is not as we had idealized.

Cannot schools be involved, such as by extra-curricular activities?
H. J.: It’s possible to do it all. All this can be done. What's upsetting me is this. As long as there are some defrauded/scammed people, certain people have been involved. Now there is no fraud/scam. These people are outside. What is the feeling of these people? We should have made a fool of ourselves in the fraud. We should have been part of the scam. Because maybe so maybe we could have been involved. There was no dissatisfaction. All the people who took part in with me say, “So Hafiz, were we involved in this?” No... so...?

So nothing.
H. J.: So nothing. So those who came again turned their backs on us. How do I turn this fire off? Let's see.

Can you give me some concrete example of what you say?
H. J.: For example, civil society, those who were part of the pressure for the Arqueonautas to leave here should have the opportunity to be given more training on the process and to be the sentinels of the patrimony. This has to happen. But there has to be a place where they can stay. Any place with authority. If the president wants to do some things, they can do anything to intervene and influence that decision.

Is not GACIM supposed to do that?
H. J.: GACIM serves this purpose, yes. But in fact what that does not happen. It is the deciding authority. But who influences the decisions they make? Civil society is not involved, what is it all about? "Ah, it's to be in the museums." Do local people go to museums? No, they do not. People also do not realize that the whole Island is a museum. For us the walls of the museum, are familiar, are things that we do not appreciate. My walk on the Island, is already part of the museum and I'm not there with a mirror to look at myself. No one goes to the museum. That is ours, we live it, we live together. No one comes here to say "I'm going to enjoy Escondidinho (name of a hotel). I'll visit and meet Escondidinho." No, this is my way of seeing.

But do you think museums should not exist?
H. J.: No, no! That's for the ones who comes.

In the Island there are boys who offer themselves as guides, for guided tours around the Island, telling the history of Mozambique. That is, there are young people interested in history. What fails between their interest in history and belonging to an association to carry out projects?
H. J.: They will join an association when they see the benefits of it. It is a way of life where people do not join forces to reach a world. Each one is by itself. I can offer myself to help the guides and then…? What am I going to do? I'm going to give the sandals for them to wear but I cannot give just to one, I have to give to a group. “Ah but we are not a group, we are an association.” But do you get together to promote advocacy for heritage conservation? Zero! Do you hold an assembly and then determine the matters that are part of heritage conservation? Zero.

The protection of heritage on the Island, for the time being, is due to the shared efforts of many individuals. Individual efforts.
H. J.: Yes. Always with interests of sale and foreign benefit. But not for the benefit of all people. This is what we want to do, things for a lot of people. Now we have this building, it stands still. You're coming for example. The foundation has a part office, a zone like that painted and another one that is not so clean, is under construction. For the community people who come to do studies it would be nice that benefited the island. A person that comes here to study and instead of staying at a hotel, he's coming in and we're getting through. Now if there is any course, tell us that money is not for us to take, not to eat. It is to maintain the building, to use the building for the people themselves. Because it is. It was from the state but now we assure it. If it was the government would have sold out and turned hotel.

Do they also have people formally trained in heritage studies working at GACIM?
H. J.: Of course! And if they do not have them, call the university and say: we have a vacancy for this sector.

And someone will come for sure.
H. J.: Why not? They have money to fund this. The government has money to fund the technician's salary. We don’t. We are only here to watch, so that is the question. It was better if we had join the process with Arqueonautas. No, no, no, no…

Then people also begin to lose faith because they see that nothing changes.
H. J.: Nothing changes and will become general. But this is like a time bomb. People will get to a point and say "Let us also steal". Let it go. Oh, this has to stop. Because? This does not work. But it was good that we had a chance. Civil society. Tell me what you think of it. Three components: we should be empowering for example community policing, because in fact the island of Mozambique, there is a bay (starts sketching on a map). All this zone including this one in the sea that is of our interest. From this corner to this corner has to be policed. Because there are many shipwrecks here. Others were shot and continued to flee and ended up here. This area has to be patrolled all over.

And nowadays they only focus on the Island of Mozambique.
H. J.: Exactly. And people who are not from the Island, are from Maputo.

But what does patrolling mean? Policemen or normal people patrolling.
H. J.: People who are studying heritage and at the same time protect. Or even fishermen. Fishermen who, using their natural side to deal with the sea, are aware that no one here can touch the water that is there. “Look, there's a boat and such. What is this?” And we'll talk to the authorities. Do not touch it. It's possible. Creating archaeological sites is a beautiful place to create tourism.

Because Mozambique does not have many archaeological sites.
H. J.: Underwater archaeological stations. For example, there is now a dive with Ricardo. If there are tourists we do ... I lived through these things, I lived it, not of this in concrete but of the sort. We got there and asked, how many tourists are there? I would take 16 people there to Macuti and pick them up at the hotels. This same formula can be used. If there is a dive here, that is already sealed the station, is in service, let's go there, let's watch the excavation, we get down there and we see the excavation happening, to work. It is happening and you do not touch. You do not play because there's someone to control them.

It's like a museum.
H. J.: Exactly. This is tourism. This is it.

But these are things that take a long time. Even for example in Portugal where people have a higher literacy rate and there are many more archaeologists, people continue to carry artifacts home, or to melt gold pieces they find…
H. J.: Yes ... So are these things that ... When this group is trained here within the organization there are already 3/4 people who are not even in uniform. Community service. Who supervises everything that goes on. I've been to Zanzibar. You come to a beach and you see young people playing football. And four of them are cops. You do not cross with any police on the street, but you're quiet. Someone's on the street and picked up your briefcase, it is taking it. Two young people, others follow and pick it back.

So you think Zanzibar is a good example of what the Island of Mozambique can and should be.
H. J.: Yes. Security and tourism, a boiling industry. A calm city, everything very well controlled. At night you see no one. But if someone makes a mistake, a crime, soon someone appears to touch you and say no, do not do this.

But do you consider the Island of Mozambique dangerous?
H. J.: No, no. Now, by chance, they took my computer. But when they steal the computer and it's like five thefts in a year. But one has to feel secure. The tourist has to feel safe. Only this impact brings more people. Then we sell the archaeological things several times. There are several factors that have to ... It is a strategy in which several points have to correspond to moles.

Foreigners think Island of Mozambique it's a dangerous place at war...
H. J.: Yes, yes. That's why taking people to macuti was my job. Because it was said that if you went to the macuti zone they would steal your camera. But it was a lie. I would take the people there. The people can go to the macuti area to walk around, this is good. We already won.

The fortress of São Sebastião is now empty. Do you think it's a good solution or one should rehabilitate the space? And if so, with what?
H. J.: Several things can happen there. As long as they are not things ... or one can fill the space but one must go giving that house a smile, a feeling that that building was a military house. It is neither a residence nor a palace, it is a military house and of repression. He participated heavily in the slavery process. It took about 90 years to be built and I do not know why but nobody likes the house, in fact, we the population. It is as if in our subconscious we knew that we suffer there then we must take advantage of that space but we must wash its face. The house has to have a warm smile. "Ah, do a school there" but be careful you have to do something else. It cannot happen for example a party, because when you have a party there ... And the house is happy, for moments. It can be done for example in a corner a museum, a little thing there ... but the house cannot be closed to parties.

And do parties take place there?
H. J.: Yes, yes. The last festivals happened there. Whatever we want to do there, we have to take into account for the party to happen.

It has to be joyous things.
H. J.: Yes. The party has to happen in there.

Do you think there is a great weight in the history of slavery here on the Island that people feel? Or in general do not care.
H. J.: They no longer care about that. So much. When there is discussion, people of this family and such. Because once the process was over, some people were assimilated, they were taken over by family. I remember my father had someone who walked with him and my father told us that, I know this young man, this gentleman, from my childhood, was with me my whole life. When my father became ill, that gentleman lay down on the floor, my father in the hospital. He lay on the ground and only left when my father left. He was actually their slave, given by my grandfather's father who had a slave. If my father did not do his homework, it was him that would be punished, not my father. It was this gentleman. But how did we treat him? By uncle. He was not my father's brother, he was not family but we treated him as if he were family. He later lost his sight and my sister took care of him and took him to the hospital for cataract surgery. We treated him like family. That's just to say that in other families it happened like that. And they say the origin of that person is that. The behaviour of that family comes from there. We do not talk, but we do.

And you think it's important to talk?
H. J.: Evil is talking about knocking down other people, not that. But we can talk about healing the wound and making the person more productive. I liked that. Making the person with more love. Make you more cheerful, more loving, more, much more. It is always good, now talk about the hurt of others not.

What does the Island mean to you?
I do not know. I'm connected in a way ... I'm supposed to die here, there's no way to avoid that. It is the legacy of my grandfathers. I would love to get out of here and live my youth life and break life and walk around. But responsibility is ingrained in my life, it is done, I cannot give it up. It is as if my father's name goes out, my existence goes out. No, no. I have conflicts with my children for example and... you have to take care of this. You have to stay here. And they say "no no, we already studied and we want to go to our life". And just one that shows willingness to stay but suddenly ... let's see ... it is a big challenge. But it's a mistake again that my parents did not tell me. I'm telling them. My parents did not tell me. I felt guilty, it is probably the mistake I'm making.

What is your opinion of UNESCO presence here on the island?
H. J.: I think that once again the problem is sustainability. UNESCO did not really play a big role. Unesco has small grants that it gives. NGOs and usually someone cames from the south, wins a scholarship, come here, and set up. Now when UNESCO wants to come here to do punctual work, they use that office. It is not a UNESCO office. Then there was a scholarship that UNESCO gave three years to an NGO, I forgot the name. And they developed the works here. I've never seen UNESCO office here. To have an office here means to have a lady secretary with contract with UNESCO, a project manager, program manager and a coordinator of UNESCO activities. I never saw.

I thought there had been an office here with a small representation of UNESCO.
H. J.: It was from an NGO that had a contract with UNESCO. Now one thing is for sure. If they had given this contract to a local NGO, these technicians could have come to work for us on the island today, but the interaction of the office had been with an island lady, an island guard who actually practices island acts and that office would be alive. And that information would be on the Island, with the islanders. The office closed and what was left? Nothing. Lack of sustainability.

Does the island of Mozambique have any tourist centers?
H. J.: USAID helped to create one. But suddenly the council took over and the building exists. Missing is riding.

But you feel that there is no interest of the municipality in carrying out these initiatives...
H. J.: It's in the system. Interest exists. But they want someone from outside to finance, they have the money to do. Did someone need to come out and create a tourist information center? No, this is not normal. The idea exists, the building exists...

Where is the center situated?
H. J.: By the bridge. The building exists, it was built.

So it was built especially to be a tourist center.
H. J.: Yes. People exist. The will exists in people. But for this, people are always that something to happen has to be by the foreigner. That's where everything does not fit.

Do you feel that there are divisions between the two sides of the city?
H. J.: There is a clear division between sides. Whoever is on this side (Stone Town) is considered more non-genuine.

So what can I do to be useful here these days?
H. J.: Institutional capacity building. These main objectives were the training, the social pressure here, for the country to sign the convention and this convention to be fragile in the community, to have an impact. Desired impact protection of underwater heritage. And then the buildings are the entrance door, to improve the quality of life, the entrance door is tourism, from income for families...

item.title: A perspective on diaspora, Identity and Macuas
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
This is an excerpt from the interview with Hafiz Jamu, in 2017.

Interviewer: What do you think of the way museums, on the Island of Mozambique, are made?
Hafiz Jamu: That is not our story. It is not the history of these people. It is the history of the colonizers. This does not matter to us. I told Professor Ricardo at the last meeting, I was with a teacher from Coimbra in partnership with the University of Lírio to organize a small workshop and they did it on the island.

Last week.
H. J.: Right. In his presentation, he said a lot “The Portuguese people ..!”

Look teacher sorry but I'm not interested in knowing the history of Portugal. Firstly because I am not Portuguese and according to I am not looking for history of Portugal, this is already well studied. I do not know the history of the Macua people. That's what interests me. Any relation of Macuas with other peoples of the world. That's what matters to me. I am not against the Portuguese, no. I'm saying that...

Yes, I understand. I like to know the history of my country and Hafiz also wants to know the history of yours.
H. J.: I like the Tagus River. Yes, I like to listen to it. I'll go and see some day. One day if I have money and am on vacation I will go there to see it. But I'm not going to Portugal, to know the river I'll see the river that is 50 kilometers away. I want to know about my people. What happens; what were the problems; how do these problems relate to today's history? Why is it that if I do not know how to use the cutlery, people say, "You do not know how to use cutlery because you are Macua"? Where does these ideas come from? Why is that word is used in the pejorative sense to mess with me? Why is saying that you are Macua is the same as saying you are not civilized? Why? Archaeology must have a clear interpretation of this.

Are there more stereotypes like that?
H. J.: Yes there are. This is so harsh that even Mozambican people in the South know it too. People think the Macua is a third-class citizen.

Where are the Macuas?
H. J.: They are in many areas. It is the largest tribe in Mozambique, the largest, occupying more space. In the south, we have a Ronga and Massena tribe, but these tribes are sometimes three within a province or two, a lot of concentration. Not with the Macuas. Macuas occupy 4 provinces that are much more extensive. These kinds of sayings are many. They occupy a larger area than the others.

How do people here on the island of Mozambique identify themselves? Like Macuas or like from the Island of Mozambique?
H. J.: Macuas, are a Naharra variant. Macuas are in northern Mozambique, from the province of Zambézia; all of Nampula, 60/70%; of the province of 60/70% of Cabo Delgado. They are all Macuas. Now inside the Macuas, there are variants. There is Macua more from the interior of Nampula; there is the Macua below the Zambezi River, Lonhé. The ones on the island are called Naharra. And why are they called that? The genuine Macuas come from the province of Nampula, because of migrations that came by boat, Arabs, also Portuguese. In the end, almost near independence or 100 years before, including the Portuguese only came men, without their wives. Sometimes because they practiced some crime in Portugal, or crime in other colonies and they came here and they would marry. This man would marry a Macua woman and have a son. He them would adapt the father’s education and speaking the language of the mother but already with some disturbances of language of the father. So that language that seems creole, that is, Naharra language mixes Macua language with Portuguese and Arabic. The Macua people of the interior speak pure Macua, does not mix. Naharra carries Portuguese and Arabic words. Mixture.

Has any special language program come up to study, classify or protect the language?
H. J.: No, no.

And you think it's necessary?
H. J.: I think yes. Languages ​​change over time. In this process of patrimony protection especially slavery, it was the University of Denmark Roskilde who invited a community called Zanzibari, which is in South Africa. They came to Zanzibar. They were invited to a conference. They are considered Zanzibar people. They went to Zanzibar under the pretext that they were returning home. By accident, the truth is that they invited me and I went to the meeting. I am very interested in traditional dances and such. So at the time of the interaction I went to talk to them. What language do you speak? What is the language of your land? Say something in your language. When they started talking I started talking to them. They were speaking the language of the Island of Mozambique. No, these people are not from Zanzibar, these people are from my land. These people are from my land. They are talking in Naharra and much purer than mine, better than my Macua. So they are not Tanzanians. They are Mozambicans and especially from the island of Mozambique because they were sold and the ship did not even leave South Africa and this cargo of slaves stayed there. They were cohesive.

The identity of Mozambique is widespread.
H. J.: Exactly. They stayed there and live in community and have habits and customs of the Island and from there I started. I continued to talk to them, keep in touch and some have come to stroll here, to see their homeland, already have houses there in the community, already marrying. But they do not speak Portuguese. They speak English and Macua.

It would be interesting to see where the community of the Island of Mozambique is dispersed. Also, not much attention is given to this.
H. J.: Yes. That's what I'm thinking with Robert Parthesius. Make the Island of Mozambique the research center for this, mainly because of its geographic location side. We are almost in the center from Kenya to Namibia, Somalia, and Quiloa. The Island of Mozambique is very well located. That's why the fortress and these things are here. So if we make the Island here the geopolitical center for the protection and conservation of the archaeological heritage, we pressure the government to sign the convention. From here it is much easier to reach to other points, including Yemem and India. My name is Hafiz Jamu. Jamu is Indian. We have Arabian and Indian blood as well. This whole area was what it was. History it is what it is. So it is possible to do these things, to do studies. I arrived a few days ago. I always lived in a small house and such, I stayed there for 20 years. But now my mother passed away and I inherited a house the size of the Escondidinho. I have a house this size this way. It's from my grandparents. It should be 300/400 years old. There was a room that was never opened and I opened. I found little things, chairs, saw the models of things, the lathe that is Arabic, and other half Indian and other clay pots ... a mixture of things and utensils.

item.title: Church/Chapel of Santo António
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
On the edge of the beach, on one of the highest grounds of the Island and framed by palm trees, lies the Church (sometimes also referred to as Chapel) of Santo António, from the sixteenth century. Erected on an old defensive redoubt, the Church is walled and built in stone masonry, with wooden doors. It comprises one chamber and one chancel, facing South-West.

It underwent rebuilding works in 1810 and 1969.

Bibliography to know more:
Cid, Isabel (1992) - O livro das plantas de todas as fortalezas, cidades e povoações do estado da Índia oriental de António Bocarro. Lisboa: Imprensa Nacional Casa da Moeda.
Dias, Pedro (1998) - História da Arte Portuguesa no Mundo. Espaço do Índico. Lisboa, pp. 356-380.
Loureiro, João (2001) - Postais Antigos da Ilha de Moçambique & da Ilha do Ibo. Lisboa, pp. 49, 73, 92, 105.

item.title: Chapel Nossa Senhora do Baluarte
item.dc:creator: Veronica
item.content:encoded:
Surrounded by the high walls of Fort São Sebastião and the infinitude of the Indian Ocean, lies the Chapel Nossa Senhora do Baluarte, continuously splashed by salt water and fustigated by erosion.

The Chapel Nossa Senhora do Baluarte dates from the sixteenth century (1522). Architecturally, it is built in Manueline style, being the only one of its kind, in a good state of conservation, in all Subsaarian regions of Africa. It is also considered to be the oldest European construction in the southern hemisphere, holding at least 12 underground tombs.
Its structure is made of stone masonry and inside we find a single chamber, the slab flooring, and roofing tiles. In the nineteenth century, an external porch was added to the structure, probably on Indo-Portuguese influence, and, in 1996, the chapel went on rehabilitation works.

In 2019, cyclone Idai inflicted severe damages to the structure of the Chapel. Rehabilitation works are intended to start in 2023.

The access is done via Fort São Sebastião, in the northern limit of the Island of Mozambique, as the chapel is located on one of its bastions.

Bibliography to know more:

Lobato, Alexandre (1966) - A Ilha de Moçambique. Panorama Estético. Lisboa.
Rau, Virgínia (1963) - Aspectos étnico-culturais da Ilha de Moçambique em 1822. Lisboa.
Dias, Pedro (1998) - História da Arte Portuguesa no Mundo. Espaço do Índico. Lisboa, pp. 356-380.
Loureiro, João (2001) - Postais Antigos da Ilha de Moçambique & da Ilha do Ibo. Lisboa, p. 91.

item.title: Hagia Sophia
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Hagia Sophia, the third Christian basilica on this site, was built in 537, was converted into a mosque in 1453 and became a museum in 1934, following a decision taken by Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, the founder of the Turkish Republic. Subsequently, the multi-faceted values of its multi-layered history were revealed, and the building has been open for the public to admire the unique beauty of its architecture and art (https://www.europanostra.org/)

item.title: Al Ajami Neighborhood
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
Al Ajami is all that is left of Jaffa

Cosmopolitan luxurious neighborhood

Al Ajami was the most affluent neighborhood, with luxurious villas, cinemas, theatres, a big range of cafés, sports clubs, schools, a private hospital, banks, car dealers, pharmacies, shopping streets, public baths, a church, a mosque, community centers, and gardens. Some of the villas were nearly 500 square meters and had spacious high-domed halls and marble floors. Here lived the mayors, editors-in-chief, heads of Jaffa’s Chamber of Commerce, members of The Citrus Board, doctors, engineers, bankers, orchard owners, and film directors. Sandwiched between orange groves to the east and the sea to the west, the neighborhood was home to cosmopolitan and urban Muslim and Christian Jaffans. The Ajamis were often involved in the import and export businesses, in the press, in politics, and in culture. They were the city’s connection to networks both regionally and internationally.

Beauty and the Beast

While Jaffa was under attack in 1948, workers such as fishermen, sailors, small business owners, bakers, teachers, and most of the Jaffans had to stay in their city until the end. Most Jaffans were turned into refugees in one night. The 97% of the nearly 120,000 Jaffans that turned refugees, their children and grandchildren, are scattered all over the world. When Jaffa was occupied most Jaffans were pushed to the sea and arrived in Gaza or Lebanon. Gaza’s population comprises about 85% refugees from all over Palestine, but a substantial part of today’s Gazans are from nearby Mediterranean Jaffa. Gaza is the biggest Jaffa today. Gaza today, 66 kilometers from Jaffa, has been living under siege since 2007, and this includes its Jaffan refugees. Jaffan refugees in Gaza, live behind barbed wire, walls, and blockades from sea, air, and land. According to the UN, Gaza has been technically unlivable since 2020. Other Jaffans ended up in refugee camps all over the region and are registered refugees of the UNRWA. As much as 80% of the population of Balata refugee camp east of Nablus, is originally from Jaffa.

Al Ajami residents were richer than others and many left before the city fell. They lost their luxurious homes, villas, businesses, orchards, lands, and offices but they had money and networks. Yet nearly without exception, all the crème de la crème of Jaffa was involved in the resistance and the defense of their city, already from the 1930s.

European import, the Ghetto

In 1948, there were 120,000 Jaffans, 80,000 in the city itself, and 40,000 in smaller towns and villages in its vicinity whose work and livelihood were connected to the city. On May 13, 1948, Jaffa caved after a three-week siege by Zionist paramilitaries and was ethnically cleansed. Jaffa fell and 97% percent of its population disappeared. Only 3,900 Jaffans remained and they were rounded up in Al Ajami neighborhood. In one night, Al Ajami was transformed from a luxurious neighborhood into a military prison camp, complete with barbed wire, guard dogs, and a military curfew that lasted for two years – (although military rule didn’t end until 1966). Jaffa shrank in one night, in its population and its geography. The Israeli government soon built a wall that closed off the neighborhood and placed guards and dogs on the periphery. Residents of the neighborhood were not allowed to leave without a permit and had no access to the sea. The new state named the neighborhood ‘Ghetto’, a foreign term in Arabic, a concept brought from Europe. 'Ghetto' described the exact opposite of what Al Ajami was. Labeling the most luxurious neighborhood of Palestine ‘Ghetto’ was not a description, it was a plan.

Wrong ethnicity

Overnight, Jaffa the heart of Palestine, stopped beating. Merchants were denied access to their shops. Families were prevented from returning to their homes. Israel declared all the surrounding countries as enemies. If you looked for family members who fled and were refugees now in nearby countries, you were contacting enemies and would be punished by law. The State of Israel decided that the remaining 3,900 Jaffans, who were rounded all up now in Al Ajami, had to share the homes they were in, with the new occupying settlers. Indigenous Jaffan families lived in one room and had to share bathrooms, toilets, kitchens, balconies, pots, and pans, often mattresses and sheets, with their newly arrived occupiers. The Jaffans’ world disintegrated. There was no workplace to go to, the new employers wanted Jewish workers. Palestinian Jaffan children missed school for a few years. Stuffed in one room without employment or a place to go to, with no knowledge of the whereabouts of their family members who had fled, while their occupiers were sitting on their sofa, the remaining Jaffans were living a second trauma. Depression, hopelessness, violence, unemployment, and drugs- were the fruit of such conditions. Abed Abu Shehadeh, (a Jaffan who was a member of the Tel Aviv- Jaffa city council), explains that in the 1950s and 1960s, Ajami was probably the most dangerous neighborhood in the new State of Israel. Up until the 1980s, most families had at least one drug addict among them. A state that had taken over a whole land, could not take care of 3,900 indigenous Jaffans.

Absent by law

Homes and buildings, whose owners fled the occupation, were looted. Then they were confiscated under the 1950 Israeli Absentee law. Every house and building in Palestine of each refugee was confiscated. “Absentee” did not only mean refugees who were outside Israel, it often meant people who were not present when the decision was made, even if they lived nearby, such people who lost their homes and ownership are called "Absent Present". In addition, all public property, buildings, and land, were confiscated. Jaffa’s refugees accounted for 15% of Palestinian refugees in 1948. Their ownership of houses and buildings was moved to Israeli public housing companies such as Amidar. One year after Jaffa fell, in 1949, Jaffan Palestinians made up less than 2% of their city.

Welcome to Bulgaria

In 1959, Israeli journalist and writer Nathan Dunevich wrote that Bulgarians replaced Jaffans and Jaffa had turned into little Bulgaria. In the 60s and 1970s, the state of Israel destroyed 50% of the Ajami neighborhood, 70% of the old part of the city, and 100% of the Manshiyya neighborhood. Al Ajami is all that is left of Jaffa. Al Ajami was systematically neglected and left to fall apart. It became full of social trouble- and the “Ghetto” project succeeded. Al Ajami became a neighborhood riddled with poverty and crime. The city of Tel Aviv used to be one suburb of thriving Jaffa. After destroying most of Jaffa, Tel Aviv swallowed the rest and turned Jaffa into its “Ghetto” suburb. In the 2010s, Al Ajami with its historic buildings became hip and chic. The media started describing Al Ajami as: “authentic”, “historic”, "eclectic" and “nostalgic”. Beneath this layer of hip and chic nostalgia lies a reality of taking over what was left of Jaffa. In 1985, Tel-Aviv started planning Jaffa and ordered a master plan for Ajami 2036. “The aim was “to bring a beautiful Greek village type that spills into the sea” Emily Silverman (Jaffa: A Guide to Gentrification, film 2022 by Keren Shayo and Lavi Vanounou).

Ethnic Gentrification 

Al Ajami’s history is the transformation from one extreme to the other. The gentrification of Al Ajami brings the change full circle, back with expensive villas for millionaires. In the early 2000s, hundreds of  Al Ajami’s Palestinian residents started receiving demolition and “vacate” orders. This time, gentrification is not only about money and so-called class, it is about the last 3% of Jaffa's original Palestinian population.

Jaffans are facing a strong ethnogentrification, a process turning Jaffa into a fully Jewish city, (for context, in 1850 Palestine had about 350,000 inhabitants, 30% of whom lived in 13 towns. The percentage of Jews in Palestine was 4%. Like Muslim and Christian Palestinians, the Jews were also called Palestinian Ottomans. In 1886 Jaffans consisted of 16,900 Palestinian Arabs and 100 European Jews. In 1931 there were 44,638 Palestinian Arabs and 7,209 Palestinian Jews.)

Today the neighborhood’s most iconic buildings are listed as properties for sale on Sothby’s, or for stays on Airbnb. The Jaffan owners of each of these homes and buildings, (even when they still hold the ownership documents), cannot claim their homes, cannot buy their own homes back, and while the whole world is open to book a stay on Airbnb, the owners of these Jaffan homes cannot even sleep in their homes as tourists in, since most are not allowed even to visit Jaffa. The very few original Jaffans are fighting for their right to stay in their city.
