item.title: Jaffans Bounce Back: History of Resistance in Jaffa
item.dc:creator: Sarah
item.content:encoded:
Resisting the Pharaos 1460 BC

The first resistance of the Jaffans that we have archeological evidence of, is from around 1460 B.C.E. to 1125 B.C.E. when the pharaonic New Kingdom conquerors ruled Jaffa. In 1472 BC, Pharaoh Thutmose III of the Eighteenth Dynasty occupied Jaffa. They arrived with a small fleet of 400 men and a smuggled 200 soldiers inside Jaffa hidden in giant jars. This was a way older story than The Trojan Horse. The result was occupation and resistance. Bent arrowheads and a massive destruction layer of burned mud bricks found under the collapsed tower at the Ramesses Gate, attest that the Canaanites bitterly opposed Egyptian rule in Jaffa, which reached its peak during the 12th century B.C.E. Layers of fiery destruction in ancient Jaffa bear witness to the violent Canaanite resistance to Egyptian rule over the seaside city thousands of years ago.

On the 3rd of March 1799, the French laid siege to the city of Jaffa which was under Ottoman control. Jaffans resisted fiercely inside a walled city against a modern army. Napoleon attacked with cannons and the French had a variety of innovative rifles, pistols, sabers, and axes. For four days, the Jaffans resisted, but on the 7th of March, Jaffa City fell to the French. Napoleon allowed his soldiers to slaughter and rape for two days and two nights. The French slaughtered about 2500-4000 people and the sick French army spread the plague. 

1834 — Muhammad Ali Pasha (The Ottoman Ruler of Egypt) Destroys Jaffa

The Peasants’ Revolt in Palestine was a moment of political unity in Palestine. It was a revolt of all Palestinians from different classes, subcultures, geographical areas, and religions. The peasants and townspeople refused to supply the Egyptian ruler with a fifth of males of fighting age. This was the first of modern successions of revolts against foreign occupiers—against the British from 1936 to 1939 and against the Zionists in the 1940s and 1948. 

The urban notables of Palestinian cities, including Jaffa and its surroundings did not carry out Ibrahim Pasha's orders. On May 24th, Ibrahim Pasha departed from Jaffa with 9,000 soldiers on his way to capture Jerusalem. The next day, thousands of Jaffans and other rebels left Jaffa to attack Ibrahim Pasha's forces on their way. The five-hour trip, took two days while the rebels attacked the Egyptian troops, killing at least 500 soldiers. By June 8th, many crucial cities as well as Jaffa were in full rebellion. On June 30th, Muhammad Ali landed in Jaffa with 15,000 troops from Egypt. Ali personally ordered the decapitations of the governors of Ramla and Lydda and of the headmen of rebellious villages near Jaffa. The Mutasellem or the tax collector of Jaffa was beheaded. The administrator of Jaffa and his son were beheaded. Jaffa's urban notables, who backed the rebels fled by boat into exile to the island of Cyprus. 

This revolt reduced the male population of Palestine by about one-fifth. Muhammad Ali Pasha demanded a fifth of the fit male population, between May and August in 1834 he left with a fifth of the fit male Palestinian population dead or exiled.

1936-39  — The British destroy Jaffa

The Great Palestinian Rebellion  Or The Great Arab Revolt

The Great Palestinian Rebellion or The Great Arab Uprising was against the British administration of the Palestine Mandate, demanding Arab independence and the end of Jewish immigration as the League of Nations had authorized in 1922. The discovery of a shipment of arms, in October 1935, in the Jaffa port destined for the Haganah organization, fueled Palestinian concerns that the Zionist movement was aiming at a military takeover of their land. In reaction, a six-month general strike of the Palestinian population totally stopped the county. The British banned all Palestinian political parties, political and community leaders were arrested, and a number of high-profile public figures were exiled. British tanks, airplanes, and heavy artillery were deployed throughout Palestine. The British also meted out collective punishment: thousands of Palestinians were relegated to “detention camps”; residential quarters were destroyed; schools were closed; villages were collectively fined and forced to billet British troops and police. 

A British commission toured the country to see what was at hand. In 1937, the Peel Commission recommended the partition of Palestine into an Arab and a Jewish state. The Palestinian population relaunched their armed insurgency with renewed intensity, initiating the second phase of the revolt. Curfews were imposed in Jaffa, the uprising's first urban flashpoint, sometimes confining the whole population to their homes for twenty-two hours a day. The most extraordinary demolitions in 1936 came in June at Jaffa, where British forces razed much of the Old City to pave the way for military access roads. Issa El Sifri a Jaffan youth activist, compared the events to an earthquake and estimated that over one thousand dwellings and ancillary buildings were destroyed, putting ten thousand people out on the street. A later researcher counted roughly 650 families whose homes were destroyed and another 1,150 families that temporarily or permanently evacuated – rendering approximately one-sixth of the Arab population of Jaffa homeless. Although the demolitions destroyed a critical rebel sanctuary, local partisans continued. While Jaffa bore the brunt of the state's increasingly militarized response to the strike, other cities also became sites of urban warfare. Palestine's British garrison grew during the strike from two battalions to twenty-two, and the army took over schools throughout the country for use as barracks and bases, further contributing to the militarization of urban space. Jaffans faced searches over the next months, with hundreds detained afterward. The entire city's male population (boys included), was searched and processed in cage screenings at the local military base. From July 1937, until the fall of 1938, witnessed significant gains by the Palestinian rebels. Large swaths of the hilly Palestinian interior, including for a time the Old City of Jerusalem, fell fully under rebel control. Rebels established institutions, most significantly courts, and postal service, to replace the British Mandate structures they sought to dismantle. 

By early 1939, members of the Jewish Settlement Police in Palestine (about 14,000) were subsidized, uniformed, and armed by the British government, Special Night Squads comprising of Jewish and British members launched “special operations” against Palestinian villages. The ranks of British and Jewish policemen swelled and Palestinians were subjected to house searches, night raids, beatings, imprisonment, torture, and deportation. The British called in military reinforcements. In 1939, more Palestinians were killed, more were executed (by hanging), and nearly twice as many were detained than in 1938.  Over the revolt's three years, some 5,000 Palestinians had been killed and nearly 15,000 wounded. The Palestinian leadership had been exiled, assassinated, and imprisoned. 

The Great Palestinian Rebellion in numbers:

25,000 to 50,000 British soldiers 

20,000 Jewish policemen, supernumeraries, and settlement guards 

15,000 Haganah militants

2,883 Palestine Police Force, all ranks (1936) 

2,000 Irgun militants 

The result of the revolt was: 

5,000 Palestinians killed 

15,000 Palestinians wounded 

108 Palestinians executed 

12,622 Palestinians detained

5 Palestinians exiled

Zionists Lay a Three-Week Siege to Jaffa and it Falls 

On 14 May 1948, many parts of the city are destroyed and 97% of the inhabitants are ethnically never allowed to return. Of the about 120,000 residents, only 3,900 Jaffans stay in the historic city.

item.title: Underground Women's Resistance
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
Zahrat Al Uqhuwan زهرة الأقحوان

A teacher of math changed from skirt to pants and went underground. With 13 other Jaffan women, Zahrat Al Uqhuwan (The Daisies), a secret organistaion, carried out strategic planning, armed resistance, and attacks during the defense of Jaffa 1947-1948.

“The fighting in Jaffa, in the Jabalia area, was extremely tough because it was right next to Tel Aviv. Do you know who led the resistance there? It was a woman commanding the volunteers there. Her name was Mouhiba Khroshid. This should be written in history.”

Musallam Bseiso, for Al Jazeera

Zahrat Al Uqhuwan 

In the fall of Palestinian cities and towns in 1948, Jaffa was among the ones that struggled the most. Jaffa’s highly modernized urban growth resulted in a quadrable population from the 1920s to the late 1940s. Many people arrived to the city from all over the region and from all over Palestine. This meant that a certain cohesion needed in times of war was lacking. The defense of Palestine and Jaffa was in the hands of the British Mandate, ‘Mandate’ meaning taking care of something. The British did not defend Jaffa or the Jaffans. Jaffans fought Zionist gangs for their lives, homes, and their city, until the very end. Jaffa fell when Palestine was still Palestine, two days before the state of Israel was declared. 

Secret oath on Thursday 20 February, in Jaffa in 1947: “I swear by my honor, my religion, and my denomination to be loyal to my principles and spend what is dear and precious for the sake of goodness to help the needy and weak”  was sworn by 14 women who also swore to keep their membership of  “Zahrat al Uqhuawan” a secret. The founding document had the signatures of Muslim and Christian Jaffan women including Yusra Toukan, Adla Fatayer, Fatma Abu Al-Huda, Victoria Humsi, Subhiya Awad, Khadija Kilani, Madiha Al-Batta, Najma Okasha, Maysar Daher, Saniya Irani, Faiza Shloun, Mabara Khaled and Najla Al-Asmar (who became leader of the Secret Land Organization). 

  مهيبة خورشيد، نريمان خورشيد، يسرا طوقان، عدلة فطاير، فاطمة أبو الهدى، نجلاء الأسمر، صبحية عوض، خديجة كيلاني، مديحة البطة، ميسر ضاهر، سنية إيراني، فايزة شلون، مبرة خالد، نجمة عكاشة. 

Later, during their operations, more women and some men joined the organisation.

Zahrat Al Uqhuwan started with charity and interfaith work. With the escalation of the organised terror attacks on Jaffa by Zionist gangs, Al Uqhuwan became an armed resistance group. The women collected rifles, grenades, and machine guns, and recruited more members. They joined men in armed operations as well as participated in demonstrations and collecting donations. Zahrat Al Uqhuwan was in the news: "Arab girls are in the first ranks of warriors,” wrote Jaffan Newspaper al-Difaa’ (Defense).And “Zahrat Al Uqhuwan restored Arab women to their historic dignity,” wrote Jaffan Falastin (Palestine) 

Sisters 

Muhiba Khorshid is the Palestinian founder and leader of the armed underground resistance, Al Uqhuwan. Muhiba was a feminist, a member of the ‘Arab Women's Association’, a strategist, and an excellent speaker. 

Muhiba was born in Jaffa on 18 April 1925. She studied Arabic Literature and Journalism and became a math teacher. She liked to sculpt and play the violin. Muhiba worked for equality and religious tolerance and was outspoken enough to be summoned for investigation by the British Mandate authorities. She was able to avoid the investigation by obtaining a false medical report. One day in early 1947, Muhiba saw a six-year-old Jaffan child being shot dead in his mother’s arms by a Zionist. That moment changed her life and she contacted the Palestinian chief in command Abdel Kader Al Husseini and that was the beginning of Al Uqhuwan. From that moment on, she worked fully with armed resistance, every day of the week. Muhiba developed as a resistance strategist, field fighter, and courageous leader who knew how to keep her group safe and supported. She worked across different borders of religion, gender, class, and armed hierarchies and she communicated directly with the highest resistance commanders. Twenty-five days before her city fell and she turned a refugee, Muhiba celebrated her 23rd birthday fighting and resisting, until Jaffa was occupied.

Nariman Kohrsheed, Muhiba’s younger sister was born in 1927 in Jaffa. Nariman was a secretary at a chemical plant in Tel Aviv before she joined the resistance. Her turning point was when she sat at home and watched from her window Zionists attacking a Jaffan bus and beating its passengers. On her way to work the same day, she saw a residential building being destroyed by Zionist terrorist organisations.

“What a tragedy! What is it I’m seeing? What happened to the Arab lands? Indeed, it is a great disaster that the tongue and the heart are unable to describe.” Nariman said at a public speech and was dismissed from her work because of that speech. Now the Uqhuwan had its second member. Nariman Khorshid led the training of the military section of Al Uqhuwan and was proud of wearing pants and being armed.

The Battlefield 

The Uqhuwan women fought side by side with men in the resistance, particularly in the areas of Karam al-Suwwan and Darwish neighborhoods in Jaffa. Resistance leaders Abdul Wahab al-Iraqi and Ali Bey al-Turki were impressed by their bravery and work and expressed their support. Nariman Khorshid tells how the Hagana Zionist gang (a terrorist group according to The British Mandate) tried to attack the Islamic Orphanage in the center of Jaffa. Ten women fighters from Al Uqhuwan stood on the battlefield alongside men in a combat that lasted three hours and resulted in one of the Uqhuwan women getting killed. The Zionist gang was defeated and withdrew from the orphanage. 

Nariman tells of another battle: “Once, my companions and I clashed in a heated battle with a strong terrorist gang. The fighting continued for a long time with grenades, machine guns, and rifles until we ran out of ammunition after we killed many. When our ammunition ran out, we were attacked with grenades and some shrapnel hit me. I passed out and almost fell captive in their hands. But God bless! A number of Arab soldiers were close to us, so it was difficult to take us captive. And the Arab soldiers rushed and rescued me.”

The orphanage survived the first attack, but “On January 4, 1948, a truck loaded with explosives covered with oranges exploded in front of the New Seraya, a government building housing an orphanage, the social welfare offices, and a kitchen for the poor. Thirty Jaffans, many of them orphan children were killed, and over 150 people were injured. Ismail Abu-Shehade was working at a garage nearby when he heard the explosion: “They claimed that the Seraya was a center for terrorists, but it was nothing but an orphanage. Lots of children were killed” (LeBor, 2017, p. 108). The bombing, by Jewish militants, terrorized Jaffa. Municipal services nearly ceased, and the middle-class exodus accelerated further. The Jewish Irgun militia (Etzel) knew when Jaffa residents would meet in cafes to hear the daily news broadcasts and would roll in barrels filled with explosives (LeBor, 2017, p. 111)...The port was overwhelmed with thousands of refugees cramming into small boats to find little space on larger vessels anchored out to sea. As the larger ships set off, they became targets of shells as they passed Tel Aviv, according to refugee Mustafa Hammami…We few families who stayed went to live in the orange groves” (LeBor, 2017, p. 117)...On April 25, three weeks before the end of the British Mandate, the Irgun attacked the Manshiyya neighborhood for six days…on 13 May, 24 hours before the declaration of Israel’s independence, Jaffa surrendered and was placed under Israeli military rule (Golan, 2009)...Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion declared in a cabinet meeting in June that “We must settle Jaffa, Jaffa will become a Jewish city” as Jewish troops began to loot property in vacant Palestinian homes (LeBor, 2017)...In July, the newly formed Israeli government created a Transfer Committee to prevent the return of the refugees and to settle new Jewish immigrants, including Holocaust refugees, in the now vacant homes.”

Since the British who occupied Palestine as a mandate to care for the land, were not protecting Jaffa in any way whatsoever, Muhiba and Nariman needed support from abroad. Nariman visited King Abdullah of Jordan on the recommendation of the Supreme Executive Committee. She also met the Chief in Command, Mufti, Hajj Amin Al-Husseini, in Syria. The Uqhuwan's resistance strategy worked locally, nationally, and internationally. 

As a result of the military success of the women's resistance, some male resistance fighters felt uncomfortable and attempted to stop Al Uqhuwan. On the 16th of March 1948, during one of the most difficult periods of fighting, Muhiba Khorshid sat down and wrote a letter to the highest command in Palestine, to commander in chief Haj Amin-al Husseini. In her letter, she named the men harassing the women’s armed struggle, including the general commander in Jaffa, Adel Najm al-Din al-Iraqi:

“... the commander of the Jabaliya region does not like the serious activity in our region as a result of the support we get, and our attacks on Zionist gangs in the Bat Yam region, where we inflicted heavy losses in lives and vehicles, while we had no losses. When it became clear to Sheikh Hassan Salameh that nothing would deter us from our determination to resist and struggle, he gave strict orders to stop us...”

Muhiba wanted a quick end to the harassment and more support for their work. To make sure, copies of the letter were sent to: ‘The Secretary General of the League of the Arab States’ - Abd al-Rahman Azzam Pasha, and ‘The commander of the Liberation Army in Damascus’.

The letter was signed “Fraternity – Devotion – Selflessness" Zahrat Al Uqhuwan.

Terror strategies through history: In 1799, Napoleon allowed hundreds of Jaffans to flee after the horrific massacre he and his army inflicted in Jaffa- so the news would spread horror. In 1948, while Jaffa was still under the British Mandate rule and protection, between 9-11 April over 100 Palestinians were massacred in the most horrific way in the village of Deir Yassin by Zionist militias (partly led by Menachem Begin). That massacre was meant to spread horror and a warning and was a turning point for unarmed Palestinians fleeing en masse. Yet villages, towns, and cities resisted. But on the 22nd of April, the north port city, Haifa, fell. When Jaffa was still under British rule and protection, on May 13th, 1948, two days before the State of Israel was declared, Jaffa fell to the Haganah Zionist militias. A Memorandum was presented by the representative of the Arab Higher Committee for Palestine (of whom Alfred Roch was a co-founder and member) at the UNO United Nations Organisation, reporting attacks and massacres against Palestinian Arab civilians. On April 24, the Israeli government announced the official unification of the Tel Aviv and Jaffa municipalities. Jaffa was over.

Al Uqhuwan women: Victoria Houmsi

The story of Zahrat Al Uqhuwan is one of Muslim and Christian Palestinian women, who were already active in the Jaffa urban scene in different fields. We don’t know about all the members because some members were loyal to their oath of keeping their membership a secret, until death. A few came out and we know that Victoria Houmsi was part of Zahrat Al Uqhuwan mainly focusing on intelligence, spying on British soldiers and Zionist gangs. Victoria was a renowned businesswoman and a co-owner of The Arabic Hotel in Jaffa before she bought her partner’s shares and became the sole owner of the hotel in 1939. The Arab Hotel was on al-Mahatta (Station) Street, a notable landmark in Jaffa until the Nakba when she was forced to flee to Jordan. Victoria Houmsi lost her hotel, home, and city. She kept the hotel keys, which are now with her grandson Khalil. 

 Al Uqhuwan women - Madiha Al Batta

In addition to Al Uqhuwan, feminist Jaffan women were involved in political life, to name just a few: Odette Azar, was a feminist intelligent Jaffan social organiser, and leader of demonstrations, Um Ghaleb Ad Dajjani, Um Kamal Abu Laban, Salwa Damashqiyya-Said and Samia Damashqiyya Abu El Jabeen and Yousra Touqan Abu El Jabeen, to name a few. More names and details need to surface in order to understand the intricate and crucial role of intellect and resistance that Jaffan women played.

Exile

Jaffa fell and was ethnically cleansed. From about 100,000-120,000 inhabitants, only 3,900 were able to stay. The ability to stay in Jaffa was regarded as a superpower by the Jaffans turned refugees. Nariman fled to Beirut via Jaffa port and later moved to Cairo. Like all Jaffans who had to flee and became refugees in one night, the Khorshid sisters were not allowed to return. Muhiba worked in teaching, got married, and had children. Nariman joined the Imbaba Aviation Institute in Egypt in July 1948 to train as a pilot. Nariman’s aim was to return to Jaffa, and twenty women joined her. She soon realised that she was not returning home. Nariman worked in an organic fertilizer company in Cairo, married, and had children. Muhiba died in 2008 and Nariman in 2015, both Al Uqhuwan leaders are buried in Cairo.

Jaffa: "On April 6, 1948, the settlers of Belarus had already fought the war, and this was before the Declaration of Independence was announced. Towards the end of the mandate, the Jewish Agency purchased the British Army camps, known as Camp 80 and Camp 87 adjacent to Pardes Hanna and this was supposed to be a smooth transfer. But this was a time of war…The Azerbaijan Organization that participated in the fight - and several weeks later even conquered Jaffa - sought a way to urgently obtain a large number of weapons and ammunition. The solution was to send Ezel fighters to Camp 80 disguised as British soldiers and to equip them with fake delivery certificates as if they came to pick up the equipment for the evacuation of the camp. At some point, the British camp commander suspected the Ezel men. A battle broke out and the Ezel men killed 7 British soldiers, including the commander himself, and one member of the Ezel, Yitzhak Kova.”

*In addition to the Uqhuwan, there were two other women’s resistance organizations in Palestine that we know of, plus multiple individual women resistance fighters. The groups were:

  • "The Black Palm" was a Palestinian women’s resistance organisation active in the Jerusalem area. Among other actions, the group sent threatening messages to the British Police, and some of its members were arrested, tried in military courts, and imprisoned. One of the group's members was Munira al-Khalidi, who was sent to prison in 1937.
  • “The Comrades of Qassam" was a women’s resistance group active alongside the “Al-Qassam Comrades”. This resistance group was founded in Haifa in 1930 and opposed British occupation.
  • Among individuals, the most famous is Fatma Khaskiyya who took part in the 1936-39 Great Rebellion and was a leader in 1948 and responsible for arms. She lost her daughter in battle but continued and turned refugee after she was wanted by Israel 'dead or alive'.

item.title: Welcome to the Masquerade
item.dc:creator: Sarah
item.content:encoded:
Roch: Oranges, Parties, and Resistance

Alfred Roch was a businessman, a crucial Palestinian politician, and a supporter of culture- and he excelled in all three. While a member of the Palestinian National League and at the height of WWI, a photograph of a masked ball held in his home at Easter in 1942 shows a group of wealthy Jaffans. Contemporary artist Joumana Manna’s  “A Sketch of Manners (Alfred Roch's Last Masquerade)” is a short video recreating this photograph.

Alfred Roch, 1882-1942 was one of the biggest citrus exporters, involved also in shipping, and a member of The Citrus Board.  Roch was one of the most prominent Jaffan Palestinian leaders during the British Mandate. He was also a renowned figure in the Roman Catholic community in Palestine and firmly opposed Zionism and colonialism. 

The Roch family was one of the biggest land and orchard owners as well as owners of numerous houses and well houses. In addition to business and politics, Alfred Roch enjoyed life. In 1911, he established a sporting club in Jaffa known as “Circle Sportive”, and his house parties and soirés were famous. Alfred and Olynda had two daughters Fortunée and Paulette*.

Roch was active, involved, and represented the Orthodox community in Jaffa.

Alfred Roch actively campaigned to get public support for the Arab Revolt in 1916 and the Ottoman authorities exiled him to Anatolia. After the end of World War I, he returned to his hometown and became an exporter of Jaffa oranges, especially to Britain. In 1927, Roch participated in founding the Palestine Free Party in Jaffa aiming at "complete independence [for Palestine] by realizing Palestinian national aspirations and sovereignty; defending personal freedoms of all kinds; [and] moving the country towards social and national unity." He was then chosen on 21 January 1930 by the Executive Committee of the Palestinian Arab Congress as a member of the Palestinian delegation that went to London to hold talks with British prime minister Ramsay MacDonald and the Minister of Colonies, Lord Passfield, about the repercussions of that uprising and demanded an end to Jewish immigration to Palestine, the confiscation of lands, and the transfer of their ownership to Zionist organizations. Roch joined the Palestine Arab Party to which he was elected vice-president.

On 20 April 1936, Alfred Roch signed a statement drafted by prominent Jaffa figures, which called upon residents to participate in the general strike and he was appointed to the committee overseeing the implementation of the strike. He became a member of the Arab Higher Committee, which lead the general strike and the Arab Revolt (1936-39). 

When the British Mandate authorities dissolved the Arab Higher Committee on 1 October 1937 and exiled some of its members to the Seychelles Islands, Roch was in Geneva, attending the proceedings of the League of Nations and campaigning for the Palestinian cause. He was barred from returning to Palestine for five years. Two years later, Roch was a member of the Palestinian delegation to the London conference held in February 1939 at St James's Palace in London. 

On 22 April 1942, just after he was allowed to return to Jaffa after 5 years of exile, Alfred Roch suffered a heart attack near the Apollo Cinema in the Ajami neighborhood of Jaffa, while he was on his way to his office. He was rushed to the city's **French Hospital, where he died shortly after arriving. His funeral procession was held the following day in Ajami, and he was buried in the Latin Cemetery of Jaffa. Roch died young but was saved from the Nakba. 

Alfred Roch’s daughter Paulette Roch 1913 - 2002 

Born in Jaffa, Palestine in al Ajami 1913. Paulette married Mr. Michel Tadros. Her children are Marie-Claude, Nadim, Nabil, Samir, and Raji. Alfred Roch’s grandchildren from Paulette’s side are Jean-Loup, Julien, Yasmina, Karim, Tarek, Théo, Roch, Hugo, Michel, Marc, Luana, and Marie-Reine, his great-grandchildren are Jana and Maude (all information is from 2002 from Paulettes’ obituary). Paulette Roch Tadros died in Montreal on August 28, 2002, at the age of 88 years and 8 months.

**Built in 1887 The French Hospital of Jaffa was one of the best hospitals in the city. The hospital and its chapel were turned into a hotel by Israelis.

item.title: Meet Count Talamas
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
and his Coat of Arms in Al Ajami, Jaffa

Musa Talamas is the son of Issa and Tecla Talams, born in Nazareth in 1627. Issa and Tecla had three daughters (Catarina, Elizabeth and Maria) and another son, Hanna, born in 1664. Musa Talamas married Maria Benyamin (a local surname). One of the sons moved to Jaffa, probably Musa, and that’s how the Talamases were established in Jaffa. 

Antoine Jiries De Talamas lived in Jaffa in the late 1800s and ran several Jaffa orange orchards. He was given the title of Count by the Roman Catholic Church with a Coat of Arms after he built St. Anthony's Church also known as the Latin Church. Antoine built the church down the road from the family villa. The street the villa and church stood on, was named "Count Talamas Street". Count Antoine De Talamas’s home still stands in the Ajami neighborhood of Jaffa today. The people who took over the villa after the occupation of Jaffa in 1948, have added two stories to the villa. The building now consists of four apartments. The crown on the lintel above the door is the only remaining clue that this was the residence of Count De Talamas and his family. St. George's Church survived. The orchards did not.

The Jaffa Shamouti oranges were a very lucrative export business, and Antoine Talamas decided to build the biggest church in Jaffa. In 1932 Talams built St. Anthony's Church in Neo-Gothic style, down the road from his villa. The church has stained glass windows and stands today as the first thing on number 1 Yefet Street (originally Hilwe Street). The distance between the Talamas villa and the church is less than a kilometer. Both the villa and the church are a short walk from Jaffa’s port and the Mediterranean.

*All Talamas photos from Facebook British Mandate Jerusalemites

Meet one of the Talams family members, Nathalie Handal, a writer, and poet

Jaffa, from Nathalie Handal's My East in Venice

“The previous year, I was having coffee with an Arab-Argentinian photographer at the Yafa Bookshop and Café. A man nearby apologized for intruding into our conversation and said, There is a house that the Talamas family owned in Old Jaffa port, close to The Old Man and the Sea restaurant, and it has a dream view. I asked him to explain which house he was speaking about. I was aware of the land my family once owned, but the photos I have are of houses on hills and orange groves. Today the city is completely urbanized. It takes effort to visualize where these old homes once stood.

My friend and I followed the man’s instructions. When we arrived at the location, we asked a Palestinian woman for help. She pointed to the remains of an old stone house on a plot of land not yet developed by the Israelis. The view of the sea filled my body quietly.

The Palestinian woman said, Now he lives in Ajami, a formerly affluent neighborhood turned Arab ghetto. Who, I asked? The man who owned this house, she replied. I grew hopeful.

I immediately called a local friend to help me find out more. The next day, we went to see a blind man said to know by heart one thousand telephone numbers. When we arrived at his office, he was behind his desk on the telephone asking for information about my uncle. My friend had briefed him about me. He put down the phone and told me, We had a person from the Handal family here. His wife was called Aziza. She was from Birzeit. They both died in Jaffa thirty years ago or so. Then he added, As for the Talamas… There was Badiyah Talamas who died in the 1970s, and Emily Talamas who married Benoit Alonzo, their children are in Italy…Milano…three sons and one daughter. He named two, Amadeo and Romano. I asked, Who is Emily? He told me she was the daughter of Count Talamas, a relative who apparently had been given that title by the Pope as he was a generous supporter of the church and the Vatican.

He proceeded to tell me that the uncle I was looking for was a bit sick and that he had three sisters, one in Amman who he thinks married someone from the Haifawi family. You know, he added, when families moved from one city to the city, their surname changed to the city they came from, Haifawi from Haifa, Nabulsi from Nablus. One rarely knew what the surname was before that.

That’s how information has been delivered to me throughout my life: pieces that need to be reassembled. My search has been among people afraid to speak for they’ve been tortured, or unable to speak for their wounds are too wrenched. And I’ve had to consider the cracks of memory, its blunders, the way information is transmitted from one person to the next, what was lost and forgotten, what was added.

The telephone rang. Someone had found my uncle’s number. As I listened to the blind man repeat it, the last three numbers, sitta, sab’a, thaalatha, echoed inside of me as if this were my last chance to meet a member of that generation. The call ended with the usual long Middle Eastern gratitudes: Shukran kteer kteer illak, shukran, bye bye, wala’himak, ahla. And with the final mumtaz, a common expression meaning “excellent,” we headed to my uncle’s house.

As we walked through Ajami, I tried to imagine the once-majestic multicultural Palestinian city of Jaffa. Taking a stroll down the grand boulevard to the lavish Alhambra Cinema, or along the port, through the winding alleyways of the Old City where some homes had striking views of the sea, sitting on the grand balconies of Mediterranean villas with lush gardens or in music halls and cafes. My thoughts strayed to the early 1950s, when Jaffa, once Palestine’s largest city, became known as the Tel Aviv-Yafo municipality, and Palestinians became a minority, forced to live in neglected neighborhoods, patrolled and closed off with barbed wire.

We stopped at an iconic green pharmacy where the owner knew the stories of all the families from Jaffa. And a little further down, to the right, was Dar Talamas Street, known today as Sha’arey Nikanor Street. I paused at number 9, Count Talamas’s house, which had been converted into eight Israeli apartments. I looked at every new name beside the buzzers and wondered what these inhabitants, or those before them, did with all of my family’s possessions: the furniture, paintings, albums, letters. How did they reconcile the fact that they slept in the houses of those forced into exile in Alexandria, Beirut, Trieste, Venice, Marseille, London, Paris, and Santiago?

As I walked away, the sun resting on my back, I felt the trauma of my relatives sinking inside of me. Those who fled and have to live with a void, those who stayed and are second-class citizens in Israel or imprisoned behind the wall in the West Bank, their lives twisted with frustration, grief, and adversity.

When I reached my uncle’s house, I paused. He had come outside to greet me. I was struck by the common family traits: the rectangular face, the blue eyes, the tall and long physique. We embraced as if we had known each other all of our lives. Two more family members came out to meet me, and they too had piercing eyes. They immediately served me drinks and sweets. I admired the patterned fern green, white, earth-toned, and purple-red Palestinian tiles. I was struck by how familiar the house was to that of my grandparents—the wooden furniture, the embroidered tablecloth, the ornaments—and also how it contained the same energy, one that is deeply alive despite all the loss, one that is cultured and proud. That vigor decorated the house.

My uncle explained that he came from the branch that didn’t have the money to flee by boat in 1948. He showed me photos. I was surprised by how many women were nuns. He mentioned that there was still one in Jerusalem, but then added that he thought she passed away. I knew too well that even when the miles between us weren’t much, the reality that separated us was interminable. Before I left, he gave me an envelope of photos and told me to visit my relatives in Venice who had a restaurant. When I asked for more information, he said, When you get to the train station, turn left and you’ll find it.”

item.title: Ahlan to the Berouti Home and Family
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
This is the photo album of Randa Berouti

Randa Berouti is an artist who creates mini-sculptures of gold, silver, and stones. The story of the Beroutis here is about Randa's father Charles Berouti, her grandparents Emile and Victoria Berouti and about her maternal grandparents the Halabis. This is a story of Jaffa and the family home in Al Ajami. The story continues after the Nakba in 1948 when the city was ethnically cleansed with pictures from exile. All the photos and information are from Randa Berouti’s private collection.

​​

“Four years after this wedding photo, when Nada was 27 and Charles 32 years old, they had to rush from the war zone with only enough money for a month. The British blocked all Palestinian money in the banks. With 3 babies. My brother was only 3 months old… Never allowed to return home. They fled to Damascus and then to Lebanon. They lived in one room in very hard conditions...” Randa Berouti, Wedding in Jaffa 1944

“The Arab accounts are twice blocked”: UK Treasury currency regulations (Feb 22, 1948) and Israeli Government “freeze order” (June 12, 1948)

On February 22, 1948, the British Treasury’s suddenly announced, “without any prior notice or explanation, that it would “exclude Palestine from the sterling area and henceforth suspend the free convertibility of Palestinian pounds into pounds sterling.” It also stated that the Palestine Currency Board would no longer, after May 14, 1948, continue to issue Palestinian pounds,” so that the “termination of the Mandate for Palestine would be accompanied with the end of Palestinian currency as legal tender.”

A History of Money in Palestine

Missing Checks, Vanished Funds: a Financial Accounting of the Palestinian Nakba of 1948

Exile

On 14 May 1948 Nada, 27, and 32-year-old Charles, rushed from the war zone with two children and a 3-month-old baby. They collected all the money they were able to because all bank accounts were blocked, in addition, the British soon declared that the Palestinian Pound ceased to exist which meant the cash you had was non-exchangeable. The Beroutis had money to sustain them for one month. They were like all other Jaffans, expecting to come back after 'things calmed down' in a few week or months, but after things calmed down, they were never allowed to return to their home or city.

In addition to sorrow, life continues with family moments, culture, and more weddings.

​​

item.title: Jaffans, Where Are You Now?
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
Would you like to share your Jaffan story? Please try to use as many details as possible relating to where your roots come from, names, anecdotes, and even trivial details and memories, or what other Jaffans memories you have heard. You can share here.

The Hamos Fled in a Buik

Waleed was born in Jaffa in 1941 and lived in the prosperous Al Nuzha neighborhood. He went to the “Hosni Al-Asmar Kindergarten” in 1945. Waleed’s grandfather exported high-quality Jaffa oranges to London and Britain and owned 400 dunums of orange orchards in Jaffa. The grandfather also owned shares of Al-Hamra Cinema. Waleed was seven years old when they had to flee the occupation of Jaffa. “I remember Al-Hamra and the other cinemas, Apollo and Nabeel. The Sakakini Market, the Iskandar Awad Market, and the many bakeries.”  Waleed is known as engineer Waleed Khaled Hamo.

1948 and Exile

The Hamo family owned a big car import business and shop in the center of the city. In 1948, they turned into refugees when the city fell. The grandparents, their seven children, their spouses, and all the grandchildren had to leave their birth city and were crammed into the family business cars. The Ford, Dodge, and Buick model 1936 were taken out of the shop vitrine and cramped. Waleed’s father Khaled Hamo drove the Buik, with the women of the family. They drove through the Palestinian towns of Anabta, Rafidiyeh, and Nablus. They stopped and rented a stone summer house in Nablus. After living in the best neighborhood in Jaffa with running water and electricity, Waleed remembers seven lanterns used for lighting and that the water was pumped from the nearby well to fill eleven barrels. Most Palestinians were sure of returning home after a while. Although the Hamo family lost the 400 dunums of orchards, the shares in the cinema, their network, and their homes, they were much better off than most Palestinian refugees. After a year of being refugees living in a summer house without water or electricity, the family moved to Baghdad in Iraq. After kindergarten in Jaffa, Waleed went to school and graduated from the University of Baghdad. He worked with the Union of Engineering and Environmental Consultants Company in Jordan, Amman, for 14 years. Waleed was also an engineer in Iraq, Kuwait, Sudan, Libya, North Yemen, South Yemen, Libya, and Sudan until he retired at the age of 69 years. Jaffan Waleed Hamo now lives in Atlanta, Georgia in the United States.

item.title: Khor Rori
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Khor Rori or Sumhuram as per the inscriptions found here, is located 40 km east of Salalah, Oman, on a hilltop on the eastern bank of a sweet-water inlet (khor), about 400 metres from the open sea. The remains of the settlement are located on a rocky spur running east-west. Khor Rori is one of the many creeks along the coast of the Arabian Peninsula, but what is unique here is that the creek opens into the sea to form a natural lagoon due to the presence of a sandbar. The geographical location of Khor Rori would have undoubtedly played a significant role in the settlement and the continued preoccupation of the site. The settlement is very clearly visible from the sea because of the two rocky promontories that protect the mouth of the creek, known as Wadi Darbat. The whole area along the coast abounds in precious sources of drinking water. Another important factor would have been the relative proximity of the settlement to the area where frankincense was grown, to which Sumhuram was connected by a network of settlements in the hinterland and on the other lay at a convenient distance from the sea. The site is often identified with Moscha Limen mentioned in the Periplus and may have formed the eastern outpost of the Hadramawt kingdom which ruled over Southern Arabian till the 3rd century BCE. The Periplus describes Moscha as “a port established for receiving the Sachalitic frankincense” (The Periplus of the Erythrean Sea, pp. 35). Moreover, the Periplus also describes  how Moscha was primarily a port where ships sailing towards India often sought refuge during the tempestuous winters. (Read more about the role of Khor Rori as a harbour of safety and refuge for wintering ships here.) This sprawling coastal settlement existed from at least the 4th century BCE to the 5th century CE indicating the continued importance of the site.

Khor Rori boasts of a unique geographical locale; this coastal plain of Oman has an environment distinct from the rest of Arabia, as it is quenched by the mists and rain of the south-west monsoon each summer, known as the khareef season. From approximately mid-June to mid-September upwelling in the ocean pounds the coast, while the coastal plain and mountains become a sea of green. On the west of these narrow coastal regions, which run parallel to the Indian Ocean are mountain ranges and plateaus, followed by the vast Arabian desert known as the Empty Quarters (Rub’ al Khali in Arabic). The coastal region hence has a particularly distinctive and diverse flora, ideal for the growth of frankincense trees (Boswellia sacra). Perhaps the unifying motivation behind all periods of occupation of this region, the most prized variety of frankincense grows on the back slopes of the Dhofar Mountains in Oman stretching into the Hadramawt region of Yemen. The availability of freshwater in the coastal areas has been the key to human settlements at sites in the region ever since the Neolithic era. Remains of several early human settlements have been found on the coast and just off the coast in the many wadis or dry river beds which drain into the sea. 

Discovery:

The discovery of Khor Rori is most commonly credited to James Theodore Bent, who discovered the site in 1895 with his wife Mabel. He also identified Khor Rori as being the same site described as Abyssapolis by Ptolemy. (Read more about Bent's discovery of Khor Rori here.) Since then, Khor Rori has been extensively excavated by several international archaeological missions, including the American Foundation for the Study of Man and the Italian Mission to Oman.

The settlement:

Excavations have shed light on the architectural structure of the city of Sumhuram which includes an impressive fortified settlement flanked on both sides by high towers and an elaborate gate complex. The gate complex extends about 21 m outwards from the walls highlighting its architectural importance and making the entrance easily visible from a great distance. The city had at least two main parallel streets with two market squares in between. Houses are located in the northern part of the city and remains of irrigation channels to divert water from the wadi to the residential areas have also been found. The city had an elaborate storage facility but an unusual feature was that it could be accessed only with two small doors: one which was located towards the city and the other led to the lagoon or the so-called port, suggesting limited access and control over what was stored. The chambers of the storerooms were plastered with a thick coat of mortar which probably helped to improve the conditions of conservation of the merchandise stored within. The presence of frankincense droplets found on the floor of these rooms suggest that they were used to store this precious merchandise. The most important structures of the city seem to be concentrated in the northern part, consisting of a gateway complex and a very large structure termed as the Palace-Temple, or the Monumental Building, which houses the only freshwater well in the city, construction around which has been dated to the earliest part of the city’s existence. The discovery of bronze waste at the site has also indicated that it functioned as a manufacturing center of some kind.

One of the most striking features of the city is the presence of at least three elaborate religious complexes both within and outside the city gates through different periods of occupation. While two shrines belonging to different periods have been identified within the city walls, an older shrine has been found outside the city, near the sea. The presence of three elaborate shrines at Khor Rori indicates the continued ritualistic pre-eminence of the site through different phases of the city’s history. The earliest shrine was located on the coast, accessed from the sea as well as from the city, but was later moved inside the city, protected within the heavy fortifications of the city walls. On the basis of material remains found from the shrines, including various ritual items and frankincense, archaeologists have argued that the shrines were visited by people living in the city as well as those from far off places, including some from across the Indian Ocean. Moreover, Khor Rori was not merely a trading settlement as commonly discussed in the current academic discourse, but was also linked with other Hadramawt temples in the region through various ritual networks. The detailed discussion of the three shrines in the next section will establish how the shrines may have served as places for social conglomeration as well as the ritual use of frankincense and not merely its role in the Indian Ocean trade circuit.

The shrines:

One of the multiple sacred places of worship in Khor Rori is a series of stones arranged around a circle around a water spring. The significance of water and the almost ritualistic importance attached to it since a very early period is evidenced in the presence of a unique formation at Khor Rori called the “Sacred Stone Circle”, discovered in 1958 by an excavation team led by Dr. Ray L. Cleveland. Located 250 meters to the north of the settlement, near a spring of potable water, the stones were arranged in an orderly, semi-circular manner and were placed around a rock mass under which a small cave could be identified. The prevalence of circumambulation in the Arabian Peninsula and the fact that the rock arrangement was located near a water spring, lead us to believe that this arrangement of rocks may have held a ritual significance. This belief is further strengthened by the discovery of similar stone circles in regions like Najran, which is home to the UNESCO-certified Ḥimā Cultural Area and was also an important landing place on the frankincense and myrrh trade route. Read more about the sacred stone circle of Khor Rori here. The primitive structure of the sacred stone circle may indicated that it predated the three other significant shrines discovered at Khor Rori.

The oldest built temple at Khor Rori, is what has been called by archaeologists as the temple extra muros or the temple outside the city wall at Khor Rori. This temple stands as an isolated structure to the northwest of the city close to Wadi Darbat, only a few hundred meters above the water level. Dated between the 3rd to 1st centuries BCE, archaeologists have suggested that this small temple was in use only during the earliest period of Sumhuram’s history since being located so close to the water, it may have been prone to frequent flooding, which  may also have been the cause of its final damage and abandonment. In its layout and orientation, the temple conforms to other Hadramawt shrines in the region. Remains of a stone altar as well as a sandstone offering table have been found in the shrine. A hollow cavity on top of the altar suggests that it might have been meant for holding a container such as an incense burner. 

Material remains found from this shrine include a highly decorated incense burner, pottery shards, fragments of bronze, two spindle whorls in bone and shell, 10 chlamys townsendi shells used as oil lamps and a necklace made of 73 shells of different families. 5 of a total of 12 stone objects found inside the temple were meant to crush products, which archaeologists have suggested were frankincense or other resins. 

A second temple, called the temple intra muros, or the temple inside the city walls, also known as the temple of Syn has been found located against the northwest corner of the city walls and has a layout similar to the older temple lying outside the city walls. Excavations have suggested at least two phases of construction of this shrine: The first phase between the 3rd  century BCE to the 3rd century CE and the second between the 3rd to the 5th century CE when several modifications were made to the shrine. On the basis of examination of other South Arabian shrines archaeologists have suggested that these might have contained bronze sculptures – an animal manifestation of the deity (usually a bull), which is associated with Sin or Syn. The architectural layout of the temple includes rows of pillars, a podium, and several side chambers.  In particular, one room with remains of food leftovers has been identified as the temple kitchen.

A large number of ritual objects have been found from this shrine including animal figures, shell incense burners, ornaments, ceramic vase with South Arabian character and a part of an offering table. Several bronze objects including the fragment of a jug with a horse spout, non-South-Arabian coins, a camel pendant and a bronze bell have also been recovered. The two most significant finds include a bronze bowl and a bronze incense burner with inscriptions naming the temple of Syn in the city of Sumhuram. A bronze plaque carrying a human face and an inscription, which mentions the temple of Syn, has also been found. The architectural layout of this shrine was in conformity with other shrines of Syn elsewhere in the Hadramawt kingdom.

A third shrine at Khor Rori is what has been labelled as the  urban shrine or the Palace-Temple and is located just behind the huge structure called the Monumental Building, which protects a freshwater well, possibly the only source of fresh water within the city. Archaeologists estimate this as probably the oldest part of the city. The urban shrine, similar in the style as the temple outside the city wall has a whitish plaster floor, which is lined up with benches also covered in plaster. The main focus of the shrine seems to be the altar, which is now badly preserved. Several architectural elements such as lintels, decorated blocks and pillars were discovered along with several incense burners. There is a striking serpent motif that appears in the decoration of small pillars set beside the altar. 

The ritual networks:

The shrines at Khor Rori, lying protected in the centre of the settlement, were religious spaces as well as places for enacting public ceremonies and ceremonial gatherings as indicated by the number of benches found within the shrines. On the basis of the architectural layout and ritual performance at the shrines, scholars have identified the three shrines at Khor Rori to be in conformity with other Hadramawt shrines found in different parts of Oman and Yemen, such as at Raybun, Shabwa, Makaynun etc.

Inscriptions found from the various shrines suggest that Sayin or Syn, to whom the temple of Sumhuram was also dedicated, was the federal god of the Hadramawt. Syn is identified as a lunar deity, and he can be traced as early as to the 6th century BCE through inscriptions. Temples dedicated to Syn have also been found at least in the Raybun oasis, Wadi Amd and Wadi Idim, and Shabwa. On the basis of epigraphic evidence from different Hadramawt shrines, it has been suggested that the Hadramawts had a polytheistic pantheon and that each region may have had its own distinct deity. The temples at Sumhuram can hence be located within this larger network of shrines which dotted the kingdom. A limestone plate with the image of a bull incised on it has also been found from the temple of Syn which indicates the association of the shrine with the lunar deity.

From the material remains found from the Hadramawt shrines, it is also possible to trace the ritual interconnections between the various shrines dedicated to Syn, which may have involved fumigation and offerings of incense and libation, ritual ablution, sacrifices and feasting. 

At the three shrines at Khor Rori, elaborate arrangements for storing water in the antechambers at the entrance of the shrines such as stone basins and large vessels have been excavated, which indicate traditions of ritual ablution and purification before entering the shrines. An elaborate system of ablution comes from the shrine near the Monumental Building where a freshwater well is located at the centre of the temple. To the west of the well is a large stone tank with a hole near the bottom. The building also contains a series of rooms that are plastered from wall-to-wall and have been identified as public baths. Freshwater was possibly also used in temple rituals as evident from some of the water vessels found in the sanctums of the shrines as well as for cleansing of the offering tables, which appear worn because of exposure to water. The importance of water to rituals can be reaffirmed by the fact that one of the shrines is situated in close proximity to the only freshwater well inside the city. It can also be suggested that the water well itself was precious and access to it was restricted by housing it in proximity to the sacred space. 

It is evident from the layout of the three shrines that the area near the podium, which included an altar and an offering table, was the most important part of the shrine. Blood sacrifices may have been performed here as evident from the findings of animal bones. Along with the bones of pig, goat, chicken, and fish, the bones of a whale have been found from the urban shrine. Other offerings included fruit, dates, and cereal. The floor of the shrine directly in front of the altar has been found covered with a thick deposit of ash, along with nuggets of frankincense, animal bones, small pieces of bronze, and bronze objects. That the rituals involved congregations is also evident from the rows of benches found at all temples, where the devotees may have sat and watched the ritual enactment. In addition, several small-sized stone and bronze objects have been found from the temple of Syn and in the extra muros temple at Khor Rori such as mortars made of stone and bronze, other bronze objects such as a bell, an inscribed bowl and pieces of jewellery, glass and shell beads, and dice, which may have been a part of donations to the shrines.

Remains of kitchens or refectories have also been found in most Hadramawt shrines including from the three shrines at Sumhuram, with evidence of cooking including an oven in rooms outside of the sanctum, which indicates that ritual feasting formed a core part of temple rituals. As per inscriptions, Syn is believed to have been a lunar deity who was worshipped and celebrated at holy banquets held inside the temples.

The shrines of Sumhuram such as the other Hadramawt shrines were embedded in networks of the circulation and ritual use of frankincense, fumigation being a central ritual. This is evident from the large numbers of incense burners of various types found at the shrines with residue of resin still stuck to their base. In addition, many shells and fragments of pottery have also been found that were used for incense burning along with mortars for crushing the frankincense. Large incense burners with pyramidal bases have been found placed at the centre of both the extra muros and the intra muros shrines along with many transportable votive burners. Incense burners in Sumhuram have also been found in houses, streets, fortification walls as well as from rubbish dumps, indicating the wide use of frankincense. It is also important to note that incense burners from other sites and geographical areas have also been found in Sumhuram, suggesting that people from other regions came to worship at the shrine of Syn and offered him frankincense.

The afterlife of Sumhuram:

There are various theories which suggest the abandonment of Sumhuram, including the sanding up of the harbour area. Political factors such as competition in the Aksumite and Sasanian trade may also have played an important part in destabilising the site. Even though Sumhuram may have been abandoned, by the 8th century the settlement had moved further to north to what is now Al Baleed. The remains of an elaborate mosque with a pillared courtyard is found here and is identified as probably one of the earliest mosques in the region.

The presence of the mosque on the one hand indicates the continued importance of the site in the proximity of the frankincense production centre, but moreover also suggests the centrality of a new place of worship in the vicinity of the earlier shrines at Sumhuram.

Heritage:

In 2000, UNESCO listed the Dhofar coast of Oman as the Frankincense Trail and a World Heritage Site, which was later renamed in 2005 as the UNESCO Land of Frankincense . As per the UNESCO listing:

“The frankincense trees of Wadi Dawkah and the remains of the caravan oasis of Shisr/Wubar and the affiliated ports of Khor Rori and Al Baleed vividly illustrate the trade in frankincense that flourished in the region for many centuries as one of the most important trading activities of the ancient world.”

In this unique listing, UNESCO has demarcated a geographical area, which includes both cultural heritage as well as natural heritage. The four components of the listing include three archaeological sites: (i) The Oasis of Shisr, lying 180 km north of Salalah, which was an agricultural oasis, and a caravan site and an important station for water supply on the routes from the hinterland to where the frankincense was brought on the port; (ii) Khor Rori and (iii) Al Baleed, which were successive ports and fortified settlements where frankincense was stored and traded. ; (iii) and finally The fourth site in the listing is the region of Wadi Dawkah (the Dohfar region) where frankincense trees still grow and are harvested. The four sites in Oman are nominated by virtue of embodying the cultural sites and landscape in which the trade of frankincense took place, from the Neolithic period to the Middle Islamic Period, northward through the desert routes and eastward and westward through the maritime routes going to India, and China and East Africa.

The site’s Outstanding Universal Value is defined by four elements, which illustrate the history, significance and continuity of frankincense trade in the region, one of the most important luxury items of trade of the Old World. However, the UNESCO listing and delineation of what constitutes the heritage of these ancient sites limits the scope of understanding the complexity and networks of these very early settlements in light of the role of frankincense as a commodity of luxury trade without acknowledging its importance in ritual practices. The four sites, which are included in this listing, emphasise the procurement, storage, trade and export of this luxury commodity. A major lacuna with this listing is that there is no indication of the local consumption and circulation of frankincense. 

Popular academic discourse places great emphasis on the economic and commercial significance of Khor Rori. However, it is important to reiterate that Khor Rori was not primarily a centre of trade and commerce for frankincense. In fact, the Periplus does not name Moscha as one of the principal ports of trade and commerce in the south Arabian region; rather, it was known to be a centre of production for frankincense for the kingdom of Hadramawt. Khor Rori may have became a part of the trade circuit on account of the frankincense it traded in exchange for goods like “cloth and wheat and sesame oil”(The Periplus of the Erythrean Sea, pp. 35) , possibly from Indian vessels that wintered at the port. Hence, while frankincense was produced and stored in Khor Rori, primarily, its trade was facilitated through ports like Kana. (Read more about Kana/Bir Ali here). While there is overt scholarly emphasis on the role of Roman demand for frankincense as controlling the rhythm of frankincense trade in the Indian Ocean, recent scholarship has also suggested how the kings of Hadramawt employed their own ancient versions of trade barriers and tariffs to protect their monopoly over the distribution of frankincense. Apart from placing trade barriers in place, the rulers of Hadramawt also placed more physical barriers in context of Khor Rori being fortified to militarily protect the frankincense-producing region. 

Ancient cosmopolitanism:

If one moves away from this narrow prism of over-emphasising the centrality of trade as the defining feature of ancient cultural networks and understanding the history of settlements around the Indian Ocean as being port cities and ancient harbours, the sites can provide useful information about several cultural and ritual linkages. The three shrines at Khor Rori, located on the coast, would have served as nodal points that were not just connected with the hinterland but also accessed from the sea and visited by various kinds of people as attested by the material remains found there. The shrines represent a cultural entity that tied together various religious networks in the region, which included the harvest and procurement of frankincense, the ritual use of this frankincense and through notions of pilgrimage and ritual feasting the movement of various people and ritual objects within the region of South Arabia as well as from across the ocean. Frankincense was an important ritual commodity, which circulated through the region along with pilgrims who travelled between these shrines and was not merely an item of luxury trade that was only exported outside of ancient South Arabia.

The objects found from the shrines of Khor Rori indicate widespread interactions with the outside world and a cosmopolitan character of the city. For instance, a substantial presence of Indian sailors at Sumhuram is evidenced by the Indian ceramic types such as the rouletted, black, and red ware found along with a pot-shard with Tamil Brahmi script. The fragmented rouletted ware, a variety of fine grey pottery found at Sumhuram, is the only evidence of this ceramic type found anywhere from the Arabian Peninsula and establishes direct maritime links with South Asia. One of the rarest objects to be found at Khor Rori is an Indian bronze figure of a female in a dancing pose believed to have come from western India. There is also evidence of graffiti on the city walls of Sumhuram which depict both the Arabian ships as well as the double masted Indian variety.  This further underscores the argument that the movement of people across the Indian Ocean did not merely involve the transport of trade commodities but also items of personal use or ritual objects such as the bronze female figurine. The unique geographical position of Sumhuram located on the Southern coast also underscores its importance as a hub which helped it to bridge two sailing circuits: one with India and the other with regions of the Gulf with sites such as Ed-Dur and Mleiha.

Visit and explore:

UNESCO has preserved the excavated structures and has also displayed the excavated artifacts from Khor Rori at the Sumhuram National Park. In fact, one can also watch archaeologists live at work at this fascinating site. One can also find interesting artefacts from Khor Rori at the Smithsonian National Museum of Asian Art, which is home to the figurine of the dancing yakshi, the Oman National Museum, Muscat, and at the Al Baleed Museum.

References and Further Reading

Avanzini, A et al. "Along the aroma and spice routes: The harbor of Sumhuram, its territory and the trade between the Mediterranean, Arabia and India". Arabia Antica: Pre-Islamic Culture and Archaeology, Bandecchi e Vivaldi, 2011.

Avanzini, A and Sedov, AV. "The stratigraphy of Sumhuram: new evidence". Proceedings of the Seminar of Arabian Studies, vol. 35, 2005, pp. 11-17.

Cleveland, Ray L. "The Sacred Stone Circle of Khor Rori (Dhofar)". Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research , Vol. 155, 1959, pp. 29-31.

"Land of Frankincense." UNESCO World Heritage Convention. Accessed 12 August 2023.

Kulshreshtha, Salila. "Practices of faith: The coastal shrines of ancient South Arabia." The Archaeology of Knowledge Traditions of the Indian Ocean World, pp. 175-190. Routledge India, 2020.

Pavan, Alexia and Esposti, MD. " The Urban Shrine in Quarter A at Sumhuram: Stratigraphy, Architecture Material Culture", Arabia Antica, 2016.

Sedov, Alexander V. and Batayi, Ahmad. "Temples of Ancient Hadramawt". Proceedings of the Seminar for Arabian Studies, Vol. 24, 1994, pp. 183-196.

Seland, Eivind Heldaas. "The Indian ships at Moscha and the Indo-Arabian trading circuit." Proceedings of the Seminar for Arabian Studies, Vol. 38, 2008, pp. 283-287.

The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Travel and trade in the Indian Ocean by a merchant of the first century, translated from the Greek and annotated by Wilfred H. SCHOFF, Logmans. Green and Co, New York 1912; Oriental Books Reprint Corporation, New Delhi. 1974.

item.title: Palácio de São Paulo
item.dc:creator: Salama
item.content:encoded:
In Stone Town, one monument that catches the attention is the Palace of São Paulo, also known as the Palácio dos Capitães-Generais, painted in bright magenta colours.

Probably constructed using the basis of a former defensive tower, the building was erected between 1619 and 1635, to house the College of the Society of Jesus, with an annexed chapel of São Paulo, of baroque style.

Suffering several alterations in its usability and architecture as the centuries passed. With the Jesuits expelled from the Kingdom of Portugal, the building was transformed into a Palace to host the Governor of Mozambique, changing its name to Palácio dos Capitães-Generais and later to Palace of the Governor, remaining the administrative centre of the country until 1898, when the capital of Moçambique moved to South, to Lourenço Marques. The Palace was then inhabited by the Governor of the Moçambique District until 1935, again with the administrative capacity being moved to current Nampula city.

Without frequent usage, in 1969 the Palace was remodeled to mark the construction of the bridge that connects the Island of Mozambique to the mainland.

In 1975, Samora Correia slept at the Palace on its way to Maputo. Shortly after, the first President of Mozambique declared the Palace to be transformed into a museum, being restored in 1990.

Today the building showcases eighteenth-century architecture, hosting two museums: the Navy Museum and the Museum-Palace of São Paulo, holding one of the biggest collections of indo-portuguese types of furniture, and art.

Adjacent to the Palace it is the Misericórdia Church that hosts the Museum of Sacred Art.

To know more:

item.title: Photo Album: Jaffa's Sea
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
Jaffa was a port town already during the Bronze and Iron Ages. The sea made Jaffa and there’s no Jaffa without its Mediterranean. Jaffans call their hometown “Mother of Strangers” because the city embraced everyone, including all the strangers who arrived at its shores. There's the sea with fishermen and sailors, there's Jaffa's port with pilgrims, tourists and export of Jaffa oranges. And then there is the beach that followed the blooming of business and growth of the urban city, the beach became a place of leisure. Jaffa's port turned into the place where Jaffan were pushed to flee, and the spot of the turn of Jaffans to refugees.

Jaffan fishermen, son and father and a group in a cafe by the sea, 1930 source Women for Palestine

item.title: Photo Album: Jaffan Weddings
item.dc:creator: Umayya
item.content:encoded:
Who is recorded and who is invisible? Jaffans fled their city suddenly in one day, and all their belongings including photographs and memoirs, are gone. The homes and all archives of the city were taken over by the State of Israel. What is left of the biggest city of Palestine is haphazard images and documents popping up here and there. What reaches us is mostly photographs of the richest families who left the city earlier with some of their belongings. In addition to that, at the turn of the century and until Jaffa fell in 1948, not many had the means to photograph their lives, weddings, or homes. This leaves us with a clear gap in the visual heritage and a dichotomy in the Palestinian identity of the extremely affluent or the very poor in refugee camps. Jaffa was an extremely diverse city, on many levels, and that is important to keep in mind. Because of pilgrims and tourists from all over the world, Palestine was one of the first and most photographed places in the world. The copyright of photographs, documents, and films, has restricted the accessibility of Jaffans to the only thing left of their own city, history, imagery, memories, and heritage. With the greatest respect to the hard work of professionals and amateurs, in this case of memoricide, we think that the ethical right of humans to access their heritage and history surpasses some cases of copyright. We would thank every effort to make this site perfectly copyright-full, until then, indigenous Jaffans have a right to access their visual and archival worlds.

Jaffa Orange is the IP, Intellectual Property of the Palestinian city of Jaffa. Developed after experimentations at the Shammouti family groves and became commercial around 1865. After 1948 when Israel occupied the land, it started exporting Jaffa Oranges under the name Tel-Aviv, but that did not succeed. Jaffa Orange is one of the very few surviving intellectual and tangible heritage of the erased city of Jaffa.

item.title: Photo Album: Urban Jaffa
item.dc:creator: Salama
item.content:encoded:
By the Bronze Age Jaffa was a bustling port town. In the 1930s and more so in the 1940s, Jaffa was a full-blown diverse and cosmopolitan city and the export center and the entrance to Palestine. Jaffa had cabarets, bars, 18 cinemas, theatres, and the cultural and entertainment area was known as The Cafe Area. Jaffa had more public bathhouses than mosques and churches. It had 27 schools, banks, tile and textile factories, high-end shopping, markets, a railway station. Jaffa had the majority of Palestine's publishing and printing houses and was the intellectual center of Palestine. Jaffa was the urban capital of Palestine. With a new masterplan, Jaffa was planning an expansion of its urbanism.

King George Street, note the Jaffa water tower in the top right corner, Matson Collection / Palestine Remembered

Jaffa’s Masterplan was published in 1946. It is the work of Egyptian engineer Ali Mas’oud and city planner Osman Rostum. The ambitious plan included schemes for new housing projects, transportation infrastructures, public parks, and the development of the city's waterfront. The proposal positioned Jaffa at the forefront of urban development in Palestine and envisioned its future within a broader regional landscape.
